content:
, 2014
„All those street brawls. It’s amazing I lived as long as I did.” ~RonanMURDERED: Soul Suspect is a new game made by Airtight Games, known from their other, warmly acclaimed production: Quantum Conundrum. This time, instead of a puzzle-adventure game devs made sure to provide us with a polished action-adventure suspense story backed with a supernatural mystery. Although professional reviewers are mostly critical about this game, I’ll try to convince You that it’s actually worth both its price and Your attention.The Game starts on a high note, with our protagonist – reformed cop Ronan - falling to his death after brutal fight with a mysterious murderer haunting the streets of modern day Salem. Soon he comes to his senses, only to discover that death itself was just a beginning. We end up being trapped on earth, but in a new ghostly form, with our mind set on a one simple goal: to complete our unfinished business, and finally move on to the other side.Unfortunately for Ronan, this unfinished business involves solving this one last case, which ultimately led him to his own demise by the hand of a dreadful Bell Killer. Luckily our hero is a fast learner, and easily adapts to the new state he’s woken up to. On our quest to hunt down the killer we’ll be using Ronans wits and experience gained as a police detective to find new leads, connect evidences and even access past memories imprinted into the ghost-realms fabric.The game consists of two different gameplay modes – first being a free roam explorations, during which we use our ability to pass through objects, summon or cast away solid fragments of the past Salem, and later even teleport to pass beautifully designed locations while finding as much collectibles as we can, and second being much slower ‘investigation mode.’The investigations are the most iconic moments of the game, and thanks to their presence many players felt obliged to describe Soul Suspect as “L.A. Noirish”. I’d argue with this opinion, because although in both games we progress through solving some cases the feeling of those is definitely different. In Soul Suspect we conduct our investigations with appropriate supernatural twist by correctly influencing possessed people, linking uncovered evidences or even accessing past memories lingering in the ghostly Salem. In turn Soul Suspects system feels much more simple, and dynamic in comparison to L.A. Noires ‘adjust and question’ model.Leaving gameplay behind, the strongest point of the game is definitely its scenario. With perfectly written characters and interesting plot twists, Ronans crusade against Bell Killer will be a memorable experience appealing to every gamer. The locations inspired by some of the Salems most iconic buildings are recreated in a great detail, and greatly contributes to the games spooky atmosphere. The whole experience is polished by believable voice overs and sounds, with only minor flaw being games music which felt somehow nonexistent.The only serious drawback of the game, is the large amount of collectibles, that makes even ‘Alan Wake’ blush in shame. It’s actually hard to move more than 5 ft without stumbling upon some new note, item or a graffiti flooding us with new information either related to our investigation or the Ronans past. All those stories are pretty well written, but the sheer number of those papers seriously affects immersion preventing us from fully diving into the games world.Murdered: Soul Suspect is definitely worth getting and trying especially for its captivating story. The game is definitely a must have for every supernatural events enthusiast, shining brightly in comparison with other productions picking up this subject. And if after reading the above review You're still unconvinced, I'd like to tell You that in this game You can possess a cat, and fool around in its body!Pros:- Agitating suspense story with supernatural twist.- Smooth controls with both mouse/keyboard and x-box controler.- Lots of witty puzzles and logic investigations.- Interesting ghost-powers affecting gameplay.- Clever world design with parts of the past Salem overlying its modern streets.- Really spooky side stories to unlock.- Can possess a cat!Cons:- Game’s a bit short, with full play through taking about 8-9 hours.- A high number of collectibles seriously affects immersion.- Due to its nature game is linear.

content:
er 2, 2015
												Well, I did not know who Airtight Games was up until now but doing 2 consecutive walkthroughs of Soul Suspect will certainly make me remember them for a while! This is a third-person view adventure game that employs some stealth elements and lots of crime scene investigation gameplay mechanics.The story follows Ronan, a con-turned-detective who has just been murdered and whose soul - for some reason - cannot leave this world and proceed to Heaven where his wife awaits. We soon learn his killer is the one he was originally after - a couple of cutscenes later his memory is refreshed and he is certain he needs to solve the mystery of the Bell Killer who has been haunting his residential town for a while so that by solving the murder case he can peacefully enter Paradise.Now, when playing this game I was constantly thinking of the adventure games released by Telltale Games. Why? Because the puzzles are easy and there is a great emphasis on the story immersion. Unlike those Telltale adventures Murdered allows you to control the protagonist and freely walk around in Salem. Still, I wouldn't really call this an open-world journey as many places are only accessible if the story demands it - the "hub area" is mainly for collectibles and a couple of side missions where you help other ghosts finish their business and ascend once and for all.Then come the demons. Certain sections require you to hide from the beasts and approach them while they turn away - execution is not mandatory but collecting evidence and other "artifacts" in the areas require you to rid Salem of them for good. While the game is not difficult, at all, and lacks any real combat it does have a great story. I almost completed it in one sitting as I really wanted to see the antagonist dealt with. Murdered has a great atmosphere which is accompanied by a great score and very well done voice acting.To summarise: if you are in for a great story and for something new and you do not mind that one playthrough gives you all the experience (a 2nd should only be done for the collectibles) then Soul Suspect is an easy grab - especially with a discount!

												Vou tentar ser meio breve aqui, mesmo que não consiga. Os trailers do jogo deixam qualquer um muito ancioso para jogar, porém, dependendo do tipo de pessoa, possa vir a se decepcionar com o que encontrará dentro do jogo.Para quem espera algum tipo de luta, velocidade, tiros, qualquer tipo de ação em geral, não vai encontar isso por essas bandas. O jogo é quase que um livro animado, para quem é acostumado e gosta de ler bastante, vai adorar (Assim como eu gostei bastante). A história pode não ser perfeitamente feita e maravilhosa, eu particulamente achei que o motivo de toda a confusão poderia ter uma explicação mais interessante, ou melhor dizendo, o motivo de tudo poderia ser outro, essa parte da história poderia ser mudada para algo melhor ( Só minha opinião por sinal, não deixa de ser interessante. )''Murdered - Soul Suspect'' não é um jogo de muitas horas, se você seguir direto para o final da história principal ( Deve durar mais ou menos 8 horas, algo assim.) Mas caso não o faça, tem muito o que explorar, muita informações escondidas pela cidade de Salem, além das sidequests, que basicamente é onde você, Ronan, faz uma boa e manda os fantasmas presos a terra para o céu, aliviando a dor que eles tinham devido alguma dúvida.Pessoalmente falando, o que mais gostei no jogo foram as informações pelo mapa sobre tudo, todas as histórias que faziam a atmosfera da cidade ficar ainda mais sombria.------------------------------------------I'll try to be brief here, even if I fail. The trailers of the game let anyone excited to play, however, depending on the type of person is likely to be disappointed with what you find in the game.For those expecting some kind of fight, speed, shots, any kind of action in general, will NOT find it for these bands. The game is almost an animated book. For anyone who is used to and likes to read a lot, you'll love (Just as I quite liked). The history is not that perfect and wonderful, I thought particularly the reason for all the confusion could have a more interesting explanation, or rather, could another part of this story be changed to something better ( Just my opinion by the way, it is still interesting.)'' Murdered - Soul Suspect'' is not a game for many hours, if you go straight to the end of the main story (should last roughly 8 hours, something like that.) But if you do not, have a lot to explore , a lot of hidden information by the City of Salem, besides the side quests, which basically is where you, Ronan, is a good soul and sends the ghosts trapped in the earth to heaven, relieving pain because they had any questions.Personally speaking, what I liked the most about the game was the information about the map everything, all the stories that made the atmosphere of the city get even murkier.

content:
7, 2015
												This is a fine example of style over substance. The voice acting is solid, the writing is generally okay (it's cliched at times, but has some decent moments) and it looks good. Unfortunately, it is hampered by gameplay which ranges from mediocre to bad. On the mediocre side, you are given a mere handful of skills, which are used remarkably infrequently and only in very obvious situations. The detective aspect has some good aspects, but while it mostly avoids LA Noire's tendency towards arbitrary and frustrating sleuthing, it does so by making things terribly obvious and having no consequences for failure. My favourite was a scene where you have to find a key. Not only does the game tell you how to go about getting to the key, it then presents you with a puzzle to pick it up, where you have to choose between the key, a fork and a spoon. Spoiler: the correct answer is the key.As for the bad, the combat is hideous. Awkward controls, very limited options and overwhelming noise make for a frustrating experience.There's plenty of collectables in the game, some of which are at least a mild challenge to get, but unless you're really into that aspect of it, you're better off just watching the story on YouTube.

content:
6, 2014
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is a detective puzzle(?) game, with some action(?) elements. You play as Ronan O’Connor, a cop whose wife died. That's all the back story the game has to offer. Though there was a bunch of collectables, each one had around 2-3 sentences of boring info. So I never bothered to read them, as it wasn't engaging or well wrote at all (much like this review). Ronan is murdered at the start of the game by the Bell-Tower Killer, who Ronan was hunting down. He soon discovers he is a ghost, and he must solve his death to move on to the afterlife. The game is open world, in the sense it has a hub of sorts between missions. It's literally just filler to add time to the game as you walk a short distance to the next area. The hub is littered with collectables to find, but they glow up so it's easy to get them all quickly. Investigations are poorly done. The only game I could compare this to is L.A Noire. But this feels like the poor man's L.A Noire. It's a total cheap knock-off. Asians are not only making fake American clothing, but games now too. You are thrown into an area and must walk about looking for clues. There is no indication of what might be a clue, so sometimes you could be spending upwards 10 minutes looking for the final one. Only to stumble upon by sheer luck, Whereas in L.A Noire, the controller would vibrate, or a jingle would play. The clues are also really badly thought out. Most of them are just one word, or a little phrase. Instead of finding proper evidence, you'll get one word like "damage", or "scratch". It's as if no thought was poured into the game. The only action in the game consists of you running up behind demons and holding a key, then pressing a QTE prompt that's displayed. There are no more than 20-30 demons in the entire game, so this was very lackluster. Concluding investigations was poorly done. You'd be shown all the evidence you have found, and must select 1-3 different pieces you think are most relevant to the question asked. But this could be rather arbitrary. As the clues were poorly explained, it was hard at times to figure out the most relevant ones. There are 3 badges displayed at the bottom of the screen. I at first assumed these were lives, and that if I messed up 3 times I would have to start again. But it turned out they are not. There is no failing. If you get it wrong, there are no consequences at all. As there is no point/scoring system, or achievement for getting all 3 badges in every case. Overall, the story was pretty meh. There was not much to it, and it was rather cliché. Nothing was really explained either, or made much sense. The main focus was figuring out the murders, but there were random things to do with other people tacked in, which seemed silly. Gameplay was pretty bad. Being a ghost was cool, but there were issues with walking through walls. Investigations were poorly done. Again, if you expect another L.A Noire, you're gonna be seriously disappointed. Most actions were performed with pressing a key or two, and there was just nothing to it. You walk up to an item and hit E. There was no examining it, or any of that jazz. Action was non-existent. The whole demon business was stupid and pointless. The game takes around 9 hours to complete 100%. Rushing the story and ignoring the collectables will probably reduce that time by around 3-4 hours. I do not recommend this game, even on sale. It was a drag to play, and I only did so because of the Playfire Rewards.

content:
er 8, 2016
 Overview  Murdered: Soul Suspect is a mystery adventure game played in the third-person perspective of Detective Ronan O'Connor a career criminal turned cop, who is hot on the trail of the notorious "Bell Killer" in the quiet town of Salem, Massachusetts. The opening scene will introduce you to an elusive killer, Detective O'Connor and an unknown teenager. The failed capture of the Bell Killer leaves Detective O'Connor dead, the girl missing and the killer still at large. It is now up to you to solve your own murder and find out what happened before your soul can move on.It should be noted that none of what I mentioned above is, in any way, a spoiler. This occurs minutes into starting a new game. However, it stands as an interesting premise, one I honestly can't recall playing in the past. With that being said, Murdered: Soul Suspect has been a very difficult game to pinpoint. I found myself motivated by the main storyline, but often pulled astray by lackluster side missions and shoddy combat junctions. The end was worth the time invested, but getting there was one of uncertainty; let's start from the beginning.For those that don't know the history of Salem, Massachusetts, it is infamously known for the capture, trials and executions of accused witches circa 1692-1693. The game takes place entirely within a small suburb of Salem and the lore of the game is derived from such [so much so it practically beats you over the head with it]. While previous knowledge of these events aren't necessary, as the game will give you over two-hundred collectables that provide details of such events, it is interesting to see what was influenced from the town's history or forced to make deductive conclusions from seemingly illogical perspectives.During the course of your investigation you'll meet others [both dead and living] that will help you on your journey, providing clues that propel you closer to the truth. Here is where I had mixed feelings about the game. You see, the main story I found compelling and the script did a wonderful job of teasing you with tiny, minute details without giving you much of anything to go on. Then, however, you're side-tracked with boring side missions and dreadful combat. As you were warned, you must occasionally fight demons whose sole purpose is to consume your ghostly essence, but luckily Ronan has the ability to banish these demons with the power of obnoxious QTEs; where he gets these powers is never explained. Whenever I was forced to fight these demons I found it painfully annoying. These encounters felt forced, stuffed into the fabric of the game where the suspense waned and a hole needed to be plugged. I hated the combat to the point I chose to simply die each time I got caught and reload as opposed to actually killing the demons.Demons aside, Soul Suspect suffers from several other shortcomings: repeating dialogue between NPCs, useless abilities like "Poltergeist", which gave me the ability to possess electrical devices during plot convenient sequences, the ability to read minds when it was necessary and the ability to teleport. Even with all of these powers I still felt like a poor excuse for a ghost, the store brand product of something better. The game gives you these abilities, but then severely limits you to what you're able to do with them. Even as a ghost, I couldn't indiscriminately walk through walls, forcing Ronan to avoid "ghost walls" or spiritual residue from old structures and objects, all of which prohibited walking through; Invisible walls for ghosts you might call them. It is never explained why they exist or the reasoning behind them.The strangest thing about the game isn't the main story, which is surprisingly solid, but the extras the game throws in to expand its own longevity. The side missions were dull, the collectables were seemingly unnecessary outside achievement hunting and the combat was utterly pointless. Woven between these shortcomings was a tapestry of mystery that could have been so much more if the effort was put elsewhere. Instead were given bits of possibility only to be disappointed. Forgo the extras and put that effort into Ronan's murder and you have a great murder mystery to solve. However, you never really feel like a true ghost, nor really even a mediocre detective. Murdered: Soul Suspect is a case of trying to do too much and spreading your content too thin. The phrase "less is more" fits this game all too well.  Pros  Voice Acting - I was surprised by how good it actually was done. Atmosphere - I really liked the environment, music and background effects of the game. The creepy, "ghostly" vibe never let up.Main story - It kept me hooked until the end. Cons  
The combat is forgettable, the demon portals just stand as roadblocks if nothing else.  The "stealth" aspects are impossible to fail, even if you try. Zero replayability. Overall, Murdered: Soul Suspect is good, but not great. It has a lot of hiccups that, if you can look past, has something interesting to offer. The story is intriguing, the voice acting is well done and some of the characters are interesting. I'd cautiously recommend it if you can find it on sale, but don't except a masterpiece if you pick it up. Case closed.

content:
r 17, 2015
												I will make this one very simple for you: Do you love collecting ♥♥♥♥? I mean, really REALLY love collecting ♥♥♥♥? Is all you ask of a game that you push a button, hear a pleasing jingle, and see the "X out of Y" counter increment? Because if you do, you will love this game. And if you don't... well, let's talk.Murdered is the tale of the tragically-named Ronan O'Connor, loose cannon of the Salem PD with nothing to lose. The game opens with him getting ventilated by the world's least-subtle-slash-least-catchable murderer, the Bell Killer, and you spend the rest of the running time trying to figure out why. Well, that's a lie. You spend most of the running time wandering around Salem, ghosting through walls and people in search of the 242 collectable knick-knacks scattered throughout the city. While some require your ghostly powers to reach or reveal, most are just sitting out, waiting for you to mash X on. Each one gives you a tiny snippet of backstory on the characters or Salem if you bother to open the menu, and a few let you hear a cute creepypasta story if you collect the whole set.If you're wondering why I haven't talked about the core gameplay yet, that's because it's dogshit. No lie, the investigations in Murdered are probably the worst of their kind. At every major story beat, you have a crime scene you need to investigate for clues to answer a specific question. Around the scene you'll find plenty more doodads sitting out for you to mash X on, each giving you a clue. After finding all the clues, you have to pick the clues that are the most relevant to answering the question at hand. This is where it all falls apart, because the expectations of the developers in picking answers ranges from so obvious you'll miss it to absolutely non-nonsensical. You're either going to breeze through every investigation or stumble over every answer depending on how well your brain is wired like the developers. Not that it matters either way, because there is literally no penalty for ♥♥♥♥ing up an answer, you just try again.So that's how Murdered plays, terrible detective sequences broken up by fits of collection-sperging. If that was all, we could flip it the bird and move on with our lives. The weird part is, everything else about the game is fantastic. The graphics are gorgeous and detailed, bringing the town of Salem and its residents (living or dead) alive. Sound direction is on point with satisfying effects and a moody, fitting soundtrack. The characters are charming and memorable despite what seems like every effort to make them obnoxious. Bad-boy Ronan is vulnerable and compassionate, manic goth-girl Joy is plucky and nuanced, and the entire supporting cast is interesting in their own ways. Your ghost powers also keep things fresh, allowing you to possess people to intrude on their idle thoughts, or poltergeist their appliances to freak them out. There's even some stealth combat against some pretty horrifying demons that's simple, engaging, and a welcome break from the running and collecting.I'm not going to pretend Murdered is a great game, or great for everyone. But even after identifying its flaws, I had a blast with it. Full disclosure, I watched my buddy stream the entire game months ago, and still had enough fun with it to play through the whole thing myself. A lot of your enjoyment is certainly going to hinge on the collect-a-thon aspect, but if you get into the story and learn to love Salem and its characters, there's a perfectly good game to be had here.

												The game is a supernatural detective thriller, where you play as a detective who was working at the Salem Police Department. The game takes place in the city of Salem, Salem is known as one of the most famous witch trials in the United States. In the game you are a detective who tries to find out who his killer was, Ronan. The killer is known as: The Bell Killer. The police has no clues, no leads and no links between his victims. In the game you have the freedom to explore the modern-day town of Salem. Except trying to find out who his killer was, you can also solve the other side quests from another ghosts like you. They also wants to know something, like: how they died or did my boyfriend cheated with another woman before I died?When you first play you start with a cutscene that tells you the most important things you need to know at the beginning. After the cutscene you fell of a window and tells the most imptorant things of his past. After these cutscenes you can play the game, but the soul of your body got out after the incident. So you'll be trying to get in your body, but after getting shot by seven gunshots at your chest. Your body dies except the soul. He became a ghost, because he tries to resolve who his killer was. Normal people can't see you, except mediums. But there are also purposes of becoming a soul, you have abilities that you never had before like. Some of them are: Teleporting, manipulating- and to influence people. Souls can only die by Demons, whoa are trying to eat your soul and you die also by a red/black creepy hole. My Impressions of the game:The game is really amazing and I had most of the times fun. The game looks in my opinion like The Wolf Among Us and L.A. Noire. In The Wolf Among Us you'll fall from a window too at the beginning, coincidence?The Pros and Cons.Pros- The game got good graphics- The game has besides a good main story, also good side missions- The game has trading cards- The game audio is well-madeCons- Sometimes there are too much demons in one room- The normal price is a little bit expensive This game is definitely worth a shot if it is discounted for a reasonable price. content:
13
												I bought this game when it was on sale for only $3.00, so the price was not an issue for me - but now having played it all the way through I can genuinely say I would not have regretted paying $30.00 for such an enjoyable, atmospheric experience.Storybuilding was phenomenal - from beginning to middle to end, there was never a dull moment as I was deeply engaged the entire time. I grew attached to the protagonist Ronan O'Connor fairly quickly, especially as you begin to uncover clues about his past. I bought everything the developers sold me about the "ghost realm" and how it functions (such as there being consecrated "obstructions" that ghosts can't pass through - perhaps not the most realistic idea to some, but considering we're dealing with a video game, I found it to be a very reasonable and clever excuse to keep the player's area of exploration streamlined but not restricted). The way that one investigation would lead to the next felt natural and smooth. Towards the end of the game I started to grow fearful that I would be disappointed by the conclusion, but I absolutely was not. From start to finish the plot was well-thought out and brilliantly executed.The worst part of this game to me are the demon-hunting sequences. In all fairness I've never been much for destroying enemies, but even moreso than usual I found them to be an annoyance. Luckily individual demons follow their own path on a loop, but when there's more than one to an area it can become much trickier to get the timing right. Really, though, it just takes a lot of careful planning and mapping out your steps in advance.Otherwise, for negatives, the autosave feature is a bit of a pain because I had to leave the game up & running at all times until I finished. That is, you cannot save your game on your own time, the game chooses when to save FOR you. So then if you exit & reopen the game, you'll be started back at the beginning of the last area you entered instead of specifically where you left off. Also, there are some parts of the game where you have to select the "most useful" clue(s) and while I got most of them easily, there were a few where the logic was simply lost on me.The 38.9 hours I spent on this game only accounts for 1 playthrough - I know the average person doesn't take NEARLY as long to finish, but I'm a born-again explorer and spent a ton of extra time scanning the environment in every direction, every corner, every wall I could pass through and even revisiting areas I'd already been to in case I missed anything. So if you enjoy being thorough like me, it is possible to make this game last a long time which adds to its value.Also, there are multiple occasions where you can play as a cat. A+++

This is a unique game to be honest, because it surprised me, a whole lot.Imma do it like they all do, cus it's easier to understand reviews, so here:PROS:-An unique experience (for now)There aren't many games with it's concept being you die and become a ghost solving your murder (not really a spoiler, because the title spoils it all then), and this one is from my perspective done exceptionally well.-Voice QualityI can't say this is the best voice quality I heard, but the voice is mixed and put together, doing its job of keeping you on your toes, really well.-GraphicsFor the graphics maniacs and the graphicsrexics this is a meet down the middle. For its scenery and location, the graphics fit really good, since it gives this dark, mysterious vibe with a dash of detectiveness.-StoryOh. I absolutely loved the story (I haven't finished it yet (at about 7,5 hrs right now) but I know I'll be too lazy to edit this review, but I know I'll love it, so y'know), and some moments in it are a really well done,unique, some other important adjective of a moment. It's what it is - great.-DemonsWell, I wasn't really expecting them and I was scared sh*tless at first (still am at times ;D), but you get used to them. They offer a new type of enemy, but in an interesting form, making it something you probably won't see soon.-CluesThese little sons'a'b*tches are tricky but fo' real entertaining and I think that with time I started enjoying myself, when I got the answers to various questions about, ''why this happened'', ''why that happened'' and them putting them together, reminds me of Sherlock Holmes in a way, yet unclear to me. Checking IGN guides on where stuff is also happens quite often (often being almost everytime).-CollectiblesA lot of em. A lot. Which is good (?), but what's even better is, that at any time when you're in the town, you can go to various interiors (since collectibles are more or less spread out across interiors), and collect the ones you might've missed.CONS:-There aren't any consI enjoyed it, and the achievements make for some work, but you get the hang of it.Also, when this first came out, I was oh-so-not interested in it, but after time (time being about a year later), it was on sale and I said ''why not''.P.S I don't think I regret it. content:
ry 4
												Murdered: Soul Suspect has a really cool premise. You're dead, a ghost, and you need to figure out who killed you. You can walk through walls, do poltergeisty stuff, read people's minds, woo!In reality, the game is mostly just wandering around surprisingly small maps, picking up a seemingly endless pile of collectables that serve as plot-filler and as a source for some spooky ghost stories. Also, since you're a ghost and still cannot walk through some doors (because the writers of the game wrote themselves into a corner) you need a living person to help you, and that person is one of the most annoying 15-year-old goth-teenage girls I have ever seen in a videogame. Yaay for cringe!Beyond walking around, touching things and reading people's minds, the only form of gameplay is avoiding and destroying demons in an oversimplified stealth minigame followed by a QTE. On the whole, the gameplay is not very engaging and solving some of the scenes flawlessly requires you to do quite a bit of the old "what was the game dev thingking about here" -mindgames.For a murder mystery plot, the game has way too few characters and the clues are too obvious to keep the game interesting.The game also seems to have a low number of voice actors, resulting in samey characters, and for some reason it also seems the game devs made precisely four character models: "man", "woman" "girl" and "scary little girl" (five if you count the demons) and went with those, so all the people in the game have the exact same body types and... It feels weird. Like they're all clones, milling about endlessly.All in all, Soul Suspect falls flat despite a cool premise and the game isn't really very enjoyable.Playtime: 6+ hours (Single playthrough)Ratings (1-10)Visual: 6Audio: 7Story: 4Gameplay: 6Overall: 5

er 8, 2014
												I thoroughly enjoyed  Murdered: Soul Suspect. Let me start by saying if you are looking for action, adventure, and shooting in a run and gun style look elsewhere (You don't shoot a gun at all, not even once). If you are looking for a solid game with a great storyline, reading, thinking, and a great mystery plot that keeps you guessing look here. Is the game scary? No I would not say it is scary, maybe creepy or atmospheric. The Dev does a good job of making you feel and realize that you are not among the living. There is the occassional disappearing ghosts and scary music but nothing like silent hill, dead space, or amnesia. The point of the game is not to scare or freak you out. It's to tell a great story and for you to solve a mystery.On top of figuring out your own mystery there are about 6-10 little side quests. None are very long, but they are each enjoyable and have a little story of their own. There are also hundreds of little collectables to find and to keep you busy. I am not usually a fan of finding and hunting for hidden objects; but for some reason in this game it does not seem to tedious or difficult. The style of game just seems to lend itself towards finding lost or hidden items.All that being said I would recommend this game overall score 8/10. I picked it up at 75% off and am not disapointed. I think for me even %50 off would justify the purchase. If it's on sale and you are a story driven gamer I would strongly urge you to pick this one up at some point.Oh and if that's not convincing enough did I mention you have the ability to posses cats, and you have a never ending cigarette?! Yup see I knew that would help you make the right decision!

number of helpful: 15 of 21 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 6, 2015



YouTube™ Video: Murdered: Soul Suspect Review 

			Views: 118		

			We take a look at the detective horror game Murdered: Soul Suspect! http://noobsthatplaygames.com/		

Remember those God awful Nancy Drew Detective games that were sold in the bargain bins at Best Buy and Walmart?...Well swap out adorable Nancy with a buff, gritty, tattoo covered, cop and you have Murdered: Soul Suspect. The game puts you in the shoes of a recently deceased detective who becomes trapped on earth as a ghost until he can track down his murderer and solve his own case. While the general idea of the game sounds very interesting, the gameplay doesn’t hold up strongly enough to back this promising premise.The game offers fairly solid visuals; they aren’t anything that will knock your socks off but they get the job done and provide an immersive, bone chilling, spooky experience. The game is fittingly set in Salem Massachusetts, but you won’t be exploring much of the town, as the game is designed to give you the false sense of free roam when it is in fact painfully linear. The game has a fairly expanse world, however due to the ghostly limitations the game places on you, you are unable to enter any buildings unless the door or window is already opened for you. This leads to the game being extremely linear, with what appears to be a vast explorable world turns out to be an empty ghost town in and of itself.The core gameplay mechanics consists of incredibly disappointing “Detective Work”. Detective work is conducted by entering the crime scene (which usually consist of about 3 fairly small rooms) and meandering about the room pressing the interact key on all the shiny clues that are sprinkled throughout the crime scenes. The game requires that you find a painstaking amount of these clues for each question and at some points you may find yourself spamming the interact key repeatedly hoping you will blindly click on the last elusive clue that you need to proceed, imagine it as the Easter egg hunt from hell. The game does introduce some fairly interesting puzzle mechanics on certain clues, such as word association deciphers where you are presented with an image and around 15 words and have to pick the 3 or 4 words that are most related to the image to crack the clue, however these interesting tidbits are never truly fleshed out to their true potential.Don’t go into this game expecting any form of combat whatsoever, the combat is almost nonexistent and consists of walking behind the demonic enemies and performing a series of simple quick time events to eliminate them. The demons themselves look genuinely terrifying and if you do happen to mess up the quick time event then you will be chased by the demon and have to escape by quickly transporting through preplaced ghostly rifts that allow you to hide until the demon gives up on searching for you.  The only thing this game really has going for it that makes it worth playing is the intriguing, twist filled story. The stories pacing is done very well and at times you almost wish Murdered: Soul Suspect was a movie rather than a game. The voice acting is pretty solid and one of the best aspects of the game; being such a story driven game it benefits greatly from making sure that it has some good quality voice acting. While there are many cut scenes, they are enjoyable and emotion filled. It’s just a shame that the rest of the game feels like such a grinding chore just to get to the next cut scene to watch the story unfold.Overall Murdered: Soul Suspect seems like it has so much potential but never truly takes advantage of anything that it has going for it. The game holds your hand through a painfully linear environment and offers absolutely no challenge or difficulty. The only thing that makes Murdered: Soul Suspect even remotely worth playing is the fairly enjoyable story delivered through the cut scenes. The game plays out like a very good movie with obnoxious, tedious, burdensome, gameplay in between. What seemed like a very promising premise wasn’t strongly supported enough by the overall weak puzzles and lack of difficulty.I would only recommend this game if you get it at a ridiculous sale pricehttp://noobsthatplaygames.com/

content:
, 2015
												7/10.   If you enjoy story driven games, this game is a good fit.  A well fleshed out storyline with excellent voice acting, cinematics, and live action gameplay.  I didn't find any silly time wasting quests or non-sensical gameplay at all.  		I had no idea what the gameplay would involve, and it's an interesting mix.  You are a detective who becomes a ghost and needs to find out who killed you and why. So, lots of investigations.  To me, the investigative parts of the game are most like a hidden object game.  You walk around a small area and find the clues to solve the inquiry.  Very straightforward.  There is a bit of action involved with demons to dispose of. You play stealthy while sneaking up on them.  Later in the game, it gets more intense with up to 4 demons simultaneously and can be a little challenging to sneak up on.	There are clues, letters, special bad guy info bits, historical parts, human mind reading, and some side quests too.  I didn't enjoy these as much.  They just aren't interesting and add little to the game story.  Mostly, the human mind reading gets boring to the point where I stopped bothering to read minds one third of the way through the game.  There are also ghost stories to unlock.  Some are good, some are so-so.  I liked the asylum one best.  Those are optional and require going through the rooms quite a bit more to search out hidden unlockables.  If anything was time wasting, that was it.  But, it's not mandatory.	To me, the story dragged up until about halfway.  After the cemetery I was hooked and kept on playing without any lack of interest. Before then, I was getting a bit bored, so slow gameplay and story up until midway.		Two things that stood out to me that may interest others: 1) It's not an adventure game.  Don't go in expecting an adventure game of any kind.  This wasn't clear to me from the onset until I had been playing a bit.2) If you like action or fast paced horror games, this may not be for you.  This game is laid back, not terribly scary, and takes it's time.  More for the detective story fans IMO and fans of hidden secrets.	The ending is good and don't watch a vid of it please or it really ruins the experience.  If the initial half of the game wasn't so slow and a bit scarier, I would probably rate it higher. Still a good game, lots of love went into it, and it's optimized very well too.

content:
8, 2016
												An excellent game. Murdered: Soul Suspect is a story rich detective game. Your character is murdered at the start of the game, and now as a ghost he has to solve his own murder by following the trail of a serial killer.The game takes place in a dark urban setting, giving the atmosphere of danger and hopelessness the entire time. In addition to the crime mystery element, it also includes a lot of paranormal concepts, particularly relating to ghosts and mediums. The story is paced very well and does not drag out or include any filler content. Every area you visit is another jigsaw piece in the grand scheme that helps you get closer to uncovering the mystery behind the string of murders happening in town.Most of the gameplay consists of you searching around the area for clues and then putting them together to finalise on what happened. Most times it's pretty straight forward. It plays like a point & click game, but without overly convoluted puzzles. Everything you find makes logical sense. In addition to that, there are also other collectibles scattered in each level, each of which provide some information on characters or the town's lore. Some also let you uncover special hidden ghost stories, which is a nice reward, as some of those stories are pretty chilling.At times there are stealth sections where you have to avoid being seen by soul-eating demons. They add a bit of challenge to the game, but overall I was not much of a fan of these sections as they felt unneeded and often got in the way of you exploring. A lot of the time the demons would come in groups of 3 or so, meaning you'd be spending some time trying to figure out how to get past them. You can't fight them, and the only way to kill them is via an execution from behind, if you're brave enough. Gladly these sections were few and far in between. Most times you'd only come across 1-2 such sections per level. So if this aspect is putting you off, I'd still recommend to try the game, since most of the game is spent putting together the clues.Don't expect challenging gameplay or anything of that sort. This is a story-driven detective game at heart, and I think most critics who have slammed the game have missed this point.I'd highly recommend this game if you like games about solving murder mysteries or anything with a dark, gripping plot for that matter.

content:
18, 2015
												Well, nearly made myself to finish it. This one started as a promising story-driven atmospheric paranormal detective about ghosts and investigation of death of your own character while actually being a ghost: walking through walls, spy on citizens, possess them and read their minds, do stuff in yout favor, collect evidence and make conclusions... Yeah, very promising. And this all also wrapped with pretty good graphics with good visual art and detail, good score and voice acting. As a fan of atmospheric story-driven games I was really looking forward to Murdered: Soul Suspect. And at the beginning it was good. But it failed for me eventually.The catch? - Dull story and mainly boring and repetitive gameplay.The story had a good potential but authors were unable to pull it off. Eventually it slipped to so trivial and dull finale, that I began to regret for my wasted time. Authors tried to fill it with the notes of Salem's history, Ronan's personal story and love tragedy, but it didn't worked, something was missing and the main story felt... shallow. The ending of the game is plain ridiculous both gameplay- and storywise.Throughout the game there is almost no progression in gameplay: after you learned how to discover things, collect evidence, solve the case, possess people, counteract the opponents - you'll do it till the end with almost no diversity or new meaningful mechanics. The investigation part is very dull and making conclusions is not particularly interesting - especially when doing it dozen of times.I know this might look silly to blame a story-driven game for lack of gameplay (it's not Dear Esther though), but we're talking about the game with also sort of 'open' locations for your discovery, where you can freely go and explore it, solve some side-quests (they are also trivial and repetitive). On the contrary, I never got bored in story-driven Spec Ops: The Line, even though it's mere third-person shooter, because of its constant progression in fascinating story, locations design, changing circumstances, obstacles and gameplay.In Murdered, besides that you can wonder around the locations doing side-quests, looking for collectibles (fun at first, become boring and useless later) or navigating your way from point A to B there are a lot of times during the second half of the game when you forced to revisit old locations and more often than not run through it from one end to another.The locations themselves are not very distinctive and did I mention you can't run through every wall? At first that part with looking your way through the labyrinth of real and paranormal walls was OK, but quickly faded since they all looks the same, same blurred bluish corridors all the time. This is an unnecessary protraction of the game - you simply getting bored and 'felling off' the game's reality and story.The enemies? Man, I wished that part of the game's 'features' never ended up in final version. It's just wrong, unnecessary, badly designed gameplaywise, and... oh, that console port QTEs... Quickly press W+RMB / D+LMB... etc.No, I don't recommend this game, because I don't want more games of such quality of game design.

content:
2016
												You play as Ronan, a freshly deceased cop who's trying to figure out his own murder. Because of this unfinished business, he gets stuck between hell and heaven, wandering in the world of living, invisible to the naked eye, only able to interact with human mediums. As you learn the ropes of this supernatural world, you start collecting clues and putting all the stuff together. The ending blew my mind, really. Some people may say it's too short for a fully priced title but I think the time was appropriate for the told story and filler missions would only ruin the ambience of certain urgency in the air. Perhaps this should have been something episodic, one murder story - one episode. But we all know that is not happening anytime soon.Murdered: Soul Suspect has an awesome story and I enjoyed uncovering the case in L.A. Noire-ish style. Playing as a ghost? Very nice, not a common thing in games. Possesing people, reading minds, communicating with mediums? Sounds awesome, seems like these devs are taking the ghost business seriously. Being a murdered detective investigating his own murder? I'm sold.These ideas are great but something went wrong and they were kind of poorly executed. My guess is the developers either got lazy and told the janitor to put together some pieces of the game because they were busy actually working on the main storyline and side quests that really got some love. Or they were rushed by the greedy publisher, what do I know. But some details are just like whatever. Details so strong in numbers that I couldn't just ignore them after a while. For example: Reading minds of the entire city - extremely few lines that keep repeating even between different people. Musicless, slow, unskippable credits. Overdesigned main protagonists while other models are just copy pasted - even in the story, totally destroys the overall pleasant graphics. Some controls are weird, whole main menu and "press start" while using k+m. And a few more.Even though I needed to vent my frustration with this game in here, it was mostly because of the lost game of the year potential. (For me) I still enjoyed it. There is nothing like it on the gaming market and I very much like originality. Mixed with amazing story makes a great, underdeveloped game. I feel bad to rate it 6,9/10. I'd smack the people responsible for the lazy/rushed details.

												THIS is what's wrong with the industry. Reviewers and websites want to insure business, They do that by "pleasing" the majority, and they do that by guessing what the majority would and wouldnt like and let that bias affect their own review of the games. This works sadly. But that is also why many who would enjoy a game such as Murdered Soul Suspect won't even try it. Sad reality.This game doesnt have "action" it doesnt have shooting, stealing cars, and destruction. And it is better for it. In its own genre and taken as a separate entity, this game shines.It is a mix of old school adventure atmosphere, smartass detective work, it is slow but it is great. The Story keeps you interested, the acting is top notch, the relationship between the main character and his partner is akin that of Booker and Elizabeth in Bioshock Infinite. You'll feel like you are watching Ghost (the Demi Moore and Patrick Swayze flick) at times, at others it'll be a Tex Murphy experience.It is a fun and enjoyable experience, I am more than glad I bought this game, and if this genre is your cup of tea, you will be quite glad you had this adventure. You can't beat possessing poeple and reading their thoughts.Buy this game and enjoy it, if you have your doubts, wait for a sale. But don't miss it.

number of helpful: 14 of 21 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 26, 2015
												Oh dear, I'm dead - pretty much the main mechanic of the game.  MURDERED: Soul Suspect starts out with the death of the main character who goes by the name of Ronan, a local Detective investigating a murder. It's not the most unique premise out there, but it handles it in such a way that makes it intriguing, but can ultimately fall a little short thanks to the way the game itself is structured. A Clean Cut GhostWhile Ronan and the other main characters look pretty good and the environments themselves look pretty top notch, I can't really say the same for the NPCs. I noticed they re used qutite a LOT of NPCs without as much as trying to hide it somehow, which can definately break the immersion this game tries to set in with it's dark and drab setting. The lighting is top notch also, and really helps give the game the sense that you're in some ghostly world in an already dark setting.The environments, as stated above, look very nice and I really like how they themselves tell their own stories because of the way the game places just random objects in an area. You can have, for example, a train inside a museum to let the player know that in the past, where the museum stands now used to be a regularly used train track and the game's chock full of little things like that, as well as it uses flat and ghostly images that sorta just fade out as you get closer to them to help accentuate that you are indeed in a ghost world. It's really good. Even greatly influencing the atmosphere the game has, is it's sound design. You can occasionally hear ghostly wails in the backgrounds, and the game is very light on music, only really playing it during tense moments like when there are Demons around, it knows when and when not to play music and it handles it pretty well. Voice acting is pretty par for the course, Ronan and the main characters sound decent, but some of the VA's for the NPCs can be pretty hit or miss. Solving the Case   Murdered: Soul Suspect  is pretty much a glorified adventure game. The very linear structure the game has is done to help accentuate the story, making it feel actually more like a 3D Visual Novel than an Adventure game. The game is pretty much divided up by "stage" sections and an overworld (The Town). Each "Stage" has it's own set of collectibles that, once fully completed, gives you insight into a usually very dark and grim backstory into those items you collect as well as having it's own story section and more in general collectibles. What can feel detrimental to the game's pacing, is the way each stage is handled. It always ends up being a straight up Move from Point A to Point B sort of ordeal while exploring through every nook and cranny to find collectibles. As far as mechanics go, the game can sometimes feel a little messy since there's no map to indicate an overall layout of the area you're in, thankfully, no one area looks exactly like another so it's usually easy to tell when you're going the wrong way - you can also walk through certain walls, and railings on stairs but not all of them. You can also posses people and read their thoughts (random NPCs) but sometimes they just end up repeating lines, other times, for story purposes, you can posses people to get over obstacles, you can posses objects to cause noises and distract NPCs and you can influence people to think about certain events by using clues. Clues are items you inspect during an "Investigation" phase which can be used occasionally only during said investigation, or sometimes long term throughout the whole game. That being said, the only challenge this game does bring, is some half baked stealth sections involving "demons", creatures that live to suck out a spirit's soul and re-kill them I guess? These sections can be very tense thanks to the musical cues and the great wails they tend to do, but they merely serve to give the game padding and often can break up the pace of the story. The demons are also never used in any meaningful way to complement the story.   Murdered is a pretty fun and short adventure game that can clock you in anywhere from 4-12 hours depending on how much you decide to focus on collectibles. There's no real punishing methods the game uses outside of demons catching you, it has a fairly uneven pace that can otherwise dull a pretty nice Murder thriller story. Pros + Amazing atmosphere   + Great sound design accentuates further the atmosphere  + Decent Voice Work + Interesting and fun story  + Fun mechanics that makes you feel like a ghost.Cons - Uneven Pacing  -  Game is on the short side, story alone clocks in at about 4 hours or so  - Repeated use of NPC models can break immersion.  -Demons serve no purpose to the story and are used as padding.Overall, if you can pick this game up at a decent price range, it's definately worth a playthrough if you enjoy Murder/Crime Thrillers, outside of that, this has very limited appeal.

content:
14, 2015
												I will try to make this review as short as possible, and list a few pros and cons.You play as Ronan O'Connor, an ex-convict that found love and got married to a police officers sister, Julia. Which got his reputation cleared  criminal records hidden  and allowed him to be accepted into law enforcement. Shortly after Ronan marries Julia, she attempts to stop an argument between two men that didn't end too well, she got stabbed by one and dies in Ronan's arms. Shortly after Ronan loses his cool and basically turns into Batman.  He goes in alone and tries to stop the Bell Killer, but is quickly over powered, thrown out of a window, then shot seven times.  now you are now stuck in limbo and have to find out whom killed you before you can go into the vast world beyond. This is where your story begins.Pros. Great voice acting, almost no loading screens (I only got 3 during my whole play through.), a great cinematic story (7 hours of gameplay for most users), a very pretty game. Graphics don't always matter, but I still have to throw this in.Cons. Almost no real fighting in this game.  The Demons are too easy. , very linear story, little to no replay value, cliffhanger ending. I never liked them.TLDR. It's a great game, if you like playing a cinematic story. The $20 price tag may actually be worth it, but I always go for game when they are on sale or in a bundle. Got this little gem in Humble Bundle myself.

content:
1, 2015
												There are many flaws with this game, still I quite enjoyed it (at a discount purchase).- There are way too many collectibles (nearing 200). You need to collect a random number of things to unlock a story (e.g. 14 chainsaws). That's way too many and after collecting the necessary collectibles in the first section of the game I never did it again.- Sometimes you need to collect clues and the prompt for them are very precise. You need to angle the camera in just the right way which is very annoying for a game that's focused on that.- You need to battle demons in this game. It's by far the worst part which consists of teleporting between safe spots and trying to sneak up behind them. When I had the opportunity, I just ran by them to enter the next section.- It can be hard to find your way. This is partially because you can just walk through walls which is disorientating. At a later point in the game you learn to teleport which makes it even worse.- There are stealth section in this way where you need to guide your human partner while distracting guards by ringing the phone and other poltergeisty stuff. I didn't mind this is as much since it's easy and you don't seem to be able to fail (which I consider a good thing).- You sometimes posses a cat and run through vents because... you're in Salem?- There are (near) instant death traps and you die so incredibly fast, it's kindof funny? They just consist of black spots on the ground and are easily avoidable.I enjoyed this game the best when I ignored the side stuff and just focused on the main case where you're trying to solve your own murder. I bypassed the demon battle sections as best I could. The cat scenes were ok but unnecessary. The stealth sections where you guide your partner was kindof fun. The main meat was the investigation stuff where you collect clues and try to figure out what precisely happened at the crime scene. I completed this game in 5 hours which is probably not worth it at full price but it was for me and I found that the story didn't drag.Go buy it in a sale!

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
y 16
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is supernatural detective adventure thriller game where you are playing as detective Ronan. He got murdered by a Bell Killer a primary antagonist and now he need to solve his case as a ghost.Pros:+ Great main character, Ronan is really likable and unique.+ Voice acting is really good+ Enjoyable graphics, as long as you play with V-sync+ Good story and atmoshpere+ Lots of collectibles + As a ghost you can walk through walls, read people's minds etc.Cons:- Short (main story for around 6 hours)- Combat is poor, if you can even call that combat (you basically sneak behind the enemy and do fast QTE) - Only one type of enemy- Most of NPC's are just clones/duplicates- Only 4 optional quests ( to finish them you need like 5-10 mins each)Maybe they're expecting it to be a fast-paced action game or something like that which it definitely isn't. It's a detective game with an interesting story and characters that draws you in. It's also pretty novel in that you're playing a criminal-turned-detective's ghost who's trying to find the identity of his killer. You spend the game collecting clues to figure out your killer's identity while stopping along the way to help out other lost souls in little sidequests where you figure out how they died so they can pass on. There are also lots of collectibles, some of which provide background for the story, such as notes left by the main character's wife, or that unlock stories about unsolved crimes connected to hauntings. The mood the game sets just enhances the experience, being creepy and immersive.Overall, this game is a lot of fun. Story is great, voice acting is well done. The story is a pretty good detective tale, with everything falling satisfyingly into place at the end and a few neat twists. There are only a few drawbacks: sometimes when you posess someone and listen to their thoughts you'll hear the same thought in different people; the parts where you have to sneak behind demons and take them out can be a bit tedious. There's a lot of repitition and it seems like they re-used a lot of stuff.The other drawback is that the game is a bit short. I finished it in 7 hours, and if you check out my achievements you'll see I didn't get 100% completion. I did all the side-quests and found as many collectibles as I could. You could probably stretch it out to 10 hours if you wanted 100% completion which seems totally possible in a single playthrough.In short, if you like story-driven games, or mystery/adventure games then you'll probably like this game. If you want this game to be a gritty shooter, then go buy Max Payne instead, because you won't get that with this game.TL;DR: 6.5/10, fun detective story, don't expect a lot of combat/action, very short.

content:
ry 11, 2016
												Ronan is a criminal-turned-cop who is killed by the mysterious Bell Killer. Playing as Ronan's ghost, investigate a series of crime scenes (sometimes with the help of teenage medium Joy), searching for identity of the killer. Many supernatural elements come into play – ghosts, witches, demons – and some  flashbacks of the witch trials are pretty gruesome (drowning, burning, hanging). As the investigation progresses, you'll explore a graveyard, an apartment house, an old mansion, a police station and of course the obligatory asylum level. While the game world is small, it is open, with the ability to just wander around the town of Salem. It's a gloomy place – the game occurs entirely at night – but is well-dotted with NPCs and collectibles. Obtaining collectibles can unlock other stories (usually brief, narrated cut-scenes), and some NPCs will provide side-missions. There's a decent amount of stuff to do, but most collectibles were easily found as I explored the town or a level. Investigations require exploring a a crime scene, finding evidence (“Press E to analyze”) and sorting through the collected evidence (“Press Q to conclude the investigation”). Walking (or later, teleporting) around as a ghost feels fun;  Ronan can walk through walls, possess people (mind-reading), and turn on random stuff to mess with the townsfolk (poltergeisting). Especially cool were the impenetrable “ghost walls” from past times that can block Ronan from exploring – or even provide new hazards (watch out for the ghost train!). Oh, and you can possess cats, too. This is actually crucial to progress through several stages of the game.The demon sections, though, dragged the experience down a bit. Demons will sometimes spawn after completing an investigation. Their existence does have a crucial part to play, and they're easy enough to defeat with a little patience. Given that this is a supernatural tale, it would be rather weird if demons of some kind weren't in the game, and having some stealth sections added some variety to the gameplay.  But after a while the demons became annoying distractions from the story.And the narrative is where Murdered: Soul Suspect stands strongest. There is a lot of backstory to be found about Ronan and his wife (via collectibles). Sometimes collectibles are merely annoying, but they are worth pursuing here. Jason Brooks (as Ronan) and Cassidy Lehrman (as the medium, Joy) provide stand-out vocal performances. The graphics (Unreal 3) are great – murky and dark. Jason Graves' score provides a classic horror-story undertone. Murdered: Soul Suspect is a well-crafted detective game with a few quirks that holds its story aloft as its best attribute. If that sounds good to you, then go ahead and get this one.

(she was following him probably the whole game as seen in one scene) or when she was interrogated in the police station? or when joy was sneaking through the police station or mental hospital, there were so many cops or nurses which abigail could have instantly possessed to finish the job (as seen with the 2 poor cops at the end of the game)or when she can summon these demon hands at any time, why didn't she finish ronan earlier?"   source [www.playstationtrophies.org] This games have so much potential with their unique atmosphere & the devs should've add more things to make it perfect/complete but too bad they didn't add too much things. content:
4, 2014
												Despite an interesting premise and a promising start, Soul Suspect suffers from some significant problems.The game is good at setting an atmosphere and the lead characters background is interesting - if a little hard to belive.It struggles, however, when trying to be a computer game.  The puzzles are interesting, but their internal logic is inconsistant - you end up having to think like the designer.  Unfortunately, it's obvious that each of the puzzles had a different writer each time, meaning that every time you approach a problem it's sometimes hard to know what it is that is being asked of you.  This is a problem as the game has a rating system that punishes you if any mistakes are made.  The punishment is only the loss of a points on a system that doesnt seem to have any real bearing upon the game at large, but it is irritating to feel that failure is more due to an inconsistant mechanic than a mistake.The worst aspect of the game is undoubtably the action sequences involving the hunting or avoiding of deadly shades, trapped between the our world and the next.  Sound intersting? In practice, it's not.Unfortunately, these sections feel rushed; a knee-jerk attempt at introducing some action into the otherwise slow pace of the game.Not a bad idea in principle, but the problem is that these fights vary little from the start of the game to the end.  The shades don't do anything other than follow very short, pre-set paths which occasionaly pass something that may be used to distract them.  The "challenge" comes from the fact that as the game progresses increasing numbers are put in your path - not exactly imaginative. Mistakes result in dashing about trying to hide from the shades that hunt you more aggressively, which would make these sequences more exiting, execpt that some areas seem to lack an appropriate number of places to hide.  This leads to you dashing between the few available, never quite caught but still unable to shake the shades off.  In the end it becomes nessecery to let the shades catch you, just so you get the opportunity to try again from the start.I  would often find myself wishing that I skip these sections so I could get back to the story, which is far more interesting.  If - of course - you ignore the feeling that the check-list of horror settings is being almost audibly ticked as you progress from graveyard to asylum to church, etc.It's worth a go if you see a deep, deeeep, discount on it but I wouldn't recommend it at any other time, the feeling that the game is constructed of hedged bets is just too prevelent.

												Ronan a criminal turned cop dies and becomes a ghost. Now he must figure out who his killer is with the help of a young girl, and the abilities to investigate crimes and possess people. The only thing I would possibly change in the game is the annoying demons that you have to avoid and banish. I realize that most people like their games to be challlenging but I hate "stalking" my enemy waiting for the perfect moment, only to foil it and have to restart from the latest checkpoint. Overall, the game was entertaining, medium length, and well written. Investigations are fun and not too difficult. Its more of a good storyline game above all else.

content:
er 29, 2015
												I am recommending this game as I personally like it. I will give my reader a huge WARNING before purchasing : the game play isn't super immerse, it's more the genre of the game. The controls/abilities are a bit limited. The game itself, however is comparable to a beautiful painting. Murdered : Soul Suspect follows a detective who was pushed out of a window and then shot repeatedly as he was trying to get up. The (bell tower) killer is an unknown assailant who has been attacking random individuals. After being shot, the detective is now a ghost and has to figure out why he's still roaming the Earth and hasn't passed on.You are in third person view of Ronan (the detective) and have identical controls/movements (not actions though) to Hitman Absolution. What is probably the most outstanding feature in the game is the fact you can walk through walls. Of course, you cannot walk through any wall you wish. This will be made obvious with a solid white fill on a few walls or other "ghostly" objects will appear that will not let you pass. None the less, something completely different I have never been able to do in any game I've played yet. The combat is quite minimal. I should add if you are looking for a cop fighting action game, this isn't it. The most you'll be able to do is pull lost souls from demons that roam nearby areas. Demons are to be approached from behind when they cannot see you and soul extraction happens when you press RT. Again, not much to it but there is a rush associated with it. If you are seen, you will be chased and killed. You may hide in "ghost remnants" (small ghost cracks in levels) and can fast travel to each one in an attempt to evade the demon. There will be other obstacles in your way such as demon traps in which you require to possess a person while they walk across it. Being a ghost, you are able to possess literally anyone. NPC's will have general thoughts you can read while certain characters (usually for missions), you're able to "peek" (see what they're seeing) or "influence" (use a clue to job their memory in an attempt to force an action). They made jumping/possessing person to person quite easy to do. The game even goes as far as allowing you to posses a cat (with a purpose of course). Over time you will acquire new skills such as teleportation, poltergeist (setting a printer or phone off) and detect mode which lets you see through walls. You may also run in game but you do not have the ability to crouch or jump. Most of the time you will be free roaming until you come across a crime scene. Once in investigation mode, you will be looking around for clues and sometimes need to hit RT to reveal the complete evidence. Often times than not, you will need to find certain clues in order to find other clues (meaning intervention or possessing others to get a complete answer). Once you think you've found enough, you can conclude your investigation with the clues you've found. The game basically follows one crime scene to another and in between there are small side quests. Doesn't really sound appealing (which I'm sure is why people don't like the game) but it appealed to this extremely picky gamer. The visuals are pretty good (not super fantastic but good). I have an AMD card and have tried to get more than 30 FPS. The graphics really resemble those of Hitman Absolution. They do have a lot of symbols and ghost writing that does pop up which enriches the environment. The sounds are suitable to the environment the game provides. It's not super over the top but I would assume it's hard to imagine what a demon would sound like. Overall, I enjoyed the game. I think it's cool to play through but leaves the player with no replayability. I got this game on extreme sale in a bundle. I would say it was worth it for what I paid. I would highly recommend people do their homework before buying such a game. I like to play it, you may not due to it's lack of actual gameplay activity. RATING : 7/10Gameplay B Story / Campaign A- Visuals / User Interface B Sounds / Music B Replay-ability C- Overall  C+ScreenShots :  If you didn't believe me about the cat thing Common sense questions will come up in which you'll have to be able to connect the dots Something oddly satisfying walking through walls What a cinematic looks like  Having a short term memory will bite you in the bum  Just like in Hitman Absolution, you can press a button to see through walls and avoid danger  Me attempting to execute a demon and save a soul

												The game is good, worth a shot, but still hardly worth the full price considering that the main story can be completed in about 7 hours. Yeah, there are side quests, but there's little motivation for anyone to waste time trying to complete them, except maybe for achievement hunters, since they're not connected to the main story too closely. Since the combat, the action part of the gameplay is very simplistic (just attack the enemy from behind and press some key combinations), the exploration part could've saved the day if it weren't just as simplistic as well. Anyway, if you're like me and care more for a good story than sophisticated gameplay, Murdered: Soul Suspect will be a nice experience.Pros:- the story is complex and captivating, the ending is pretty unexpected- the visuals are nice- good voice acting- interesting characters- nice noir/dark atmosphere- interesting basic concept (some kind of "walking dead" but not the "usual" kind of "walking deads" :)  you die right in the start and then just play as a ghost  )Cons:- kinda short- the gameplay is quite simplistic, in terms of both fighting and exploring- there's only one type of enemy to fight- horror is hardly a good keyword to describe it, there's pretty much nothing scary about it- the full price doesn't seem very reasonable considering the gameplay's length

er 6, 2014
WARNING!
Avoid it if you're looking for a game.
Get it if you're looking for a visual detective/supernatural book. This game is heavily story driven. It's so story driven that you can't even call it an adventure game!Monkey Island has more gameplay in it than this game.All you do is walk around and press X where needed (I use an Xbox 360 controller). It's not a third-person action/adventure game or hell, it isn't even a "detective" game like L.A Noire (another epic game) is.Nope, in here you just walk around and press X. You don't solve puzzles, you don't shoot, you don't...you don't do anything but walking, really. It has an "open world" sandbox city that you're free to roam but there's nothing to do in it. Sometimes you stumble on a collectible and press X. That's all there is to it. The minimap shows you where you need to go in order to "progress" in the game and well, just walk on over there and you get a new cutscene.Other games that lack in gameplay, such as The Walking Dead or The Wolf Among Us, let you choose what to say or do in certain situations. This adds some replay value to both games.However, the story in this game is linear and you can't make any choices. No choices at all!So why am i recommending this game ?It has a good story! A very good story! If you don't mind watching a movie with a controller in your hand or sitting in front of your PC/laptop then this "game" is for you.

Firstly, I have to say that this game has a great story and is the most unique one I’ve played in a long time.I never played a game where you play a ghost and the protagonist is dead from the begginging. The primary goal of him is to find his murderer and be released from his ghostly form.Secondly, the setting is pretty believable and rich in detail. There are so much innovative things I only can scratch the survface of it in my review: The trains of thought to find out the truth are pretty great depicted: There are a bunch of clues which you have to find and then you have to find the link between them by clicking the most important one or figure out the right order of events. Only game of this type I played was The Vanishing of Ethan Carter. You can posses people and read or influence their minds to get clues. You can posses cats (This is pretty cool) and climb/jump around in trees. The atmosphere is pretty dense and unique. Outstanding voice acting!!!!  Great story telling (This is no action game!).  The only action element of this game is that you get hunted by demons. This is sometime kind of intense but nothing extreme scaringThe only thing which spoils this game a bit are the darn bad technics of this game. You notice every second of playing that it’s a console porting. You can’t change the assignment of keys. For that’s unacceptable: sprinting on shift..WTF?! Another thing which bothered me is hat you can‘t disable 30 FPS lock with V-Sync enabled. So it’s either "tearing" or no FPS over 30! Sometimes there are some strange glitches, too. One time I was falling into nothing (see the video at the bottom), the other time there was no background sound and one time I got stuck in the menue. Only solution was restarting the game. Well, sometimes, when you go back to the desktop via Alt + Tab, the whole game just gets stuck to your screen and the only thing to do is restart....Again!All in all, a great and very unique game with some technical glitches and confounding factorsPS: Thanks to khay★jeet ( http://steamcommunity.com/id/blaybleet/ ) for gifting me this game!! You can sneak past demons in some instances and control a cat to reach certain areas which is frustrating and annoying. You can't fail solving anything because if you mess up pointing to the wrong evidence or clues the game allows you to try again until it's corrected...so what's the point on solving anything if the game does it for you? The story is the only thing that made me want to continue playing or walking through literally. In the end it wasn't worth it.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												7.5/10Overview: AdventureWatch the movie Ghost, replace Patrick Swayze with an ex criminal cop and replace Whoopi Goldberg with a teenager, throw in some supernatural elements and you have the basic foundation for Murdered Soul Suspect. The gameplay is a mixture between investigating areas for evidence and stealth sections. Investigating areas is basic, you walk around until you get to item/object you can interact with. A few times you are given a list of clues and must select the right clues in order to advance, as far as I can tell there is no way you can fail any of these. No matter how many times you get it wrong the game will always let you keep choosing until you get it right. As a dead man you have a few tricks which you can use, such as possessing people to influence them or causing disturbances in the environment to distract people. The second portion of gameplay involves stealth which can be a bit frustrating at times but it does help break up the gameplay a bit. Every once in a while you will have to hide from demons, luckily, if they see you, you can easily run and hide in hiding spots until they decide to stop searching for you. Sneaking up from behind and pressing the appropriate buttons will kill them. The game is also littered with collectables that give back-story to characters or provide history of the surrounding locations. There are a few side quests but they are very basic and amount to nothing more than investigating an area until you found everything. This is not an action game. If you enjoy point and click adventure games you will find this somewhat enjoyable. The problem is this game offers very little puzzle solving and the entire game can be completed in 4-6 hours. I do however commend Square Enix for publishing a game like this.
