content:
3, 2014
												This is going to be a bit of an odd review.  I DO recommend the game when it's cheaper - just for the experience, but with several caveats mentioned below.  Before starting, I should warn you that this is a HORRIBLE PC port.  It has been designed for the gamepad, and any game that opens with "Press START to continue" is always a bad omen.  It's a frankly horrible and frustrating experience with keyboard and mouse (it really hasn't been converted very well).  I resorted to my trusty XBox 360 gamepad to save myself the headache...Sorry about the long review, but for tl;dr, just scroll to the very last para..._________________________When I started this game, I was pretty wowed by the concept.  Think back to the late, great Patrick Swayze, Demi Moore and Whoopi Goldburg and the film Ghost and you basically have the plot of this game - sorta (no Demi or Whoopi-alikes, and no Swayze personality).  You play Ronan, a rather bland, non-uniform detective who is murdered in the opening scene (great start!) and in that typical way (of ghosty-films) his soul rises out of his body and he looks down on himself, realising the very worst has just happened!  And it's a BRILLIANT start!  It really is.  I was so excited that I couldn't wait to throw myself right in the game.  Cops soon arrive at the scene of your murder, and there are priceless scenes like someone leaving the building in front of you, happily unaware of a ghost who slips out right behind them and then vanishes.  Absent-mindedly, you walk THROUGH a cop who suddenly shudders as you pass through them, and if you have a rumble feature on your gamepad, it too mimics that shudder whenever you pass through objects and people - fabulous!  I thought: "this is going to be GREAT!"So, you're a ghost.  You quickly learn that you are to remain behind to catch your murderer (Swayze theme again).  You learn that you can 'possess' people and read their minds and, on occasion, influence their decisions.  You can enact 'poltergeist' activity by making phones ring, switch on desk fans and the like.  You can even possess a CAT!  That alone is beautifully done - exceptional animation and effects.  The game style is closer to a 3D point-and-click adventure with some action parts, and it's mostly themed around collecting clues and solving the "Bleeding Obvious"...  There are side missions to collect odd objects, like 9 rifles, or 5 boilers (yes, boilers) and if you collect them you will be told a very short spooky story about that area.  It's a novelty, but it could have been improved by some quick-time spooky movie to watch instead of listening to a blind reading.What started really well soon goes downhill and I just want to scream about the potential this game doesn't quite reach!!!  It could have been so BRILLIANT but it fails pretty much throughout.  At the beginning, instead of flailing and wailing and trying to understand what's happening, you instead walk off happy as anything to just be a ghost as if you'd been a ghost for YEARS!  You died literally two minutes back but you're already fine with everything - off to do ghost-business right off the bat!  Remember Ghost where Swayze had to learn to touch things, who encountered other ghosts of very different kinds, who badly wanted to make contact and to find his way back to life and love, dear Demi Moore?  Ronan is not like this at all.  He's now suddenly and happily engaged in not only his own quest, but solving everybody else's problems - everybody else being people who have presumably been ghosts for much longer than our dead-2-mins hero who can magically solve problems (find clues in the immediate vicinity) of these other apparently clueless ghosts who are much more experienced ghosts than he is - surely.  But they're all stupidly incapable and you must gather the clues blatantly laid all around them.  Not good for a concept, but it's doable (he's a detective after all, and maybe only detectives can spot clues on the ground around the victims' feet...).Moving on, you will see ghostly apparitions continually.  The vast majority just do nothing.  They're not even animated - just 2D transparencies that shimmer to fade out when you approach the image.  At first, the early ones are done well, like a girl in a shower who simply vanishes whenever you try to get closer, quite eerie and clever.  But after a while you realise they're all merely static images that don't even move (very obvious when looking top-down at one from a stairway) - and often it's the same image repeated.  It would have been SO much better to have some background ghost characters just lurking around, some of them sad or lost, some angry or frightening - all of them at least moving.  Your ghostly powers are okay, though the game explains to you right away that external walls are "consecrated" so ghosts can't pass through those (ergo: the boundary of the map!) but what is SO disappointing is that, beyond the opening scene hardly anyone ever reacts!  Switch on their TV, ring their phones, WALK through them!  Mostly, they notice absolutely nothing unless you reach a case where you must distract people (in which case they react predictably to you triggering a phone or vending machine).  Mostly though, your haunting torments make no difference and cause no reaction.  It would have been such a greater game to be given a moral choice whether to haunt or help, but for what it's worth you hardly need to be a ghost really.  It's a shame - it would have been FUN to cause some haunted-house things.   Possessing people soon loses its fun too when you realise that most characters only have two lines to 'say' (always about not feeling safe or the murderer being at large), and only a couple of times do you influence them.  No Watch_dogs random thoughts here!  It gets to be boring after a while.You will encounter 'demons' for the action bit - nastly brown/orange things that will 'suck up your soul' (ie game-over - go all the way back to that ages-ago checkpoint...) and demon-holes (where they come from, of course).  You can hide from the demons in areas where past spirits wandered and left a timestamp (ie a blue foggy area vaguely shaped like a ghost).  You become invisible from demons when you are in these, and you can hop from one ghost-space to the next until you are behind the demon, and you can dispatch it with a quick-time event that, in a split second, expects you to register a thumbstick direction AND a button press.  As for the demon holes, they're nearly all just used as pathway blockers to force you along another route.Finally, there's Ronan himself.  It's impossible to empathise or feel this character at all, or sympathise with his story.  A dude in a fedora, cigarette permanently hanging out of one corner of his curled lip and a cocky swagger, and as is video-game fashion, he's the gruff, growly white male as always, but not even likeable.  You will uncover snippets of his story and wonder why on earth he was ever a cop at all.  It's difficult to be interested.  He should have been confused, angry, frightened and determined, but he is for all the world like a regular guy just sauntering along to the corner store.  ________________It's a relatively short game, and for the full price I really can't recommend it, but if it comes down to a more casual-game sensible price (the $15/$10 mark) then yes, I would say it was worth buying just to experience where the game NEARLY goes, because it is such a clever and original idea!  It's worth it just for the opening 30 mins.  It's worth it just to possess the cat, for crying out loud!  But it's not a game with any real replay value, and it's certainly not LA Noire ghost-style.  It should have been, and it could have been epic, but it misses the mark in every direction and fails to deliver on everything it hinted at when the game first opened to your murder scene, and that's such a shame.

content:
0, 2014
												Despite having its flaws, Murdered: Soul Suspect is quite possibly one of the most enjoyable single-player games I've played this year.The Pros:· A unique story that feels like a combination of Silent Hill and L.A. Noire, and the beginning does a great job of introducing you to its atmosphere. · You start at the point where Ronan O'Connor (the game's protagonist, of course) starts the hunt on his murderer, the Bell Killer. This makes you feel like you know as much about the afterlife as Ronan himself does and creates a sort of connection, right from the get-go.· The town of Salem is pretty small, but its yours to explore... and it's worth exploring. Tons of side missions and collectibles can be found in Salem, and the eerie mood that constantly lingers around really immerses you into Ronan's role.· The atmosphere is incredibly unique and satisfying. The ghostly white glow around certain object make the bridge-world connect with the world of the living. Seeing the flickering souls of dead children sitting next to a swing or a dead corpse dangling from a tree by its neck is oddly disturbing and makes you feel uncomfortable, which a bridge-world should.· Pretty cool characters. Ronan is your typical rebel-turned-cop tough guy, but his tattoo's reflect his life and the sins in it, and the detail to him is quite impressive. Even though he's partially see-through (because you know, he's a ghost and stuff), the orange bullet holes give Ronan a distinctive look from the other ghosts in Salem.The Cons:· The mechanics feel a bit underused at times. As a ghost you could be able to do so much more, like possessing and controlling others for example. Sure, you can influence people and read their minds and control a cat (10/10), but it limits the player.· For a detective game, it doesn't really require too much thinking. You have to find clues and connect the dots (sometimes those dots connect in an unlogical way), and that's basically it.· The NPCs are mostly the same. Salem doesn't have many people walking its streets, but two of the same people might be sitting a few feet from each other. Plus, they have the same thoughts, which is weird. Like freaky weird.· The combat is there, but its simplistic and repetetive. You hide in lost souls, sneak up to a demon and quickly rip him apart. It's satisfying and it even feels as if you're helping those tormented souls, but it's just too much of the same.The Visuals:· Most of its atmosphere comes from the visuals. Ghostly white silhouettes and detailed environments may not look next-gen, but they're stunning none the less.Final Verdict:· Murdered: Soul Suspect sure has its flaws, but it's a unique and highly enjoyable experience and easily one of my favorites of the year. 8/10

												Classic case of good idea, bad implementation. I found several glitches on my first playthrough, most were graphical, but one where it was a bit stupid. There were several instances of objects(both real, physical objects) were clipping together. Unfortunately all of the bugs and glitches I've noticed could have been fixed with patches yet have not been.If you insist on playing this game I highly recommend a gamepad.

content:
y 4, 2015
												I will premise this by saying that I have beaten the game and have all of the achievements completed. The metascore has you doubting, doesn't it? Well, don't let it. This game has some good and some bad, but the good wins in the end. First thing's first. Play this with a controller. I started this game with my keyboard/mouse and I immediately hated this game. The controls are a joke. The FOV is WAY too sensitive (even after changing settings). I was almost ready to give up on this game when I decided to try my Xbox controller. This choice saved the game for me. The Bad- Crappy save system. You can browse the discussion boards and find people have issues with the autosave. You can't make your own save and have to rely on it... trouble is, it's not that reliable. (you can however copy the save file from your steam folder. You have to look up how though. I think it's titled 233290. So it's a random number, not a name)- Limited action. This game is a walk around and talk to people and find clues game. There is only one type of monster (demon) and you have to sneak up behind him to banish him. So it's all about timing. I think there are probably less than 20 of them in this entire game. - Collectables. There are a lot of clues to find. Some are necessary, some aren't. The necessary ones will be located in a limited area, so you can eventually find them. The other collectables are scattered around and you have to find them. This is going to either be great because you love these kinds of things or frustrating because some of them are hard to find. Each one tells a little bit more about the story and it's characters.  The Good- Cutscenes. There are a lot of them, and I found them to be good. I know some folks hate games with lots of cutscenes. If that's you, look elsewhere. - Story. I really enjoyed the story. It's a dark mystery that you just can't help but want to solve. I felt the characters were engaging. They felt real and their struggles were believable. - Easy achievements. You will get most of the achievements without trying. There are some for collections too. Those ones I used a video walkthrough to help me find them all. - Simple investigations. So your job is to get clues and solve a mystery. This isn't the kind of game where the answer makes little sense. You collect as many clues as you can find and pick the answers based on them. You can solve a mystery without finding all the clues, but I recommend you find them all. - Time. This game didn't take long to complete and to get all of the achievements. Overall, I would recommend adding this to your wishlist. It's a really good game as long as you know what you are getting into. If you want an action packed game, this isn't for you. If you want to sit back, relax, and listen to a really cool story -- this game will be perfect.

content:
1, 2016
												"Killerman is Killerman"MURDERED: Soul Suspect is the Square-Enix murder mystery blockbuster that you never knew you needed in your life. Or afterlife. Whatever.I'm writing this after just having finished the main storyline. I'll admit I didn't grab all of the many, MANY collectibles in the game, nor did I ace every investigation with full badge power, whatever that's even supposed to mean (it was never made clear by the game as to what exactly those badges represented, if anything), so maybe I didn't get the full experience from this title. However, I'd like to make a few notes on what little I did have the pleasure of going through.Much as I'd like to ramble on at length about specific instances ingame, I do think it's poor form to spoil what passes for a plotline in this game... So I'll try and keep this as general as possible.The investigative portions of the game are awful.The stealth/combat sections that break up the investigative portions are also awful.The interrims between major investigations, where you wander around town picking up collectibles and taking on side missions, are probably the most fun... But, ultimately, still awful.No, really. Investigations are broken up into two main parts, one being "pixel hunt around the room for CLUES(tm) that are either lying on the floor or on top of a table", and the other being "poke inside someone's brain with the correct CLUE(tm) so that they give you the last CLUE(tm) you need to open up the next area".Pixelhunting is pixelhunting, and for the most part it's pretty tame. The game's nice enough to not require you to find every piece of evidence in a scene before coming to the correct conclusion, but it's also sneaky enough to WITHHOLD further evidence from you until you make a kind of halfway-conclusion. If this sounds confusing, good.It's the parts where you possess someone and try to kick their memory into gear that things get truly miserable, because I made the dreadful mistake of trying to be clever and think of actual clues, evidence, or events that might stand out in someone's mind and unlock a larger memory. No, that is not relevant to an investigation. What's relevant to an investigation is squeezing into someone's head and straight up asking them "WHO IS KILLER?". Need to work out where the suspect went? Just activate the clue "SUSPECT GOING SOMEWHERE", and you'll get all the answers you need.It's not so much an exercise in deduction, so much as a quick test to see if you remember why you're in that particular room.  Failing this repeatedly doesn't seem to have any greater consequences than not unlocking some achievement, since you just keep trying things until you pick the answers that the game wants.Okay, so the investigations aren't all that great... But maybe that's all worth glossing over in the face of an intriguing and suspenseful story?No, not really. The story is laughably predictable. I spent half the game waiting for the main characters to get on my level regarding an understanding of what was going on.  There were several points where the character was making a frustrated rant about "What does it all MEAN?" and I just sigh heavily because he's literally just read exactly what it all means.  But, hey, I guess that's what you get from the kind of genius who carefully steps over fallen debris as an incorporeal spirit.Also, yeah, psychics are totally normal and work with the police department, our first encounter with the police force shows an officer picking up forensic evidence and wearing it on his head and the creepy standoffish ghost girl who absolutely doesn't look exactly like Wednesday Addams is TOTES INNOCENT, BRUH.Oh, right, I mentioned stealth sections... Well, they're bad. Just... Stupid. Unfun. Not even difficult, they're just tedious and blatant padding with completely inexplicable mechanics. Why can our ethereal hero Mr. Fedora McGruffinsmokes banish the zombie goasts by giving them atomic wedgies? Why are they there in the first place? What even are they? Why do you have a set number of floating ghost smears you can hide inside of by rapidly bouncing back and forth between them? These and many more questions add to the mysterious mystery of MURDERED: Soul Suspect.So, yeah. Do you like sleuthing and crimesolving? Don't get this game. Do you like stealth and/or action? Don't get this game. Compelling story that makes sense and doesn't leave half of the everything unexplained? Yeah, no.Do you like backtracking repeatedly through cramped environments to pick up a staggeringly huge number of tediously hidden collectibles filled with unrelated backstory? Well then, this might very well be just the game for you!...but even then, wait for a sale.

ber 12, 2014
												I don't know why the Metascore is so low, this game definitely deserves better. I have seen good metascore on games that sucked and vice versa such as in this case. And so obviously, Metascore is not a thing to be trusted.As for the game, this was a really good and intriguing game. The things you find such as books or side stories which have lots of text to read to follow up but you can skip on it, this is one of those games that made me want to read every bit of text i found. The back stories for characters were really good, the plot is fine and unique, the animation and the artstyle is spot on. The voice acting for all the characters is damn great. This was like an adventure game following a story with no action or shooting as one might maybe expect. A game with story and interaction that not even for a moment felt boring or made me want to rush through and end this.The gameplay in this consists of looking for clues and collectibles and evading demons at times while in the story, you're chasing your own killer trying to solve your own mystery from one place to another. This is a free roaming game and gives you the liberty to roam around the Salem city which is filled with collectibles and cats and other spirits whom you can help and set them free by solving their deaths.As for my recommendation, I would definitely recommend this game to anyone even mildly interested in this. This game might not appeal to everyone, certainly not to ones looking for an action/shooter. 7/10.

content:
3, 2015
												★★★☆☆ - "Worth a try, but only on a discount" PROS:- Original idea, hooray. The idea behind this game is totally unique and works pretty well. You play a ghost and you solve murders and eventually yours with other things along the way.- Good solid storyline which is easily transferable to a decent horror movie.- Collectables everywhere.- Nice dark supernatural style to the game.- Cool demonic enemies which look as if they're inspired by the Azkaban guards from Harry Potter.- Ghosting through walls and the use of shadows in the environment is pretty well done.CONS:- That ending, what a disappointment. In terms of story it's fine but the gameplay for the final level is just pointless.- Gameplay overall just lacks something, I mean the combat is a little lame and became a chore having to evade demons and its a little quick timed in a way.- Detective? Okay so clue finding isn't as good as it should be. You uncover shadows, look at objects which just describe what they are and then he tells you what's happened. Sometimes it's okay cause you have to link to a past clue using initiative but it's far too easy! - Possession isn't utilized well enough, you can occasionally influence people to uncover something or use them to move, or peek at things but this is too few. Most of the time you listen to absolutely pointless thoughts which are uninteresting, irrelevant and sometimes repeated.- Graphics, not sure if I think they're up to AAA scratch. Whilst it's a good port this is no biggie.- Too short with no replayability. Yet it can be found cheap.VERDICT? Decent game if you enjoy mystery games like me, I enjoyed the story, game play is easy and not too thought provoking so suits a casual gamer but this game could have been a lot better for sure.

content:
3, 2014
												I just finished the game in one and a half sittings. I'll go through some pros and cons that I came across while playing through the game quickly.Pros:+The concept. It is so extremely interesting and makes for some great gameplay. Ghosts are cool. :3c+The deduction segments. You actually have to remember stuff that you uncovered way back in order to advance, which I found enjoyable and realistic. No need for a pen and paper though as the game keeps your previous discoveries and presents them when needed.+The collectibles. These withhold some very interesting bits of history, character development and a few creepy-♥♥♥ ghost stories.+The setting. Salem is a town with an extremely rich and interesting history, which is uncovered through the collectibles.+Cats.Cons.-Character development. There isn't any really, apart from some of the collectibles.-The story. You will either like the story or be disappointed. You are kept in the shade until the very end, despite all your detective work. The ending is also Shayamalan levels of twisty,-The collectibles. Yes, these were both good and bad. The good thing is the info they contain, the bad thing is they are way too easy to collect. On my first playthrough, without using any walkthroughs and not stopping to explore every square inch of every area, I found around 80% of everything there is to be found. Most of them aren't even hidden in any way. Really cuts down on replay value.-The game is very short. My very first playthrough, which I went into completely blind, only took me 6 hours from start to finish while getting 80% of all the collectibles <_>. This is also the main reason for the lack of character development. The story takes place during just one night though, so I guess the plan was to make the game short from the get-go.-No new game plus. After finishing the game, if you continue from the last checkpoint you are placed right at the last scene, which the takes you to the credits again. The only other option is a new game.-The enemies. Too easy to get rid of. They pose no real challenge and don't even really slow you down.-The town. It is way too small to really bring that feel of exploration, and the various areas are split into separate zones.Overall the concept delivered really well. The game really puts you in that fantasy of being a ghost. I would've wished for more varied gameplay and more gameplay in general. The shortness of the game really destroys it. I wanted to love this game with all my heart but I just can't. The flaws are too numerous and too big to ignore.I feel it deserves to be played, but the price right now is way too high. Definitely grab it when it's put on sale

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
er 27, 2015
												A game in which a Yahtzee Crowshaw cosplayer gets killed by a man and then, as a ghost, follows a fairly predictable plotline to find out who the killer was.  Also the killer kills some other people and there is ghosts hanging about the place.  If you, for whatever reason, struggle to follow the story, just think of it as Ghost, the 1990 film about a ghost, but in a video game.The game starts out in media res after showing the protagonist getting lots of tattoos.  Apparently this is important, somehow, because he was a criminal but is now a cop?  Dunno.  The game then moves on to demonstrating just how bad of a PC port it is.  When I first use my ghostly powers to possess someone, when using a keyboard, I got stuck and was unable to move.  The controls were unresponsive and I had to end the game’s process in task manager.  Definitely use a controller for this one.Shortly after you will meet the game’s deuteragonist, Joy, who is a young girl able to see Ronan, the player, even though he is a ghost.  She isn’t too happy about that because she is always seeing them.  She tells you to ♥♥♥♥ off even after she is informed that you are able to help her find her mother who’s buggered off somewhere (it really is just “somewhere”, you never find out where).  Eventually she resigns herself to helping you if for no other reason than to get Ronan to shut the ♥♥♥♥ up.  What a great partnership.Ronan himself is a fairly likeable character.  If you can get passed his ridiculous attire, plethora of edgy tattoos and the Phantom Cigarette which he never seems to stop smoking, he’s kind of alright.  He reminded me a little of Bigby from The Wolf Among Us; rolled up shirt sleeves, nasty smoking habit and devil-may-care attitude.  His hat is still stupid, though.  He’s basically a modern time discount Cole Phelps.The game itself is quite short.  While I am not usually bothered by the time it takes to complete a game, I was somewhat miffed when I played for around four and a half hours, went to bed, woke up the following morning and managed to finish the game off in about half an hour.  The game’s ending itself appears rushed, scrambling to tie the plot together by showing various scenes with aspects of the story being finalised, but at least it tries.Like many other developers, Airtight Games felt compelled to shoehorn in combat any way they could.  This means that occasionally you’ll come across Demons which you must kill by sneaking up behind them and performing a QTE.  This serves to do nothing else by distract the player and ruin the pace of an otherwise good gameplay loop.  Fortunately, there is a way to edit one of the game’s .ini files in order to stop the Demons spotting you.  They will still spawn, but ignore you completely.  Some may see this as cheating, I see this as an improvement.SPOILERS AHEAD: The ghost girl you meet at the beginning of the game, Abigail, is the killer.  This comes as absolutely no surprise.  It is quickly established that the people stuck in what is ostensibly Purgatory may only leave if they resolve and move on from a key event in their life.  Ronan’s problem is that he never figured out who the Bell Killer was.  And what about Abigail?  Well, Ronan has a very basic possession ability, allowing him to go inside the mind of living beings (and control cats).  But Abigail’s are far more advanced than that.  Yes, she possess people and then kills other people.  Well, mediums, specifically.  Because they’re, like, witches or something.  Her motives are flimsy at best, completely balls-to-the-wall ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and ungrounded at worst.Unlike a similar game, L.A. Noire, I found myself always one or two steps ahead of Ronan in the story.  Many times he would receive sudden clarity on something, and I would be sitting there thinking “Really?  Well, duh.  How did you not already figure that out?”.  At one point, when Ronan finally figures out the thing I’d already clocked onto hours before (the killer’s identity) he asked “But how did she do it?”.  BECAUSE SHE IS A GHOST WHO CAN POSSESS PEOPLE.  YOU CAN DO THE EXACT SAME THING.It might seem like I completely hate the game, but I don’t really.  It’s flawed, but it’s also quite compelling.  While the story’s conclusion was foreseeable, it was still enjoyable to watch the characters make their way to it.  I still haven’t figured out why the ghosts could pass through walls, but not fall through the ground, though.  ‘Tis a mystery which plagues many stories like these.

												Murdered: Soul Suspect is an adventure game with stealth aspects. The storyline of this game is what makes you want to keep playing , there are alot of broken or just bad mechanics in the game - inspecting and collecting things seems to be very hit or miss whether u get the button prompt based on camera orientation on the object. They tried to add in a aspect of danger to the game via "demons" in my opinion this was only a negative aspect as the combat system is very unfullfling and tedious , i found my self just running past most of these parts of the game ( which i suppose is the stealth aspect they were trying to include). The storyline isnt exactly ground breaking and its probably what you expect from a game set in modern day "Town of Salem" it does try to have a few plot twist and turns to keep you immersed in the main story though. There are also side quest investigations in the town which really dont advance the main story and only serve to distract you for  a few minutes. The Graphics and art style of the game are very well done and do a good job of setting the atmospheric scene in the town/game. There are is fair amount of people living in this town the only down side to this is alot of the characters are duplicated which really takes away the immersive feeling the game is trying to capture with its graphics and storyline.Its a Short game but worth a play through ( Definitely worth a purchase if its on sale )

												The best thing this game's got going for it is the voice acting and MAYBE the story.  The story had me very interested.  Maybe that's because I'm a sucker for detective stories?  Either way, the game itself is... very standard.  The "battling" of the demons is literally a repetitive quick-time palooza. Some may argue this is a great addition to the game, but you get nothing except acheivements for completing this tasks, and it felt less-rewarding then usual.There is no newgame+.  Once you beat the game, you restart from your last checkpoint, which happens to be a point of no return.  If you happen to miss some collectibles after this point: tough ♥♥♥♥; you're going to have to restart your entire file.I, personally enjoyed playing the game and getting involved with the characters and the story, but I CANNOT support the outragous price Square-Enix is asking for on this game.  I managed to spend 20$ on this bugger and I still feel like I might have overpayed by a small margine.Give or take, I'd pick this up in the future for like, 5-15$ to give it a try.  Skip it for now. content:
9, 2014
												I wish there was a middle of the road button in Steam, not just the basic yes or no.When i first saw this game i was really impressed and 100% in on the first day as far as picking it up goes.I've stuck a no on this, but my last comment is pretty much a yes, just for the right price.One of the problem's with this game, is that i perhaps didn't find out enough about it before buying it.I do like my puzzle and mystery games a lot, i sort of had it in my mind that this would be a bit of a hybrid.(Which it is, just not fully developed i think)The whole marketing side was gearing you up for playing an epic murder mystery, but what you get instead is just very linear.I'll point out the bits that really were poor, and then some of the bits i did like.1) Fighting enemies - This is both a chore, and yet few and far between too.It's almost like you "could" fight enemies in some areas as there are hiding spots and things to possess -There just aren't any.(When i say fight, basically all you do is sprint up behind them and do a poor QTE)2) Uncovering evidence - Not really uncovering, much more like clicking on things in the vicinity, with a running tally telling you how many you are missing. (This also leads into the next point)3) Detective score - 0 reasons for this to be there, every investigation will rank you out of 5 stars.Trying to jolt someones memory in the game? Well ignore the stars and just click on everything, as you wont get penalised.(Same with the uncovering evidence, just get the main parts you need and move on, the only reason to listen and view all parts is for the story - i have a positive for this later as well)4) Bugged side quests - Meet a ghost and solve their tale, only for the large amount of times that you exit and reload the game for them to be still wailing on about something when you return.(They are supposed to go to heaven... i think after you do the mission - Though it never really says, they just get ingulfed by a white light and float off)5) Masses of the same character models all throughout the game.6) Map hub world -  I can see what they were tryng to convey, what with the ghost buildings... almost like a tear in time.It's just a shame that theres not much acually happening, just a lot of weirdo human NPC's hanging around in parks and on benchs in the middle of the night complaining of a murderer hanging around (Your in a park in the middle of the night... errr)7) Lack of locations.8) Possessing people - It wears thin, especially when they only have two lines of internal monologue to listen to at best.(Most people also have set paths if they aren't just sitting)Ok, what i liked 1) Character development to a degree was pretty good, the main characters are fairly well fleshed out throughout the game.2) The story, although you know it's going to be a supernatural sort of tale, it actually just ignores most of the witchcraft side of Salem until about 70% of the way through.3) The ghost stories and tales are fairly well done.4) What little locations are in the game are nice enough to look at.5) Some times the random ghosts freaked me out a bit.What could have made it better - 1) More sections with the whole "Cat" possession :-)2) The ability to scare people and freak them out with possessions.3) More locations and places to explore.4) More... way more, NPC's and things to interact with.So, thats all i got, i think when i was playing it i came up with a lot more negatives, but the story was pretty engaging.If i had to give a score and some final comments i'd say - 6/10 - Only buy if you can pick it up for less than £10.00

content:
er 20, 2014
												I haven't felt the need to review for a while, but I can't help but talk about this game. For those of you who have played the Blackwell series (look at my review), I feel that Square Enix programmers played the games and thought, "Hey, we can make a non-P&C, grittier, updated graphics version of Blackwell!". In some respects, it really feels that way. A ghost needs to solve his own murder, plus help lost ghosts solve their issues so that they can move on with the help of a medium. Only instead of Roseangela we get a whiny teenager by the name of Joy. The crime solving isn't that difficult, but when the story is this enjoyable who really cares? The game takes place in Salem, and I feel that the town is one of the big stars of the game. The developers knew they had a lot to work with and they did a great job. You get to discover artifacts that uncover Salem's dark history, uncover artifacts that reveal haunting stories, and help ghosts piece together their untimely end. The main characters are a mixed bag. Ronan, is a detective who spent most of his life on the wrong side of Lady Law before joining the force. He's a great character. His sidekick is a gothic emo of a teenager named Joy. I see why they think she needs to be here, but I just didn't like her that much. Luckily, she only appears as much as she needs to, leaving you free to take your time between levels to explore Salem and backtrack for achievements or artifacts if need be. For you artifact and achievement junkies, there is a ton to find. Most will be able to find a lot of the stuff, in the first playthrough, but it is worth playing again. I highly recommend this supernatural detective game.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												Murdered Soul Suspect won't blow anyone away, but it's a fun game with some good ideas that are unfortunately poorly implemented at times.To be honest, I was a bit excited when I first heard of Murdered, but the lack of advertising and previews always make me worry about the final product. By the time it released it seems the studio was already closing down and no effort was made to promote it and that way try and earn some extra money with it. This was already obvious by the unusually high amount of discounts, months ahead of its release date. This game wasn't going to win any awards, and they knew that for quite some time then.Graphically the game isn't the best, but it isn't the worst either. Models look nice and detailed, as well as the vilage. There are plenty of people walking around, ghosts and human, and there's a nice mix of still standing buildings and buildings that were destroyed in a fire a long time ago (and, like all the other ghosts, are being shown with a ghostly aura around them).In the beginning it's explained why you can't just enter any building you see which sounds ridiculous when you hear it. It's obvious things were changed because of its low(er) budget. Still, it's more disappointing than it is frustrating. It would've been nice if you could go anywhere you want, but ok, that's just my opinion, of course.A nice touch is the addition of static ghosts in the backgrounds that disappear once you get closer to them. Nothing eery or scary but cool evertheless (and maybe even underused).The voice acting is actually very good, especially that of Ronan and Joy. I also can't complain about the music and sounds, which range from very decent to very good.As far as the story is concerned; it's ok-ish. I was hoping for a mysterious story and while you keep guessing until the end it didn't have the payoff I was hoping to get. About three quarters in, the story becomes clearer and your expectations will probably change. Some might like it, others might like it less. I am part of the group that liked it less. The story became less personal near the end and I was disappointed by it.Ghosts can also be found standing and hanging around certain places. They have some creepy stories to tell, and this is one of the things the game does right. But talking to some of these ghosts will give you a conversation tree to choose from. These are absolutely worthless and add nothing to the story or game. Again a case of wanting to add too much and where it's obvious they eventually had to cut it out because of time/money constraints.The real sidequests have deeper stories than the other ghosts found in the game and solving these is fun and worth the time.The gameplay consists of walking around and pressing context-sensitive buttons. Solving cases usually require you to search the area in search of items or people and press a specific button. Once you have enough evidence to solve a case you can do this, again, by pressing a button. You then have to click a memory (which basically is a piece of evidence you found) or click on memories in a certain order (like; how something may have happened).Stealth is also used but it's so minimal that it's barely even worth mentioning. I think these can be counted on one hand. Still, it adds some variety to the game and it's something that makes the games a little harder. They should've used it more frequently because it works well.There are a few groundbreaking bugs in the game. Mine started with the first investigation when things are still being explained to you. The buttons and tutorial overlays didn't work so I couldn't trigger anything. After a few minutes I reloaded the checkpoint and this time it worked just fine. This happened 3 or 4 more times during the course of the game. Annoying bugs that shouldn't be there because the other elements of the game work fine and even feel polished.Murdered Soul Suspect isn't the game I originally wanted to have but it's still fun if you like ghost and detective stories. Don't expect a hardcore game here, but something a bit more casual; a game that anyone can play and finish.It's not a great game, but not something mediocre either.[Rating: 73/100]

content:
6, 2015
Overview11 hours until the end36/48 achievementsI am not a great adventure fan, so for one of these, things might be different.This game has some of the worst aspects of adventures, the very reasons why I do not like most adventures.There will be spoilers, so if you don't want them, stop reading.The good clues:I like the graphics and the sound. I like the idea about being a ghost who searches his murderer very much. Mindreading people is fun for 10 minutes until you realize that it is good for nothing if you are not currently searching for clues.The bad clues:It starts with the bad experience in the first scene, you have to search for clues. You are even told how many there are and how many you already have.You think, "cool, searching a murder scene for clues".You saw in a video what happened, you were thrown through a window from high above. So why is broken glass a "clue"? Why? Why is your gun a clue? You have to find.. don't know 7 or 9 clues and you get NO new info out of these clues. And it is really as bad as in my first adventures, more than 20 years ago. You have to find the pixel which is the clue. But is worse than 20 years ago, because you do not just move your mouse, you move a character and the character has too look at the pixel.Next scene, you have to find x/y clues. After a while you realize, it is again moving around until you get the info that you are looking at a clue. Cool...not. It gets worse. You don't believe me? It GETS worse.You will get no hint in that direction, but sometimes, for example in the second scene, you will not find all clues, but you have to conclude from your already found "clues".These conclusions are the worst you can imagine. Nope. That is not true. They are worse.There is NO logic (no human logic at least) behind the decision which picture is the right to chose. Then, after this is done, sometimes you have new sensitive pixels in the scene. Somewhere.Sometimes it is so bad, you KNOW that there, at exact that spot has to be the pixel you want to "find" (google, walkthrough or load game), but you have to move and turn and snake around the pixel until you get it.So, what have we until now? Pixel searching, clues which give you no clue and missing logic in the conclusions you HAVE to make.Can it get worse?It can. But at least it is a taste thing. Some - adventure lovers - will see it as normal, some - as me - will start to hate.You see, there will be puzzles. These will be of the kind: "I am a ghost and have no clue, help me". Then you search a radus of 5 meters around the ghost for x/y clues (you remember that one, right?) and will come to totally unlogic conclusions and "puff", the ghost is happy and goes away to heaven. Yeah, real police stuff, you know.And then, then there are the demons. In a game about ghosts, why should be there no demons you ask?Because they are used as action/stealth elements which make the game longer, have you die and get you to curse a lot.If you find in the steam forum some message about "how to disable demons", then you know, you are not alone with your frustration. These demons do not really make sense for the story of the game. STOP! NO THEY DON'T!They just get in your way when you want to continue with the story.Oh oh. The story.I have to say, the story is kind of good and interesting. But had I known how brutal the game (what is told and what you see in backflashes) will become, I would not have bought it.I do not like brutality or sadism in my games. And I like really happy endings in my games.I was sad when the story ended, not because the game was finished, I was so happy that I was done with it, but I was sad because the story told about horrid fates of young friendly girls who just had wanted to help others.ConclusionIf you a an adult adventure lover, get it. You will love it, I fear.For all others, keep away, don't get it, not even cheap. Just DO NOT GET IT!And do NOT give it to your children to play it. I think, the story is just too brutal. At least for me.Do NOT buy!

content:
er 5, 2016
												I wanted to like this game, but then I played it.  Pretty much every mechanic in the game is handled poorly.  Most of the puzzles in the game consist of you searching the crime scene to collect a pool fo mostly useless clues and then picking the correct one out of the list when prompted.  Hmm, which clue is related to the Bell Killer?  Could it be the one that just says "Bell Killer"? Yes, yes it is.  Every time.   90% of the "puzzles" are exactly this.  No creative or deductive thought is required to finish this game.  The only other major mechanic in this game is demons.  They are one of the worst mechanics of any game I've ever played.  Basically they are like wandering sentries that you have to sneak up on to destroy.  If they spot you they chase you around for a couple of minutes.  They are never fun.  They are only annoying hinderences that stop you from continuing the story.  They were obviously slapped onto the game to make things more "difficult" and drag the game out.  Without them you could probably finish the game in a couple of hours.  Most of which is walking back and forth between the various crime scenes in the absolutely tiny town of Salem.  There are a bunch of collectibles to find throughout the game, but unless you collect all of them of a given type you don't get anything out of it.  And when you do finally get them all you are rewarded with a crappy little short story about someone's death.  The overall story of the game is ok I guess.  It has some serious problems, but relative to how bad the rest of the game is, I guess it gets a pass.  It does not however make slogging through the rest of the game worth it.  I'll give the game some credit though, the title is sort of clever.

content:
er 7, 2014
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is the game where walking through walls and objects is no longer a bug but a feature.First of all you should realize that this game is basically split 50-50 between gameplay and cut scenes. If feels more like watching a movie than playing a game. You get to play as detective Ronan O’Connor. Objective - solve your own murder, and save the terrorized Salem from The Bell Killer. Murdered: Soul Suspect offers a compelling story with several twists, and manages to entertain till the very end. There are also some side quests you can complete by helping several ghost you'll encounter during the game. These ones are optional, but are recommended to complete in order to get a better perspective of the game and your detective skills, especially since the main story is quite short. If you decide to buy it i would advice not to put much hope in the gameplay. It's quite repetitive - explore the location, gather clues on the case, escape the demons, watch the cut scene, and over again... Overall, it somehow felt intriguing and mysterious, also quite different from most of the adventure games i've played. However, even after the recent price cut from $50 to $30 i still find it a bit overpriced and would recommend to get it on sale since it's too short, and has almost no replayability value, except if you're an achievement hunter and would need to play it a second time to get the ones you've missed.

content:
y 31, 2016
												You’ve been murdered, it’s a real bummer. But now you get the chance to find out who it was and seek justice from beyond the grave. Or you would if you played this.Enter Ronan a bad guy turned good trying to stop a murderer on a killing spree but wouldn’t you know it you wind up just another one of their victims. But with unfinished business to attend to you hang around for a while and haunt the halls of Salem city searching for clues that could lead you to solving your own murder and ascending to heaven. Or at least that’s the plan but as the recently departed not many people will talk to you. Enter the one witness to your death Joy who also happens to be psychic, after a lot of convincing the duo team up and take down the evil together. The story is certainly an intriguing and unique one. I have not seen a murder mystery from a dead person’s perspective before and with the amounts of twists and turns that come flying at you as you progress it will get you enthralled right to the end.The game is stacked full of collectables, over a hundred of them to be precise, each with its own story. They all fit seamlessly into the town of Salem with its terrible past and not too stellar present. The world is more or less open world with you being able to travel from one location to another through the hub of the down town area. Each part of the world is beautifully designed and looks great mixing an old ghostly past with the present to make something new.The game also features a huge amount of side quests and cases to solve. Speaking of which the detective mode is also something of an oddity, find a crime and solve it with clues found in the environment and placed together like pieces of a puzzle, I found a lot of pleasure recreating crimes to try and figure out what had happened and who the culprit was.Now onto the main meat of the game combat…. There is none. Well that’s not true, there are a few enemies and by few I mean around 12 in the whole game and the only thing that happens is when they see you a QTE begins, win and you can proceed, lose and you have to start a short ways back. I would classify this more as an interactive novel than a game. Not that it’s a bad thing, but just be sure that’s what you are looking for before you delve in.This game offers a lot and is a great distraction if you are looking for a unique experience that’s heavy on the narrative but light in most other places. At full price I can’t really recommend it but on sale you should pick this up and just enjoy your time in purgatory.Have Fun ^_^

content:
ry 23, 2015
												This game surprised me.As the player you assume the role of the ghost of a deceased detective that is trying to piece together his own murder. You are invisible to most of the civilians, you can pass through walls, you can possess people and eavesdrop conversations.Let's talk about the game strong points:- Excelent presentation: graphically the game looks great, there is great attention to detail and the PC port is quite good.- Decent plot and interesting lore that keeps the game interesting until it's conclusion.- Original concept for an adventure/investigation.Factors that greatly detract from the experience:- The investigation mechanics are flawed and dull: there are no branching investigation paths, the interrogations are linear and you have no other choice but to follow the game's script.- There are stealth/action sequences involving demons. They feel like a simple filler, rather than something valuable. After the first or second encounter, there's nothing new to these encounters.In summary: an excellent concept is marred down by some crucial excution flaws which detract from the core experience. However, it is still worth the investment at a discount.Veredict: 7/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 30, 2014
												Surprisingly enjoyable. A not so long adventure game with an original idea but plagued by an average execution.The positiveMurdered takes the interesting concept of playing a dead man stuck between two worlds and having to solve his murder to be able to get to heaven. I really love this idea, you're investigating in two embedded worlds : the living and the dead. You can clip through most environment from the world of the living but get stuck against the environment of the dead. The setting is very well made with ghosts appearing and disappearing as well as people in an alike situation as yours : unable to let go and go to heaven. There are 4 side quests where you're helping someone to understand his/her death.I personally loved the aesthetic of the game, a mix of color and black and white. The game also is very well optimised and runs flawlessly on my laptop (i7 4500U, Nvidia GT750m) @ 900p/1080p. The story is enjoyable for the most part and the collaboration and interactions between Joy and Ronan are well-executed. Finally, the game has a lot of collectibles (242 to be precise), this can be either a positive or a negative point depending on the player.The negativeThe gameplay is below average even for an adventure game. Every step of the story involves you looking for clues in a small area, when you have enough clues you are able to link a few of them to each other to solve one question.... and that's it, for the whole game. The clues are either stupidly obvious or stupidly useless and the solving questions are terrible. The combat system sucks terribly too, it's simply about sneaking behind enemies and doing a simple QTE. Murdered won't be remembered for its gameplay.The story is very unbalanced. The first hour is basically setting the story and characters, the pace is slow and isn't very compelling. When you start seeing a bit through how the investigation is going to take place, it becomes enjoyable and that until the end of the game where you are faced to a completely stupid and abrupt ending. The ending feels rushed and I hated it because of this, the last chapter is like 5 minutes long... The rest of the game isn't very long either, count between 6 to 8 hours depending on whether you want to find all the collectibles or not.ConclusionIt might seem that the game is terrible but I personally enjoyed it anyway despite all of its flaws. The aesthetic and most of the story felt original. Many good ideas, poor execution but still worth it in my opinion. I wouldn't recommend it at full price though, buy it on sale.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
4, 2015
												I enjoyed it tremendously.  Absolutely a unique experience.Playing as a ghost was well implemented in my opinion.  They used what I found were convincing concepts in order to limit your navigation where needed, establishing clear rules from the outset.The mystery-solving was great.  It reminded me of L.A. Noire some (but I much preferred L.A. Noire I must say, as a game and specifically in its mystery-solving methods).  My one problem with it is that there really isn't a penalty for being a poor detective.  It's up to you to challenge yourself by not selecting all the answers until you get it right.  Of course, your 'ranking' is lowered for each incorrect guess but that's not a gameplay penalty as much as a pride penalty.The story was compelling and the voice-acting was brilliant for anyone with a name you learn in the game.  Unfortunately, most of the NPCs with names you don't know, are comically wooden and not remotely human.  I loved Joy, notable given I thought I'd hate an angsty teen written by someone that's not an angsty teen, moreover one that's meant to be comedic and have an attitude; the media don't seem to be good at that in general, so this was a nice change.Then there's the voice acting in the ghost stories.  That was phenomenal.  The stories were well written and well performed.  Absolutely a brilliant touch.I really felt connected to Julia, your wife in the game.  She's hardly in the game, but you can collect her memories, and they're written.  If you read them, you begin to develop a real sense of who she is.  I have to commend that sort of characterisation.The main character is believable.  Probably someone I'd laugh at in real life (even though I'd still like him; he's a good person and he certainly takes things in stride), but I can't say I haven't known people like him.  And the writing and acting make that believeable.Speaking of taking things in stride, that's one flaw in the writing; too many people take too many things in stride.  But that's negligible in the face of everything else.The combat system isn't much of a combat system, but I felt it worked well.  In fact, had they called your one move 'exorcise' or something instead of 'execute', you could have had a true example of a great game utterly devoid of combat, where overcoming your enemy isthe best thing you can do for them.  There's a nice stealth element alongside the one move you have.The dæmons are extremely creepy in design.  I love it.The music is great, but I wish that in a place where it becomes tense for enemies, that it would become less tense once the enemies are neutralised.  It doesn't.  A minor flaw I suppose.The game feels like an indie game and was developed by Airtight Games, who were apparently independent according to Wikipedia.  I say this because the graphics are rather poor compared to contemporary games, and like many indie developers, the engine used was the old UE3 engine, rather than what was most current.There's a lot of history in the game.  Old Salem bleeds into the modern Salem as the main character (and all ghosts I imagine) sees things.  You can collect snippets of history, which were probably all accurate, as the ones I was familiar with were all correct.Bonus:I'm a linguist, and I liked that a lot of the accents were notably correct.  The game takes placein Salem, which isn't too far from Boston.  I'm very familiar with the Boston accent as it's rather high-profile in dialects of English, and moreover as it has a significant Irish influence.  I'm not terribly familiar with Salem's accent but a lot of characters possess Boston traits so I assume they were trying to localise the accent at least as Massachusetts, which is really interesting to someone like me.  Also, a lot of Irish turns of phrase are used, which on looking them up are apparently common in that area of America, from Irish emigrants.  Nice.  Not only that, a lot of people have Irish names, which is rather realistic and once again interesting.Oh, but the old-time Puritan accents were cat.  Absolute rubbish they were.Speaking of cats, you can possess cats and meow and climb things and jump on things.  Another nice touch.

content:
y 31, 2016
												You’ve been murdered, it’s a real bummer. But now you get the chance to find out who it was and seek justice from beyond the grave. Or you would if you played this.Enter Ronan a bad guy turned good trying to stop a murderer on a killing spree but wouldn’t you know it you wind up just another one of their victims. But with unfinished business to attend to you hang around for a while and haunt the halls of Salem city searching for clues that could lead you to solving your own murder and ascending to heaven. Or at least that’s the plan but as the recently departed not many people will talk to you. Enter the one witness to your death Joy who also happens to be psychic, after a lot of convincing the duo team up and take down the evil together. The story is certainly an intriguing and unique one. I have not seen a murder mystery from a dead person’s perspective before and with the amounts of twists and turns that come flying at you as you progress it will get you enthralled right to the end.The game is stacked full of collectables, over a hundred of them to be precise, each with its own story. They all fit seamlessly into the town of Salem with its terrible past and not too stellar present. The world is more or less open world with you being able to travel from one location to another through the hub of the down town area. Each part of the world is beautifully designed and looks great mixing an old ghostly past with the present to make something new.The game also features a huge amount of side quests and cases to solve. Speaking of which the detective mode is also something of an oddity, find a crime and solve it with clues found in the environment and placed together like pieces of a puzzle, I found a lot of pleasure recreating crimes to try and figure out what had happened and who the culprit was.Now onto the main meat of the game combat…. There is none. Well that’s not true, there are a few enemies and by few I mean around 12 in the whole game and the only thing that happens is when they see you a QTE begins, win and you can proceed, lose and you have to start a short ways back. I would classify this more as an interactive novel than a game. Not that it’s a bad thing, but just be sure that’s what you are looking for before you delve in.This game offers a lot and is a great distraction if you are looking for a unique experience that’s heavy on the narrative but light in most other places. At full price I can’t really recommend it but on sale you should pick this up and just enjoy your time in purgatory.Have Fun ^_^

content:
y 2, 2016
												Great game on sale, got it dirt cheap not expecting too much but it ended up surprising me.  Would not buy it for full price though.  The only thing that sucks about the game are the demon encounters, they just feel out of place and unnecessary.  The game has a good enough story and investigation/exploration sections that it doesn't need the demon sections at all.  It's a real shame because the idea had potential too.  I was hoping for something in the vein of demons being disguised as regular ghosts trying to trick you into making bad decisions via dialogue options to steal your soul but instead they're patrolling enemies that you have to avoid and stealth kill.  The most annoying thing is when they detect you for no reason whatsoever or when you are in exactly the correct position to execute them and get no prompt to do so.  These sections are a pretty small portion of the game though and there's only a handful of them.  Anyone whose played any stealth oriented games will have no problems with them outside of the issues mentioned above.  Overall, it was a great story with a couple twists on the end that I just didn't see coming.  The game is worth a playthrough if you're looking for something different that's story driven and not action packed.  Voice acting was great too, Ronan and Joy are both likable characters with tons of personality.  Will probably play this again at some point to get all the collectables and do the side missions that I missed.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
15, 2015
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is actually a really good game. Okay, maybe that's an overstatement, but I really enjoyed it's approach to detective work and solving the mystery of your own murder as well as the recent string of murders in Salem in a single night.You play Ronan O'Connor, a former petty criminal/turned detective who is hot on the trail of the Bell Killer, only the opening cutscene is your own death. The game picks up right from there as you search for clues and get used to being a ghost. The devs handled the ghost mechanics rather well as far as being unable to walk into buildings from the outside unless there's an open doorway or window. But you can move through walls, bushes, benches, etc.The story is really intriguing and it seemed like it was going to be predictable, but I was wrong. I didn't know who the killer was from the get go. So, I tip my hat to the devs for pulling a decent M Night Shamalamadingdong. Sound design is eerie, as it should be. Unnamed NPC's that walk around Salem that you can possess, well, a lot of them looked the same and had the same responses when reading their minds, that bugged me. And for being an open world town, it seemed more restricted than anything because of the ghost walls that you can't pass through. It just made the town section of the game seem a lot more linear, but like a maze.The graphics were decent enough, but it's clear that the game was held back due to last gen consoles. I mean, some of the modeling and textures look like games from 2010.The mystery work was a lot of fun though, searching for clues and whatnot. Good game.7.5/10

content:
17, 2014
												Murdered: Soul Suspect was a game I've been heavily anticipating ever since I saw it in action. I expected something along the lines of Ghost Trick mixed with L.A. Noire. What I got instead was essentially a much better Beyond Two Souls and that in of itself isn't a bad thing.Taking place in Salem, Massachusetts, you play as the deceased Detective Ronan O'Connor. Murdered by a mysterious serial-killer, he finds out that the only way to pass on to the afterlife and reunite with his dead wife is to figure out the murders identity identity so he may leave this mortal plane. It's a decent Whodunit story with a lot of interesting side-stories unlocked through collectibles.My biggest problem with this game is the gameplay or lack thereof. For what it's worth, I did enjoy Murdered: Soul Suspect when you realize the game isn't trying to be Ghost Trick or LA Noire, but this is something you'll notice more and more as you'll go along. I actually think it starts out pretty well. You walk through walls, talk to fellow ghosts, discover their stories through detective work. It all seemed fine until you find out that's that where it stops. It never gets any harder, better more complex, better. The game doesn't offer much depth and at worse, becomes less interesting for the player. All you do is press X to evidence. There are no fail states in the investigation sections. There are no incentives to actually think logically and not randomly guess at what the game throws at you besides meaningless tokens and even then the game is incredibly easy. "Oh, I wonder what memory will remind this witness of the killer. Hmm... could it perhaps be this thought bubble right here called THE KILLER?" I admit, sometimes possessing a human and hearing his thoughts can be kinda cool, but it really doesn't enough with the concept. You never manipulate their actions unless it's for something incredibly mundane, never use them to walk around, there are no puzzles to solve, it just feels like a missed opportunity.Besides there's not really much to talk about. You can occasionally posses cats to find a new path to your objectives, you can try to find these loads of collectibles or.... fight random demons? Yeah, even though it's not relevant to the plot at all, you have to sneak past these dementor-like creatures or take these things down from behind stealthily, the latter being the most common. This isn't even a rare occurrence, this happened more then I could count. It's not all bad and sneaking past them does sometimes work, but why is this even here? This has no point other then to waste my time! The combat in this game couldn't be more tacked on even if you tried. I also thought using quicktime events to defeat them was incredibly annoying, because the buttons you need to press are randomized every time, but at the very least, you're given a surprisingly large amount of of time to get the right ones down so if there's one thing to praise them for it's that.It's with this that I realized that the game isn't trying to deep in terms of gameplay and that it's going for a specific audience who don't really want to put much thought into their gaming. With that said, I still had a good time with Murdered: Soul suspect. Like I said before, the story is good and that's really what they wanted to tell here. The lightning effects and shading are some of the best I've ever seen in a computer game however this comes with the unfortunate side effect of your game for thirty seconds just to load the next area. This isn't exclusive to the PC version, even the next-gen versions suffer from frame rate drops, stutters and others but technical hiccups aside, I'd say the game is still worth a purchase, but not for full price obviously. If you're still not convinced: all I'm saying is that I'll take a Murdered: Soul Suspect which simplifies a lot of aspects about its genre then the latest 6 Final Fantasy games or so.

content:
0, 2014
												If your dream has always been playing an undead fedora-wearing douchbag neckbeard solving criminal cases like some try-hard Maltese Falcon reject who can't come to terms with the fact that he neither lives in the 1940s, nor understands the actual era (dress code included) - this might just be the game for you. Douchehat McNeckbeard might be laughably slow in how he connects clues, but he comes with a full package of mangst in the form of a fridged (of course) Manic Pixie Dreamgirl wife, and the attitude you'd expect from a 40-year-old basement dweller. If that is what you enjoy in a game, this will be a dream for you - albeit an admittedly short one, since the game is as the most 10 hours, and that's when you take your time as I did.On a more serious note, this game did have potential, and I really wanted to like it. Tuning out the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ protagonist and his ridiculous and frankly embarrassing fashion sense (which is explained away in the most ridiculous 'didn't even try' manner possible in the game), parts of the gameplay, particularly in the beginning, were fun. Sadly the really fun parts are tragically underused, and for the course of the game following the opening mission, you experience practically nothing new. The first bigger investigation was fun especially through learning all the things you could do to get clues - connect existing clues in your head for new revelations, possess people and prompt them to reveal what they knew by triggering the right clues in their heads, seeing through their eyes into computer files, etc - but there it ended. You acquire a few more fine-tuned skills later on (teleporting, most notably), but nothing that really stands out. The fun experimental trying and testing which witness might have seen what and respond to which clues turns into a tedious button-smashing 'where's the one tiny object in the room that I keep missing?' adventure. Gameplay stagnates and turns into the same thing over and over and over again, only for Mr Fedora to finally come to a conclusion that quite frankly you could have told him after or even before entering the building.The worst part by far is the writing. Not only are the main characters (most notably the supposed 'tough cops' who only come across as petty, ♥♥♥♥♥y, and whiny) utterly unlikeable, but the main story itself lacks any originality. For the sake of avoiding spoilers if you are for whatever reason still interested in playing, I won't go into the details further, but whatever 'twists' were apparently thought up by the writers have been done before and repeated to death, were foreseeable to the point I don't even want to call it foreshadowing anymore, and - due to the absolutely flat character writing - lacked any sort of emotional impact. I never thought a game centring around a murder investigation done by a GHOST in ♥♥♥♥ing SALEM could be boring, but this is. It's plain and simply boring, with slightly awkward, incredibly repetitice gameplay, and with the added disadvantage of the most obnoxious, annoying, self-centred, whiny wannabe-tough guy fedora-wearing neckbeard Gary Stu of a protagonist I have ever seen. It's like a bad '40s film noir rip off (BUT IN SALEM, WOOO SUPERNATURAL THINGS) gone completely wrong. And not even spectacularly wrong, just underwhelming, tedious, and most of all - disappointing.There are worse games, of course, but this game stands out mainly because it doesn't - it's all been done before, been done better, and there is literally nothing that this game has to offer. It's not the worst, not a spectacular train wreck, but it's poor, and it's sad. Good for a few minutes of fun, and if you really have to kill time and have absolutely nothing else to do.Overall, 2/5, and that's me being nice, because I enjoyed parts of the early gameplay. Suggested time to buy: at 90% off.

content:
5
												Being an old-time fan of the venerable Scapeghost by Level Nine, I grabbed this one with high expectations. And it's all there: You get to walk through walls, read people's minds, interfere with TV Sets and solve your own murder case. All that with Unreal-Engine powered graphics, a teenage punk medium and evil demons chasing you - what could possibly go wrong? The intro sequence showing the protagonist's past being inscribed as tattoos on his body was nice storytelling as well, so I was really, really ready to like and recommend this after like ten minutes.The setting is also fitting, with run-down buildings, a creepy cemetary and, of course, an asylum, all set within Salem which drips with atmosphere all by itself.And then it feels like the guys or girls with the nice ideas went to do something else, or got fired, or had no more time left.First, after being introduced with a rich background and ambiguous personality, the characters put all their dimesions aside and do exactly what you'd expect them to, in a mildly stereotypic way that makes them feel like copies from a couple of similar movies you just can't remember right now. This is especially true for side characters. No one expects brilliant writing for every single one-line (to be exact, two-line) character, but whatever chance for creepy, humorous or kinky or otherwise interesting background was given by the setting, nearly none of that was taken. And apart from five relevant persons and a couple of side-quest givers, everyone is a two-line character.Second, the game mostly progresses through you doing "police work". In itself, that wouldn't be much of a problem, as ghost stories and crime stories usually go quite well together. But this game relies more on your stuff collecting skills than on any form of crime puzzle solving. Any hint you may find has a generic one-line description but you won't ever read one, as you get an informative clip once you found 9/9, 15/15 or 20/20 hints, I think you can guess the mechanics. Any combination or deduction is done by the game itself by letting you choose from some heavily hinted options.Apart from the main story, there are bonus tidbits scattered everywhere. Once you found x/x of these, you get told a ghost story and go on. Some of the tidbits require jump-and run episodes, some the use of ghost abilities, but there is no other interconnection between them and the rest of the game. Same goes for side quests.The plot actually does not feel that bad, but the shallow, "consoley" approach to it, repetitive gameplay and thin dialogue, the tedious fights, the linear progression and the lots of walking didn't do it for me. It is an action game without action trying to be an adventure without puzzles. Which is a real pity because it does have production value.
