content:
1
												So, by this time I'm done with the game. Having done most but not all side missions. Worth mentioning that I got it via the Square Enix's mystery box for March which was 10$. For those looking for the punch-line of the review on if it's worth your money or not (29,99$), here it is guys and gals: If you like point and click adventure games, sure, go ahead, it's one of the better of it's kind, you don't see tripple A point and clicks that often. If not, I'd wait for a really good sale. Also keep in mind that the replayability value is low, if any.Now, into the depths: *The Plot* : You're a badass detective under the department of the Salem area, an active serial killer is around and you just happen to pick to have your badass moment going-in without back up moment in the wrong place and in the wrong time, getting killed. Surprise, you're now Casper and you get to be a detective in the afterlife trying to solve your own murder while trying not to get killed (again) by demons in the ghost town. The concept in itself is marvelous- who wouldn't want to be a ghost detective? But the execution.. Don't get me wrong, it had it's moments and a few great twists, but for the most time the story felt predictable, the characters felt very shallow and generic and they certainly  did not make me to want to know more about them. I really wanted to buy into the world, but I just could not feel it. Overall, the world building felt weak, if not rushed. It's like reading one of those books that you thought they were okay, but you just wished there was more to them because their description made you expect more. In short : -Average*The Gameplay*: As I mentioned earlier, the gameplay is point and click for 90% of the time. Those interested in L.A Noire/Sherlock games are out of luck, no observation needed what so ever, your only penalties are that you lose 'ranks' each time you make a mistake, that's pretty much it. Outside that, you go from area to area, you point and click at clues, you get clues, you point and click clues into a sequence and tadam, you're the Sherlock Holmes of the Underworld. Is it repetetive? Very. Is it a criticism? Not in this genre. Outside the point and clicking, you'll get to jog around the world for quite a bit from place to place with occasional simplistic puzzles that for the most part -you guessed it, require you to click on something and see magic happen. I gotta point out that the navigation after some point gets tiring and as a result of the world not feeling very lively, the game would have benefitted greatly from a fast travel option at some point. The devs put some interesting 'invisible' walls around the game so that as a ghost, you cant go through everything, you gotta go through the simplistic puzzles, of course and on top of that, those invisible walls and obstacles which make the world look 'cooler', also make it harder and pointlessly longer to traverse. The side missions around the world although they sometimes have an interesting backstory, are not very engaging for the most part. At some point, the invisible walls get very frustrating, especially once you get your teleport power as they get nonsensical. The weakest part of the gameplay is the combat. It's tedious and clunky. I wish I could demonstrate. There are demons, chasing you around, you have no weapons to fight so you have to hide and execute them from the back. The number of times I was spamming the execution button till it responded  but I left it (you gotta hold it) and failed the quick time event (YES, QTES BOIZ) which most likely resulted to my death or running around for 2 minutes as a result is immense. Not only that but the execution animations remain the same every time and its the same, over, and over, and over.. If you're adding combat, even stealthy combat into your game, you gotta be more creative. A huge spike of irritation comes in the last sequence of the game which becomes unforgivingly hard and 'timed'. I got so frustrated at that point that I finished it on another day. But that's literally the last 5 minutes. Overall, the gameplay, aside from the point and clicking is very average, with the combat being a gigantic unpleasant pain for the player.*Graphics* : Unimpressive. Although the main character model looks good, the world itself looks mostly uninspired and bland. The textures are pretty outdated and the effects were generic mostly. The character models outside the main character are mediocore. Your enemies are always the same kind, looking exactly the same like someone performed a kage bushin no jutsu (Yep, a Naruto reference). This unfortunately is the same also for the peope around you such as cops and even some ghosts are just so, so uninspired. Overall: Average (probably) for it's time, below average for what it is now.*Sound, Music, Voice Acting* : The sound of the game is actually good, I found myself enjoying each cutscene after an investigation was over as a result of the robust sound they provided. Its not ground breaking, but it felt more effortful. The music is very repetetive, its definitely not getting any 'extended' remixe's anytime soon, if ever. The voice was okay, the lip syncing was fine but if you were expecting L.A Noire, well, that's not the one.Is it worth your buy? For 29.99 I'd probably only recommend it to die hard point and click fans that wished for big publishrs to release point and click titles. For the rest, just wait for a good sale. The only thing the game has going for it is it's story which is not as interesting as the cover makes it to be. It's a missed opportunity for a game that would have great potential if you added better combat, a more fleshed out world and made people care for the characters.

content:
5, 2016
												I was excited to try Murdered: Soul Suspect out as it had an interesting concept and Square Enix is one of those publishers whose name is a guarantee for a good game (well, most of the time it is). The game received average scores from critics upon its release, which is probably due to some false expectations. Worry not however, Murdered: Soul Suspect is a very good game, just don't make the mistake of expecting something it cannot provide.It features an 'over the shoulder' third-person view (as seen in Resident Evil 4 or Dead Space) that might lead you to believe that Murdered: Soul Suspect is an action orientated game. It isn't. It is an adventure game that focuses on collecting clues and coming to conclusions with a pretty good story unfolding as we progress.The introduction is one of the most unique in video game history: we witness our own murder. The protagonist, Detective Ronan O'Connor is killed by a masked assailant, who turns out to be the Bell Killer, a serial murderer who's been killing the citizens of Salem (a fictionalized version of an existing town in Massachusetts, USA) seemingly randomly. As a ghost, Ronan meets Julia, his dead wife, who informs him that he is stuck between the world of the living and the afterlife and cannot join her until he solves a mystery connected to his life that binds him there. It isn't hard to guess, that this is related to the Bell Killer case and we'll have to unravel it if we ever hope to leave this passageway between life and death and join our wife.First we have to get used to what it feels like being a ghost (similar to what Patrick Swayze experienced in the movie Ghost): we can't directly operate objects, can't even open doors, but we can pass through them, if they aren't parts of Salem's Old Town, where houses were christened in order to keep ghosts away (it's a clever way of creating barriers, restricting where the player can travel). There are several ghost specific skills we can use, including the ability to see (and talk to) other ghosts, telekinetic powers and even teleporting (most of these become availabe at certain points of the game). The best and most useful thing however is the ability to possess others, so we can mildly influence them and - even better - read their minds. There are parts where we can also possess a cat (!), which allows us to to reach otherwise inaccessible areas.There are several cases we can solve throughout the game (these are optional) besides our own and they are worth completing. In these cases we can help other ghosts by uncovering informations about their deaths and these side-quests are responsible for probably the best - both touching and satisfying - moments in the game, The old woman with the hair rollers, seen from the intro, for example is responsible for killing a girl who was partying too loud.Also there are little ghost tales (basically urban legends) known from horror stories. As soon as we find the given number of related objects (for example 7 pieces of boilers) we can listen to the narrated story related to that specific item (boiler -> A Watery Grave, in which a tenant finds out why the water coming from the local boiler turns brown). It's a nice little touch and adds much to the eerie atmosphere.The main story is interesting as well of course (of which I'm not going to tell anything about, for obvious reasons). Besides trying to figure out who the Bell Killer is we can find memories which unfolds the background story of the main characters (Ronan and Julia): we come to know how our hero, who had quite a criminal record, became a police officer and fell in love with Julia, the sister of one of his colleagues. It's like reading through Julia's diary, learning about her feelings towards Ronan, how she struggled with her own mental issues and how she finally said yes, when he asked her to become his wife, despite still not knowing much about Ronan. In the end Murdered: Soul Suspect provides us with a love story as well.As I mentioned before, the gameplay consists of collecting evidences and clues, talking to other people/ghosts (surprisingly the game doesn't punish us for jumping to wrong conclusions) and is occasionally interrupted by action/stealth segments. This is probably what might have confused some people deciding what genre this game is. In these parts we'll have to hide from or dispose of demons who are hunting ghosts like us. They come in 2 varieties: the floor demons (stationary, can be easily avoided) and floating demons. The latter type is far more dangerous, because they can quicky catch and kill us. In order to kill them we have to sneak behind them and press the right combinations of buttons. They can be lured away by possessing nearby crows or we can hide in ghost residue and - as strange as it sounds - inside humans, waiting for the ideal moment to strike. This is the part that received many criticism, because it goes against the regular gameplay of the game. In my opinion though it just gives some thrilling moments to the adventure. If you fail and die, nothing happens, the game lets you retry from the point the demons appeared. The end of the game also contains timed events, you'll have a limited amount of time beating your enemy, something that wasn't common until then, but it does make sense (it would feel odd, running around while irreversible events occur).The game features some amazingly well designed characters, from which I'd like to highlight Joy, the teenager medium whose facial expressions and acting are almost as real and good as of a real actor. Unfortunately the antagonist is not so memorable and it deducts from the overall value at the final confrontation. I personally also didn't find Ronan that interesting, They tried to made him unique with all the tatoos and extravagant clothing, but for me it just made him distant, someone who is hard to identify myself with.The visuals of the game are simply amazing: it uses Unreal Engine 3 and it really shows what this engine is capable of. Eveything looks amazingly beautiful and the eerie, foggy and dark (the whole game plays during nighttime) environment is especially noteworthy. You might want to turn bloom off and pick normal AA (anti-aliasing) instead of the other modes though for better quality (something which I figured out late in the game).


A mixture of past and present day Salem. 
A Screenshot of MURDERED: SOUL SUSPECT™
By: Atisz2




The sound is exceptionally good as well: the environmental audio is remarkable, finally a game where it pays off having a surround sound system. I remember playing Baldur's Gate and Thief the first time in 5.1 and the difference in sound was amazing. It applies to here as well. The noises in the cemetery, the owl hooting really makes you feel like you were there. While the music isn't memorable (actually I don't remember any of it) the characters voices are amazingly good, thanks to the great voice actors. Again, I have to mention Joy, whose voice actress, Cassidy Lehrman does an outstanding job.Overall, Murdered: Soul Suspect creates the impression of a game made with love, by an unknown developer, Airtight Games. It takes you on a memorable adventure, that's certainly not too long (took me 36 hours, but I explored every nook and cranny, something I usually do in good games) and unusual (an adventure game where you have no inventory - you're a ghost after all). Just don't make the mistake of confusing it with an action game (despite the over the shoulder point of view) and you are guaranteed to have a good time. On the other hand 29.99€ might be a bit too much for it (because of its relative shortness), so try to grab it during a sale.PROS+ very beautiful visuals+ good, enjoyable main plot, very good sidequests+ lots of investigating+ emotionally movingCONS- some underdeveloped important characters- might seem odd for lovers of classic adventure gamesRATING8/10

content:
, 2014
												How to say that and not to repeat myself? Well, what a pleasant surprise!This game is a mixture of L.A. Noire, Alan Wake and Heavy Rain, but it took only the good from them. If you are a fan of adventure, stealth, detective and mysterious games, this one is exactly what you look for.This game has great story, quite original plot twist, brilliant and believable characters and more than satisfying ending. Plus, graphics is eye-candy, music and sounds are anxious and the atmosphere is exactly how you would imagine in game like this.I finish this game almost in one turn and I enjoyed that since the beginning till the very end.Unfortunatelly, although this game is long enough for this kind of gameplay, the replayability is probably a no-no as it is common for the most of story-driven games. Even if you are a collector freak, you will probably not get over 12 hours of gameplay. So it is up to you if it is worth of 40 euros . Also, this is just another fast-cooked PC port, and even I haven't faced any technical issues like crashes, glitches and bugs, inability to remap your keys is a crime against humanity in 21st century - I strongly suggest gamepad.Last but not least, this game is not for everyone - if you are an action-oriented player, this is not for you. The pace is slow and it requires focus on details to solve the investigations. For someone like me it is an advantage, for others it can be a disadvantage.But for me, along with Wolfenstein New Order, this is another big "YES" this year.8/10

content:
ber 22, 2016
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is an interesting game. The gameplay mechanics are quite unique but the premise is fairly typical of a story with paranormal themes; a ghost partners up with the living to solve a series of murders. It's not mind-blowing but the way its handled in Murdered works quite well, mainly due to the decent voice acting, the supernatural abilities, and the clever art style that blends reality with a ghostly dimension.The majority of the game is quite fluid and offers little challenge (in a good way) but I have to say that the action sequences feel forced and really bring down the quality of this game. They break the flow of the story and the combat itself is often imprecise and sloppy for what are essentially quick time events. I figure that what happened to Murdered is the same as with Deadly Premonition in which this is something that the publisher demanded of the developers, who reluctantly and haphazardly complied by shoehorning in some janky action sequences in the final hours of development.If you're aiming for 100% completion I suggest collecting everything BEFORE entering the abandoned and decrepit house near the end of the game, as the final sequence will prevent you from collecting any more items within its level and there is no free-roaming afterward. I found this out the hard way, fortunately you can start a new game, collect what you've missed, and the relevant achievements will still unlock even if the collectibles counter has reset to zero.

content:
, 2014
												NOCLIP - The Game is a game about the ghost of a man who attemps to solve the mystery of his own death.Story - 9/10 Fitting uncountable cliches but is very well written. Being a mystery story, I suggest that you avoid spoilers. Atmosphere - 10/10 Very tight and immersive atmosphere.Graphics 9/10 - Looks like it should look in 2014, but a little edgy at some details.Sound 10/10 - I have nothing to complain about. Excellent voice acting.Playability 9/10 - No plotstoppers for me. NOCLIP - The Game has some minor issues, but does not desperately need a patch.Gameplay 2/10 - That is the reason for all the scathing reviews. In NOCLIP - The Game you play as a ghost. You can walk through walls and people - hence the name. You can also possess people to read their thougts, solve some puzzles and get your clues. You can even possess the cats and control them to access some areas. Later you get the ability to teleport.Clues - they are basically just collectibles with an occasional tiny puzzle attached to them. You cannot fail the puzzles, it is always just trial and error. Each investigation just consists of getting all these clues.The game is full of other collectibles. They unlock some background info and additional ghost stories.In attempt to make NOCLIP - The Game a bit challenging, there are fights against demons. You can beat them with a QTE or sneak your way around them. These fights are very repetitive and annoying. And that is basically it. No other gameplay elements. This is not an adventure game, this is just an interactive movie with a boatload of collectibles.At least the level design is very open and nonlinear, partially due to NOCLIP. You can also return to old levels for the collectibles you missed. Sadly, you cannot do this if you complete the game. there is only one save slot and the last savepoint is just after a point of no return, luckily the only one in the game.Conclusion: Do not buy NOCLIP - The Game for the gameplay, buy for the story and the atmosphere. But you can get that as well if you watch a decent walkthrough, which saves you some money. Actually playing it only benefits you with achievements and trading cards.Frankly, To The Moon has the same issue as NOCLIP - The Game: excellent story, but awful and repetitive gameplay, kind of like collectible hunting as well. Yet To The Moon is praised by the press. I understand the bad reviews for NOCLIP - The Game, but I can hardly understand the difference.

												An excellent game! It's short like people have said, but it was satisfying nonetheless! The game is priced correctly for such a short game (~8 hours), at 10 dollars off a normal priced one. It's not something you'll be playing for weeks and I am actually refreshed by that. It's totally story driven and doesn't pretend to be something it's not. The creepy atmosphere always had me wondering what was around the corner (or what was through the next wall!). I tried my best to guess who the killer was and by all accounts I failed at that. If you want to take a break from that FPS and sit down with a good story-driven game, pick this one up! Totally happy with every aspect!

er 4, 2015
												I really wanted to like Murdered: Soul Suspect.  The pun in the name alone gives it a couple of points straight off and I found the story enjoyable, with a well constructed supernatural mystery.  While the plot doesn’t break any new ground, it does make good use of its setting and archetypical characters.  But the game side of things really holds the experience back.  The puzzles are rather boring and quite easy, with most of the challenge being little more than a pixel hunt.  But what really ruined the experience for me were the tedious stealth sections that become longer and more frequent as the game goes on, without any variation to how they play out; they really interrupted an otherwise enjoyable story.Honestly, I wish this was a TV show or movie as it unfortunately doesn’t make for a terribly good video game.

content:
9, 2014
												Absolutely no spoilers in this review.*Edited review now that I have finished the game. It took me about 7.5 hours(played it offline and steam doesn't track offline play) to complete this game and that is including time spent searching for collectibles and finding probably about 85-90% of them. So the complaints that the game is short are pretty valid. Had I skipped the collectibles I probably would have completed it in around 6 hours. That said, I loved every second of this game. The game probably doesn't have a lot of replay value either unless you want to go back through to finish the collectible stories or help any ghosts you passed up on your original playthough (there are only 3-4 of them though I think unfortunately.)So I played this game until 3 am and could barely drag myself away from the keyboard to go to sleep. I am absolutely enthralled by this game and I love it. If the rest of the game is as good as the first 4 hours I've played of it then it will easily be contender for my GOTY.The voice acting is awesome. A lot of the random civilians share the same voice actors but thats a minor thing. I recognize most of the random civilian voice actors from other big budget games. They are all great voice actors. So it seems the devs went with quality over quantity.The visuals are great. I feel like most unreal engine games have models that look like they are made of clay, but this game does not. The ghostly effects are really cool. The way the demons move is absolutely terrifying. Animations are great all around with the possible exception of some lip syncing here and there on the minor characters.The gameplay is fantastic. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ off the demons and being forced to run and hide until they lose your scent is pretty terrifying. Finding collectibles is awesome because once you find all of a set you unlock an audio short story with a piece of art and the stories are really REALLY good so far. Your ghost powers are pretty freaking awesome and the game rewards exploration with collectibles littered all over the levels. Helping other ghosts solve questions regarding their deaths and helping them move on is a great feeling. These little side mission stories are very well written and acted. Finding clues is somewhat similar to but much more enjoyable than it was in LA Noire. Once you find all the clues you do a little solving... puzzle I guess. You get three attempts to solve the puzzle. I don't know what happens if you fail all three attempts yet. But they are generally pretty self explanatory for the most part. It asks a question on the screen and you answer it by selecting the proper clue(s), sometimes in a certain order too. The game actually makes me feel like a ghostly detective. And the story itself is amazing so far. The 63/100 metascore completely baffles me because this game is great and easily one of the best gaming experiences of the year so far.I loved the ending. It wraps everything up in a smart way. I immensely enjoyed this game. If you have any interest in ghost stories or detective mysteries then you will love this game.

content:
r 10, 2016
												Spoiler Alert: The main character dies. The good news is that it happens right at the start of the game. Then the game gets going. However, unlike some God of War clone this isn't a revenge fueled bloodbath of carnage and destruction. There isn't an ocean of "enjoy to destroy" cannon fodder to kill/loot on the way to the final boss. This is a supernatural redemption story in the vein of Ghost or Always with a dash of The Frighteners thrown in for a bit of fun.The bulk of the game will be exploring mutliple crime scenes as you piece together not only the reason for your own murder, but the deaths of many fellow spirits that you encounter along your main quest. In some regards I am reminded of the forensic analyst role from Heavy Rain. Once you have gathered enough clues in the crime scenes you can attempt to discern the next location that your journey takes you. The good news is that, unlike Heavy Rain, this game does not rely on timing based quicktime events to tell the story.However, the only real combat in the game does rely on a tried and true quicktime mechanic. This involves sneaking up behind the occasional demon and performing a stealth kill sequence to banish it. This involves a random quicktime sequence where you a flashed a direction to press along with an appropriate button/key. Not that deep.TL;DR version: If you are a casual gamer that isn't looking to mindlessly button mash your way through a plotless demon horde this is a nice change of pace. If you want some thing procedural like the Kings Quest, Monkey Island or Quantic Dream created games (Indigo Prophecy, Heavy Rain, Beyond) then you'll enjoy the storytelling. It would really fit in nicely with that friend that owns all the Telltale Games titles. Just don't expect a lot of white knuckle fragging.

content:
er 20, 2014



YouTube™ Video: MOB Review: Murdered Soul Suspect 

			Views: 109		

			Murdered Soul Suspect proclaims to be an deactivate game while being a ghost with a rich story. Available on Steam here: http://store.steampowered.com/app/233290/ Join us at Twitter or Facebook if...		

	Murdered: Soul Suspect is a console port detective game with a horroratmosphere that plays more like an interactive movie than a game.  Right off the bat, I was unimpressed by the whopping 30 frames per second that this game runs at, followed shortly by the delayed lineup of subtitles to speech.  	The story was cheesy and doesn't fit with the objective of the game;  starting out by stating that your ultimate goal is to reunite with a lost love,but then not mentioning that relationship for the bulk of the game.  As for the gamebeing a detective game, I would disagree with that and state that it is morelike a hidden object game that requires you search out 'clues' in a predeterminedlocation.  There is no deduction needed; all the clues are in one place, and the game holds your hand by leading you to the next clue and askingrediculously obvious questions.  	The ghosts, while contributing to the atmosphere, did absolutely nothingto add to the game.  For the most part, they were all from the same time period,and were supposed to add a spooky element, but as you are also playing as a ghost, and they disappear when you get close, they were more of a waste of timethan anything else.	I enjoy watching movies, but I buy games in order to, oh I don't know, play a game!  This game played like a cinematic movie, with about 20-25%of the game actual gameplay, and the rest being cinematic movies or dialogue.  Being made to move all across the mapp to get to the next action point does notcount as gameplay;  it is wasting time.	If you are interested in the story of this game, I would recommend goingto YouTube and watching the cinematics strung together rather than buy this game.It treats you, the player, as if you are an idiot that can't figure out anythingfor yourself.  Graphically the game gets by, as well as the level design.  The story is acceptable, but what little gameplay there is designed for thosethat can't deduce anything for themselves.  As a game, I cannot recommend this, if it can even be called a game.For more details, see the linked video review, as this is a basic summary of what I cover in my video. Thanks for your viewership and support for more videos check click here.http://www.youtube.com/user/SocioPyscho

content:
ber 11, 2014
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is a story-driven third-person investigative adventure game with some stealth elements. You take the role of Ronan O'Connor, a former bad boy turned good guy. Everything begins seconds after you've just been thrown from a fourth story window by the game's primary antagonist. The fall almost kills you and the subsequent bullets to the chest finish the job, meaning you play through the entire game as a ghost. Murdered: Soul Suspect plays out like a puzzle game along the lines of L.A. Noire. As a detective Ronan must uncover clues and evidence to track down the Bell Killer. As a ghost in limbo, Ronan has a number of abilities at his disposal. Although he cannot walk through external doors unless they are opened by someone else, once inside a building Ronan can walk through walls and other obstacles. He can fall great distances and not get hurt and he is able to possess people to read their thoughts, influence their actions and peek at their notes or at their computer screens. He can even possess other creatures such as cats to get to hard to reach areas. In addition to the primary plotline being very interesting, the game generally has a very well-designed backdrop, numerous side quests, and superfluous opportunities to discover more about the characters and places featured in the game.Another part of Murdered that works pretty well is the look of the game. When Ronan walks through the streets of Salem, he sees a mixture of how it is now interspersed with what it looked like during the witch trials of the 17th century. The modern Salem is in full color, but the old Salem is in blue and white, and the contrast is striking. The character models and cut scenes are also rendered well. Really, the production values for Murdered are about as good as you’re going to see in a game. The audio multiplies the eerie feeling as well, with some haunting background music. The music, combined with the sound effects works marvellously.I really liked the look, the atmosphere, and the story behind Murdered: Soul Suspect.Although at times the pace of the game can seem a little slow, I have found that Murdered: Soul Suspect to be an enjoyable detective experience – even if it is somewhat simplified detective work.If you’re a fan of mysteries, Murdered: Soul Suspect would be a worthy purchase. Overall 8/10.

r 6, 2014
												Right....first things first, this isnt a title you should get for full price but at least it was only half of that when it came out so I can respct that....but still think its not worth the price unless its on sale. This game has alot of mixed reviews but none great ones, this is because it falls very short on some expectations gameplay-wise because its freaking boring and empty. What isnt boring and empty is the story....I could go so far as to compare this as a story driven game. It can be very much enjoyble if you are not bothered by the "run everywhere and pick everything up" <basicly all the gameplay in a nutshell for this game. Of course there are some "detective" work though its basicly click on the words or events which are related (somehow) or that describe this scene by clicking words like "Panic", "Begging" or "Happy". Its impossible to fail the game, you could get caught by demons, click on all wrong "detective" events and it will just keep giving you chances to try again unles you do it. For my overall opinion I guess I can call this a relaxing game with basic puzzle-solving elements that you can stare at and let your mind go blank, its not a bad game even though its no challange and one time I nearly got stuck possessing a woman walking outside of a gas station. I enjoyed the story and there is a hell of alot of stuff collectables you can pick up and read. Thought its always worth finding all the collectables to unlock a "ghost story" audio, they can be a little cliche but damn they are entertaining to listen in. Oh and one last thing, sometimes its hard finding stuff to click on like clues, the detection on some of these are really small but they are always in the tiny area you search in....though just a heads up for the last thing you do near the end of the game where you only have 3 seconds to find something to click on... clue: "hand" Literally impossible with the 3 seconds you have to click on this tiny ♥♥♥ thing, I had to google it after clicking everywhere. >.<

This game got 1/5 for gameplay 3/5 for story.-The game basically holds your hand through the whole game. There is no punishment for getting anything wrong, and some clues are really stupid. I figured out the run button long ago and the game tried to teach me that after a while.-Gameplay sucks, basically you run around and collect garbage. That is what you do, the only thing that made it even get that score was the story which isn't that great.-Characters are all have the same faces with the same thoughts. Salem had too many people with the same faces that if the killer was one of them, we wouldn't find him.-Demons are just in the way, they didn't make the gameplay any better. It made it worse since the design for the Ghost things to hid in was far away from you, or covered by a wall, or all of them in the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥ room which the demons don't even go in. Ravens that supposed to help you are either far away or the range of their screams doesn't reach the demon that you wana kill. And quick time event is not my idea of a fun game. Wish they didn't created the so called demons because they always delayed me from continuing the storyline. Boring @ss obstacles on the ground, forcing you to go around them because they are demon pits or something.-All the cats have the same color which is black in Salem.-Some places you think it should be possible to teleport to but you can't even though you did it during a story mode.-Some escorting missions are stupid and  HOW the hell would July sneak into the church without the police even noticing her?- there is a Ghost train, so how the hell does an object have a ghost? Why doesn't animals get ghost too, since objects with no soul can have ghosts. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 15, 2016
												I rather enjoyed this game. I enjoyed the story, and the level of player engagement seemed spot-on for this quick, story-driven game.On the other hand; I did encounter some repetitiveness in the dialog after a bit. The puzzle solving felt a little forced, and didn't have alternative scenarios if you chased down the wrong lead.Gameplay: I usually don't like the over-the-shoulder gameplay style. I found it gave me some issue when trying to interact with some objects, but it wasn't too obtrusive. Combat: The enemies were laughable, all you had to do was sneak up behind them and perform an action - a random button/mouseclick which is a direct port over to the button/paddle on the console. I found these enemies to be more of an obsticle than an actual challenge. But I belive this is intended, as to keep the game story focused and not combat driven. I actually salute the developers for remaining story focused and not bogging down the player with ubsurd mechanics or prolonged battles... or health bars for that matter (You're already dead! No health for you!)Collectables & Achievements: Many players have complained that they were unable to go back and complete the collectable achievements, as this has a very linear progression in the story. This will often require a second playthrough, stopping at each location, and clearing the zone to ensure you have collected everything. I kept catching myself thinking in normal gameplay rules, where I would walk around walls and objects. Just remember, you can walk through that. There are still barriers - ghostly walls and santified buildings - that prevent you from passing through everything.Due to a bug in the final fight, I didn't finish the game. After many many attempts, I kept starting the scene in a void zone, where I couldn't escape, or didn't have enough time to complete my objective after I escaped. I have not read of this bug happening to other players. YMMV. I did see alot of weird, creepy stuff in this game, but this is the only only thing I would call buggy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 31, 2015
												You're a cop, you just got killed and you have to investigate your own murder and the case of the serial killer 'The Bell', who's going around killing young women in barbaric ways and slaughtering anyone who gets in his way. You'd think being dead would put something of a cramp on your investigative abilities, but no, it seems all the best cops are the dead ones. Maybe it's because it's late at night, but everybody except you seems to be doing about as much police activity as can be accomplished by standing around rubbing their noses.You run into a teenage medium called Joy who's looking for her missing mom, and she comes in really handy for opening drawers, crossing glowing holes into hell that try and suck Ronan down, and so that Ronan's musing is cut by about 20%. The rest of the time she's a regular whiny teenager you have to play daddy wolf to and pretend you give a pooper about her mom. The game revolves around investigating crime scenes - yours and other people's - talking to the many ghosts in Salem, uncovering lost memories, being the cause of poltergeist activity and posessing people to read their minds.Occasionally to try and make you feel like there's more to the game than prodding at a crime-scene and musing over a cigarette, Demons spawn. Since they just float around on a set path looking for something to kill, and you creep up from behind to kill them, it feels very tacked on and a really crappy attempt at adding any challenge to the game.All in all, the game feels a lot like an interactive horror movie, but it's a GOOD movie, and it feels like worthwhile interaction. Voice acting and character animation of faces is great. Is it worth full-price? That's a personal thing, seeing as it's quite a short game. But if you can get it at a discount, it's definitely a worthwhile way to spend some game-time.Get it if you like: Detective games, Violent murder, Interaction, Creepiness, A good movie, Collecting stuff.Don't get it if you like: Action, Challenge, Long games.7/10

content:
er 7, 2015
												Its still as amazing as ever! I had originally gotten this on my Xbox360 and it was a ton of fun. I saw it on sale during the Halloween 2015 sale and picked it up pretty cheep, considering the original price. I love ghost stories, horror, and killing demons (Diablo). This game has ghosts and demons (which you can choose to avoid or execute, depending on where you are), I found I actually had to execute them to continue at some spots further in.The game begins with Ronan falling through a window and narrating a bit, you also get to learn more about Ronan's (life/ backstory). Considering the fact that he's the main hero and the playable character thats a good thing and its also important.Gameplay is what really got really got me hooked. The town of Salem has areas for doing detective work and its freeroam in the Hub section and the areas (To an extent, its not Final Fantasy or anything, but you do get to explore). The character is always seen in the third person point of view (camera is behind the character).Interactive- You can go around and talk to certain people or listen in on their conversations. You can "investigate" and search for clues- which you'd then use to solve a case or continue on in the story. Collectables are always fun, but can be a pain to collect as they are actually hiding and not always in a typical spot. Cutscenes are interactive! You can usually choose what you want Ronan to say or ask next. Nothing major, but heck its something.Powers, well you get to do a lot of stuff later, but when you just start off you can already possess people and cats (no, seriously). You can also mind read or try to manipulate their thoughts. Story? Spoilers! You die first thing and become a ghost- woot! You're also a detective of the Salem police department. You also have to try to solve your own murder and many others. The game is great and recomendable, but I do have one problem. I had chugging/ lag while on my Xbox and was hoping that'd be fixed on the pc version. That was not the case, and I still have the same annoying chugging/ lag. Its not always while going to a different section of the Hub town, but it does happen a lot in the Hub area. It also happens in other spots, but it rarely happens in places like the graveyard or appartments. So, thats a bit of a bummer, but its still a great game.

content:
y 24, 2016
												Don’t purchase this game if you expect a lot of gameplay. It’s a narrative gaming experience which involves looking around for clues and solving a few simple puzzles. Overall I had fun and when I wanted a break from action-packed games I played Murdered Soul Suspect. Let’s see the pros and cons.Pros:* The game engine: the game was developed using Unreal Engine 3, one of best engines there is. The game never crashed and I was able to play it with maxed settings and 60fps.* Visual: even though the textures aren’t exactly top notch, the motion (especially the particles) and the lightening are great.* Original concept: a detective solving his own murder, passing through walls and talking to other ghosts and mediums. That’s gotta be enticing.Cons:* The “mind reading” feature: I was expecting that every NPC would have unique thoughts and a lot of embarrassing things would be exposed to the players. That’s not what happens. By using the “mind read” in several different NPCs you might end up hearing the exact same thoughts. It appears they are randomly generated and distributed amongst the NPCs. That was definitely a disappointment for me. What’s the point of mind reading if they don’t appear to be real people, but rather randomly generated walking robots that spurs platitudes?* The linearity: it is not possible to leave an area and return to the investigation later. I reckon this is a game based on narrative, but other developers managed to create narrative games without recurring to such strict storytelling (for instance, The Vanishing of Ethan Carter).* Looks like the developers tried too hard to make the game “PG-13”. The NPCs don’t do anything interesting. You never see them doing anything out of the ordinary (unless you find a ghost. Apparently everyone who is naughty ends up dead too). It’s like the whole town of Salem is composed of boy scouts.Other than that the game is fun. I hope to see a sequel that will address the abovementioned flaws. There’s a lot of potential for a series.

content:
, 2016
												This game was fantastic! Yes, it's linear. No, you don't use your ghost powers to do anything especially interesting. Yes, it's basically a supernatural Heavy Rain. But HOLY CRAP is it engaging! The storytelling is 10 times better than David Cage could ever hope to get. You'll think you know where the story is going about 2 hours in, but the way it uses it's red herrings are a twist that, while not mind blowing, is certaintly entertaining and worthwile. It's a noir-tinged, funny, and soaked in a delicious horror atmosphere. If you liked any of Quantic Dream's output, you'll adore this.

												If you like the Blackwell series (and I would heartily reccomend the Blackwell games, I bought them on GOG not Steam), you will likely enjoy this odd beast. I got it in the half price sale and consider it worth the 12 some quid, but I wouldn't reccomend buying it at full price since it's a fairly short game and like most adventure games, low on replayability.This is a good game with some terrible game mechanic design decisions.Pros:Decent storyEnjoyable charactersInteresting ideas explored throughout - enough to overshadow the cons, for my money.Cons:Clatty interface, probably made worse by poor porting to keyboard and mouse. If you use a pad on your PC, you may have no issues.Some really annoying QTE's bracketed with unskippable cutscenes - especially the finale which should have been exciting and ended up being an exercise in impotent rage management.Unskippable end credits that run for 15 mins  - laughably bad decision.

content:
7, 2014
												A very nice take on the point and click adventure games. It has what make those a games great. A great story, with plenty of supernatural, and creepy atmosphere to pull you into it. The acting is fenomenal, you do want to know what happend to this cop, and what will be the end. Sadly like most adventure games, suffers from the same weeknesses, and I am talking about the gameplay, just like other games of this kind, like The Walking Dead, great story but not much gameplay. The same thing happens here, I think that the game would have seen more success as an episodic game. Even with these problems, and it depenps if you consider this issues a weekness, you will enjoy the game. The story is more than capable to drive you  into it. If you still have doubts, wait for a price drop, but don't miss the chance to play it. Too bad  the studio behind the game, Airtight Games is no longer around. Hopefully there will be some sort of sequel, one can hope, after all, hope dies last.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
3, 2014
												For those, like me, who enjoy problem solving games, this was great. It wasn't an intense action game, but simple observation which I enjoyed.Over the course of the game, you can uncover ghost stories as well that aren't even critical to the gameplay, just bonuses. That little mechanic made it feel more immersive considering the story wasn't riding on backtracking or extra digging.Something that stood out for me in the way of dialoge was that everyone who speaks doesn't necessarily talk one at a time. Characters will get cut off and complete their thoughts later in a way that doesn't sound like a script nor rehearsed, with exception to the protagonist's classic-detective style inner monolouges.However, the quick-time controls felt awkward, the game was too short (beat it within twelve hours with a majority of the achievements done), and many "clues" didn't seem to make sense when trying to piece crimescenes together. The promise of unique abilities ("personal strengths becoming abilities) was limited to maybe one or two involving revealing information (which felt closer to the protagonist's job rather than his actual strengths). Even only one other ghost displayed only one unique ability that didn't seem to connect to their character. All of the other abilities you gain belong to the other ghosts you find as well, making the protagonist (and the other ghost with a unique ability) possess very cookie-cutter characteristics.Very little direction is taken towards obstacles you run into like the demons, spiteful cops, or paranoia plaguing the area, thus leaving much more to be desired in character development."Extra" characters aren't even kept within the game for very long, making it feel as though there are only four real characters, and many filler characters.I "did" enjoy the game and do recommend it for those who enjoy dark, investigative, or easy-paced games. Sadly this has little to no replayability and would wait for it to go on sale for $15 or under given it's short story and neglect to several details I mentioned earlier.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 31, 2015
												Get it when it is cheap - it is short and has no replay value beyond collecting things, and you cannot revisit earlier areas after reaching the finale. Overall, it is a pretty decent unfinished business ghost story. It comes equipped with the ex-con cop, lovable scamp sidekick, some plot twists, and posessing cats and people to get to locations your short-range ghost teleport can't reach. The setting was interesting to me, and there were some small jokes in a few levels such as ghost hunters in the cemetary, and a ghost right in front of the camera smiling and waving - that nobody can see.The levels are fairly well designed, although some clues require more accuracy in placement with how close to other clues they are. The demons were interesting at first but quickly became just an annoyance once you near the end of the game. Most areas are once and done, although you do revisit one of the opening areas as part of the plot and can return to areas up until the finale.This is mostly an adventure game - the only notable action sequences are exorcising demons, a single section where you have to deal with a ghost train ( which was pretty neat ), and the finale, and even then they are more or less quick time events. The rest of the game is spent navigating the hub You are unable to change the controls if you use the mouse and keyboard. The game itself doesn't have too many poor performance spots aside from some area transitions and, at least in my case, antialiasing smoke/fog during the opening sequence.The collectables were mostly pointless - the story parts, such as the water tank, rifles, saws, gas tanks, etc. were brief ghost stories - generic, but not poorly written.Overall, I feel the main issue is how short the game is - the entire plot encompasses a single night and will only really take three or four hours at most, and feels like a large chunk of that time was exorcising demons and getting to the next area. If you remove the travel time and scavenger hunt, it was rather short and would probably fit inside two hours.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 31, 2015
												Just wow.This game is such an amazing and unusual experience. A grim detective story with such a vivid characters, voice acting and visual style. This is a great game, which contsits a half of exploration and a half of interactive movie. Exploration, even if limited, is done in really interesting plain - you're a ghost, and thus you can walk through walls, collect and read ghostly notes and hints, learn about places and their stories. You will investigate some simple problems by collecting evidence, looking and listening. The 'movie' part is done nice. The plot is pretty interesting, although so simple. Sometimes I was wondering, when my character will figure out the killer. I mean, I partly looked through it before the game called the killer. However even by figuring out what was happening I've never seen who exactly was the one to blame. And there was yet another unexpected twist. So even if plot is slightly predictable, It's written dam-good. Definitely a movie I liked to play.I loved cats in this game. Just like cats should be in games. Fast, black, agile, a little glitchy. What I didn't like about them was how people react them. Like zero F-s were given that night.I loved that monitor reference in police station. You'll know when you see it. Square Enix, oh you.Now to the downsides:1. This is a game best played with a gamepad. I mean it. It wasn't made to be on PC, it was made to be cross-platform. So even if it supports keyboard+mouse, use a controller, if you have one.2. There is no free roam after you've reached the last checkpoint. The main menu will offer you to continue, but this is merely a last checkpoint, no way to collect something you've left for later.3. Not sure about the reason, but sometimes I've experienced minor graphic glitches while ui showed/hided collected piece of evidence. Might be just my laptop.4. Repetative faces of pedestrians. There's something like two or three models for each gender. Nuff said.5. Really strange placement of hiding spots. Some places have plenty of them, but never needed. The others feature but a few spots, but you will need more if you need them. And some are too far to jump between them.6. Font. Handwriting fonts in games never work as easy-to-read fonts. And this game has tons of handwritten text. Although I managed to read without problems, some might have them.But in the end, I really enjoyed this game. It's certainly a great experience.

content:
y 5, 2016
												Writing this review immediately after finishing the game.Murdered: Soul Suspect is a third person adventure, with quite a few aspects of the horror genre. The game is rather short (Roughly five hours), and the combat in the game is simply sneaking up behind the enemies and pressing a combination of buttons. Although the combat was a bit repetitive, the story itself was rather interesting for me. You play as a recently murdered detective named Ronan, who is has been left behind as a ghost in the mortal world, because he has unfinished business, which won't allow him to join his wife; who has already moved on. In order for Ronan to move on he has to find out the mystery behind his killer. As he is a ghost, he can only tamper with very few things in the mortal world, so with the help of a young girl named Joy, they work together to unravel the mystery between the Bell Killer murders, as well as the identity of the killer.7.5/10

I could not finish a scene because (after researching what I may be doing wrong) I discovered that an event was not triggering properly to let me continue. So I restarted at last checkpoint but the event still did not trigger. The only solution? START THE GAME OVER AGAIN.Sorry guys. This game had great potential and even solid execution in many ways bit if the game does not work FIX IT!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 2, 2016
												I have mixed feelings about Murdered: Soul Suspect. I enjoyed the game with it's very unique style, and the story full of twists and turns, so I do recommend it, but there are a few issues that prevent this from being as good as it could have been.Some of the puzzles require you to choose "most relevant" clues, so you might pick 3 from 10, but it often feels like guesswork. Not guesswork into your character or the story, but guesswork into the developers minds. This can lead to frustration, but doesn't prevent progress.If you miss a clue earlier in the game, even though you can return to that location, the clue isn't always there. A lot of people get stuck on the 15/16 issue with Apartment 4A, for example, and that was the one clue preventing me from a perfect score. The final area does give you a warning message, but once you enter it, you cannot return to a previous save to hunt down any remaining clues. As soon as you enter the area, you are either choosing to give up on side quests, or planning to replay the entire game again. Those issues aside, it's a great experience and worth playing if you can pick it up on sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
4, 2016
												So you are a tattooed loose cannon detective that no one likes and with some chips on your shoulder. You get killed early in the game and you become a ghost with a ghostly cigarette that never extinguishes; The point of the game is to solve your own murder.Has a Quantum Leap feel about it. As well as doing your own stuff you help others solve their murders too so they can 'move on'.The graphics are perfectly fine, quite good actually. Voice acting is good. Dialogue generally pretty decent. The story is just about interesting enough... sometimes its a bit weak. The 'ghost lore' that you are introduced too early on is quite interesting.Some gameplay elements are dull, such as the collectables (are they interesting in any game though?) You do a lot of walking around considering your ethereal. Although the exploration is okay mostly, and you are rewarded usually by a collectable. Collectables are all blocks of text that I didn't bother reading - Some collectables actually give you a spooky short story not related to the main game but related to the town it's set it in, which are actually quite good to listen to. The story about a man complaining his shower water was a brown colour to his landlord for months, when they eventually find a rotting body in the water tank was my favourite.The exciting (or what should be exciting) gameplay elements are not used enough or not done that well. For example, you can possess cats, which allows you to get into different areas but this is presented to the player on a plate - As in the area you need to get to is ahead and here is a cat purrfectly placed next to it so you can just possess it and move on.... Developers could have expanded this and purrrhaps forced the player to think for themselves a bit and actually go find a cat.The detective investigations.... I can only compare it to LA Noire as its similar but its no where near done as well. Clues are obvious and all you are doing is walking around pressing a button on every clue - The game even tells you there are 7 clues or 8 clues so you know when you are finished and can conclude the investigation, unlike LA Noire where you may have overlooked a vital clue and actually ♥♥♥♥ up the investigation entirely - So there is no risk for the play basically - So investigations are boring and are purely there as plot lines.Then there are some fun gameplay elements. Walking through walls is brilliantly done. Hiding inside people, listening to their thoughts (although many NPC's only have 2 thoughts in their head at any one time) poltergeist-ing TV's and radios.Banishing demons is quite a nice break from the normal walking around too - Although its just a quicktime button press (which you get ample time to do) it at least slows you down and makes you think a little bit about how to progress.So even though it doesn't challenge the player at all, or break any gaming barriers down I'd still recommend it to anyone who likes a story driven game with a mildly disappointing ending.

content:
, 2016
												This is really a different type of game unlike any I have played before.  Basically you go around collecting items (alot of optional items) to get stories to read and unlock.  Often times you have to find clues and piece them together so the evidence tells a story helping you in your search for the serial killer.  While the game looks pretty decent graphically, there are times where things just fell off.  For example the killer could have just murdered someone in the town yet some of the peoples mood in the town does not reflect that.  There are times when some townspeople say the same exact thing by the same voice actor or actress.  One time near the end of the game I read this old ladies mind and had the voice of a teenage girl.  There are somel moments in the game where you have to be stealthy to avoid demons and you do have the option of killing them .   As the game progressed I was more interested in how the story would develop and there was a nice plot twist towards the end.   Its a fairly short game which was the main reason I played this game after reading alot of less than positive reviews.  I'll give the game 5/10  and recommend buying it if you can get it really cheap.

												Although there are many issues with this game, I really do recomend it. It's not great, but it is worth playing.The main problem of the game is that it feels really underdeveloped.The story is short, I think you can finish it in around 5 hours if you rush through the game and skip all the collectibles.There are some pretty useless mechanics included, like, for example, reading people thoughts. At first I was quite excited that I can possess pretty much any NPC and read its mind, but I quickly discovered that most of the thoughts are repeating itself and they are absolutely useless.There are enemies in this game. One kind of enemy to be exact. Demons are annoying addition that doesn't introduce anything to the game except from dull idea of banishing them. You just walk behind a demon, hold R to start banishing and then press mouse button + direction key that pops up on screen. It's excatly as exciting as it seems. Not at all. No thrill, no fear, not even a startle from some jumpscare. They appear, you banish and move on. They could remove them completely from the game as they pose no threat at all and only thing that they manage to achieve is to annoy you.Controls are pretty bad. Especially menu controls. You can use mouse only to point the option you want, to select it you have to use your keyboard.Many technical problems, bugs. Sometimes gamebreaking.The game is faaar to easy.What I enjoyed about the game is the story itself. However short it is, it was really entertaining for me. I love the atmosphere of Salem. Conducting the investigation even though it could be more complex. That's what basically makes the game worth playing for me: the story and the world presented in it. I do recomend the game, however not for its full price. If you see it on some good sale go for it, but else just wait for the price to go down.

content:
y 29, 2016
												As the game begins we find Ronan exploding out of a shattered 4th story window after a confrontation with a shadowy figure.  He awakens to find himself temporarily disembodied but that state soon becomes permanent upon the arrival of the Bell Witch Killer.  Shot 7 times with his own gun, Ronan must now solve the mystery of his own murder and in the process uncover dark secrets that have haunted Salem for centuries.Quite a build up eh?It is and it's worthy of it.  The story is intriguing with twists, turns and dead ends to thrill any devotee of the mystery genre.  Add in a tastefully done horror component supported by an eerie backdrop of a dark and gloomy Salem complete with lost souls, haunted houses, and frightful demons.The game is gorgeous even on my creaky old gaming laptop ( circa 2008 ) and the controls simple.  You're led on a path similar to the Call of Duty campaign modes on the hunt for clues to your own murder.  On the way you'll find ample opportunity to complete side quests but be warned if like me you seek to earn all of the Steam achievements you must be methodical in your approach.  For me it took 2 playthroughs as there is no quicksave nor any way to go back once you've completed the final chapter of the game. It's a casual game but it can be maddening at times.  For one, you have no onscreen map nor any way to mark your progress toward achievements.  Meaning you'll spend a lot of time running in circles to find the way forward and backtracking for that one elusive clue.Then there's the demons.  I understand that a game in the horror genre has to have some kind of threat but they're all over the place.  It breaks the flow of the narrative and it's jarring to go from a casual detective story to a flurry of button mashing every 10 minutes.  Still, even with the more "gamey" aspects, it's still more ghost story than game which explains some of its mechanical shortcomings.  My first playthrough was simply for the sake of taking it all in.  The second was purely for my own desire to see everything and in the process earn every Steam achievement.All tolled I've spent a bit over 30 hours and enjoyed every minute of it.

												An amazing game if you know what your paying for..It's not a 3rd person adventure game like Assassin's Creed or Sleeping DogsIf you go into the game realizing that it's a new take on the old point and click adventure games where you solve puzzles and experience a narrative, then your much more likely to enjoy yourself.That being said, Murdered: Soul Suspect, does a few things really well.- Great Characters, they're very well done and you'll find yourself really caring about what happens to them.- Voice work is top notch- Extra items / Side Cases come with their own ghost stories that will have you scouring the area to make sure you collect all of them.- Setting is dark and creepy yet it feels alive thanks to all the townspeople spread throughout salemAs with any game though there are negatives of course- The demonic / exorcism dynamic of combat feels more like an afterthought meant to draw in more gamers than a mechanic that was developed to really add depth to the gameplay.- While the voicework itself is excellent.. the characters lip syncing is not as great.  Not terrible, but it's something you'll definitely pick up on from time to time.- Even though there are plenty of citizens walking about and interacting with the enviroment; there is a lot of dialogue that's used on multiple people.  Also once you decide to read their thoughts and the voiceover starts; you have to wait for it to finish before  you can listen to the next or disposses them.If you see it on sale definitely pick it up.  I managed to find this on Gamer's Gate for 13.99

content:
ber 21, 2014
												First things first: the game is really short. You can get 100% without any guides in about 10 hours, even less if you just rush the main story. Yet the game (or should I say "the movie"?) is also fun and well made. Not an AAA-title, but it's definitely a game I sincerely enjoyed.I liked the dark setting, the overall style and visuals and all the little details here and there. Also the detective story is not bad. The first half of the game is the best because you don't really understand what is going on. After that the rough outline of the story becomes more and more clear which made it a bit less interesting for me. This game may also be for you if you like to just wander and see all what there is to see in the world (though it's definitely not Skyrim).Also it is an easy game. You can't fail even if you try really hard! The gameplay is linear as a stick, the investigations can be brute forced (although they are not difficult anyway) and there no story choices to make at all, even cosmetic ones. Action sequences (the demons) become a chore rather quick. Overall it was not a problem since I played not for challenge but rather for relaxation.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
3, 2014
												For those, like me, who enjoy problem solving games, this was great. It wasn't an intense action game, but simple observation which I enjoyed.Over the course of the game, you can uncover ghost stories as well that aren't even critical to the gameplay, just bonuses. That little mechanic made it feel more immersive considering the story wasn't riding on backtracking or extra digging.Something that stood out for me in the way of dialoge was that everyone who speaks doesn't necessarily talk one at a time. Characters will get cut off and complete their thoughts later in a way that doesn't sound like a script nor rehearsed, with exception to the protagonist's classic-detective style inner monolouges.However, the quick-time controls felt awkward, the game was too short (beat it within twelve hours with a majority of the achievements done), and many "clues" didn't seem to make sense when trying to piece crimescenes together. The promise of unique abilities ("personal strengths becoming abilities) was limited to maybe one or two involving revealing information (which felt closer to the protagonist's job rather than his actual strengths). Even only one other ghost displayed only one unique ability that didn't seem to connect to their character. All of the other abilities you gain belong to the other ghosts you find as well, making the protagonist (and the other ghost with a unique ability) possess very cookie-cutter characteristics.Very little direction is taken towards obstacles you run into like the demons, spiteful cops, or paranoia plaguing the area, thus leaving much more to be desired in character development."Extra" characters aren't even kept within the game for very long, making it feel as though there are only four real characters, and many filler characters.I "did" enjoy the game and do recommend it for those who enjoy dark, investigative, or easy-paced games. Sadly this has little to no replayability and would wait for it to go on sale for $15 or under given it's short story and neglect to several details I mentioned earlier.

content:
er 23, 2014
												What does it feel like to be staring down at your own dead body, lying helplessly in the street? To see police agents discussing what might have happened to you, without being able to tell them? The first thing you might notice is that being a ghost actually renders you painfully limited in your ability to interact with the world. Thankfully, there are advantages as well. And, as you will soon discover - what you can't do, someone else might be willing to do for you.I imagine some people are holding off on buying this game due to the moderate-to-bad reviews it has received. I'd like to argue differently. It is by no means perfect - I ran into a few bugs and the game even crashed on me in the final chapter. I was also not happy about not being able to change the key bindings. But the story and its two main characters made it easy to overlook these issues. A unique idea for a video game - not perfectly executed, but more than well enough to warrant a playthrough.

content:
2, 2014
												*Review edited for release... still nothing but good things to say about it!*There is tons more I could say about this game and how much I enjoy it than what is in this review, so free to message me on Steam if you have any questions. I highly recommend this game if you're looking for something new in your roguelike/dungeon-crawling experiences... it was *the* most polished Early Access Alpha I had ever played, and is even better now that it is released.GraphicsVery nice and consistently styled, even in the character screen. The choice in what a friend of mine put as "playful yet macabre" is spot-on, and a very nice change of pace from other roguelikes (not that those are bad, but FMR is a unique breath of fresh air).SoundEverything from the music to the effects is lovely and fitting to the visual theme. Moody, atmospheric, ethereal, magical, mysterious, spooky... that is what comes to mind while playing and it's a joy to listen to! Some of the tracks really remind me of the greatness that was the soundtrack for Psychonauts (my favorite game of all-time).ControlsSmooth and intuitive when using the keyboard+mouse (controls are customizeable as well, so you can play however you want). I don't play games this twitch-reliant with a controller, but feedback about it in general has been very positive.GameplayThe randomization, pin/item/relic/Loa/leveling "build" system works really well but isn't so random that you're screwed if you get bad drops. Since your core setup is however you want to do it (and very easy to experiment with), there is enough consistency to do theorycraft and gameplay mastery... a *very* nice change from the *completely* random roguelikes. I love randomization, but it's nice to have something to play that is a good mix of random and static.The variety in gameplay is great, giving a pleasurable dose of strategic fighting and completely chaotic shmup-style play. Because FMR has this kind of variety, you never really get sick of it. Just when you're tired of one style, you roll a level that's totally different. I'm over 125 hours into it as of this writing, and I'm still not even close to be tired of any of it.Progression is incredibly satisfying, but I'll speak more to that below.GenreWhile the game is most commonly categorized as a roguelike (or rogue-lite), I see it as a mix of roguelike, bullet-hell/shmup, and dungeon-crawler. It's a fantastic mix, and adds a ton to the scale and variety of traditional roguelikes.DifficultySome may find their intital play sessions to be too easy, but the difficulty curve is not even remotely a cakewalk later on. If you feel it's too easy, just keep playing... later difficulties/quests are *much* harder and varied. You'll soon find yourself cursing (joyfully) at failed runs. Because of this, I do *not* consider this game a rogue-lite... if anything, it's just one that isn't ultra hardcore in the start and eases you into the insanity. A perfect game to introduce someone to the genre, but has enough hardcore craziness to keep even the most experienced of players happy.Difficulty in this game is where the real progression and satisfaction resides. Leveling/etc. is a nice way to ease the player into the various mechanics of the game, but the meat of it all is in the variety of difficulties you unlock. Don't expect to be carrot-and-sticked the entire time with pointless leveling and unlocks... instead, expect to get your satisfaction from mastering incredibly difficult situations that (in the later difficulties especially) require perfected playing skills.ContentLevel modifiers, difficulties, level palletes, mission objectives, mobs (and their variations), bosses, items, Loas, etc. all have a great amount of variety already, and further post-release patches are planned which is just icing on the already delicious cake. I was already very happy with the content amount in the early alpha, and that has far more than doubled between then and release. Because of the amount there is, and because of how it's sectioned out between the different quests, you always have a ton of choice depending on your mood and a helluva lot to experience, master, and be surprised by.A quick note: I am in the credits for the game for the QA work I was voluntarily doing (a nice surprise, so thank you devs!). I am not a developer or paid contractor for this game and have no bias in that regards... I just love testing, and the community was silent during a time when they really needed feedback so I stepped up. My review would be exactly the same even if I hadn't done testing for it.

 A solid crime and investagative experience   This game is not for everyone, but delivers a fascinating investigative thriller The story and approach is very unique and anyone who has an interest in the Salem witch trials and history will like this game.  I found it interesting as I have read the Crucible and enjoyed wandering through Salem.It's not very scary but does have an eerie atmosphere at times.The graphics are good and does help the player to feel immersed in the game and story. Investigating can feel repetitive at times but does continue the story and create more questions for the player. content:
ry 22, 2015
												Murdered is an interesting yet flawed game. It has some good ideas but fails to execute them in a coherent fashion. Like all games created by numerous development houses spread across the globe it lacks a singular vision. Triple A games need painstaking pre production in order to succeed. Apparently the Ghost theme was pitched at Airtight by one of Square's creative directors.The game isn’t unholy bad. It runs well on my basic PC. The voice work and plentiful cutscenes flesh out the story. Which is an standard detective yawn with Salem trial overtones. There’s a whole host of collectables which unlock side story narratives. These are a strong point of the game and pad out what would be a rather limited experience.There is one striking feature / bug that the game has. Once you finish the main story arc, you cannot go back into the town and complete / solve any of the side missions you may have missed without starting a brand new game. This soured my overall opinion of the title. A shocking oversight that could have been fixed by a small patch. Unfortunately this will never happen as Square shuttered Airtight soon after the release of the game.Its a pity Airtight aren't around to make a follow up. I enjoy a good adventure story and for the most part Murdered delivers.

content:
ry 28, 2015
												I just finished this game yesterday and it was pretty much everything I expected. It was story rich with some nice cut scenes, interesting plot twist and wasn't very difficult. Perfect since I was sick in bed all week with the fever, and this is the perfect game to play when you're not completely there. If you're looking for anything of a challenge though this is definitely not the game for you. There are also no choices that you can make that influence the game; so no replayability.I thought I would finish all side quests since I had read that they only add about 10 minutes extra per side quest. Actually now that I think about it I did finish all the sidequests, I just didn't find all the items that tell you some extra stories from salem. Unfortunately the game has a sort of battle system in the game with demons that look for you and try to eat your soul or something like that. Personally I hated these areas of the game the most, it didn't feel scary or add anything to the game, it actually just seemed really annoying, so I always rushed through the demon areas executing them as fast as possible (which just means walk behind them and press the execute command that was on screen). For me they could have just left the demons out and I would've enjoyed the game more. Or they could've made it hella scary and borrowed the run and hide system from "Amnesia: The Dark Descent". Oh well there aren't that many demon areas so it was ok.Conclusion: It's a fun, easy, detective game that lasts about 6 hours  (10+ hours if you want to 100% the game) filled with fun cut scenes and an interesting storyline. However if I look at the price this game is goin for in the steam store (30 euros) I can't recommend you get the game for that price even though I do understand why they market it at that price. If this is the type of game you love it's probably worth it since the cut scenes are well done and yeah theres enough of salem to discover/investigate. But let's be honest, once you finish this game you will never pick it up again, so you're probably better off waiting for a sale. I paid 6 euros for this and other games (Square Enix 2 humble bundle) and I think games are worth it as long as you get 1 hour per euro. This game fits that rule for me so I give it 4 stars out of 5. If you paid more than 10 euros for this game however, I can imagine feeling screwed, so be smart and wait for it to be cheaper than 10 euros or get it in the humble bundle now! while you still can :)

content:
ry 10, 2015
												As a HUGE adventure fan that almost always prefers a classic 2D click'n'point adventure, Murdered: Soul suspect is a breath of fresh air to everything the adventure genre has to offer. The graphics are just amazing, and thanks to the Unreal engine, the game runs smooth as butther with everything maxed out.V-sync limits the game to 30FPS, but you can switch that off and just enable V-sync in your GPU options (Catalyst Control or Nvidia center) which gives you all the smooth awesomeness of 60FPS.The story of this game is brilliant, and the spooky atmosphere just adds to the overall setting of the game. The way you interact with your surrounding and figure out the clues is great, but I was hoping getting stuff wrong would give you a penalty of some kind... Then again, it is an adventure game and most of them are very linear.There is no combat apart from banishing demons witch can be really difficult at some parts but nothing an average gamer can't figure out.I was afraid that the ending will be a dissapointment compared to the massive build up of the story (and the bodies murdered) but the game really delivered. After YEARS of trying to find something different and new in the adventure game genre, Murdered: Soul suspect finally brings tons of new mechanics, great voice acting, an amazing story and a beautiful engine to finally burst life into a slumbered genre.Hats off to the devs and the writters.
