content:
, 2014
												A very unusual detective story where you try to solve your own murder. The gameplay isn't very strong (they could've done so much with what they had with some effort) but the story itself is quite. Not wasting time trying to get 100% completion, I didn't feel any part of the game overstayed its welcome or that I was grinding. Some of the investigations seemed to require answers that were contradictory to what was asked though, which was the biggest gripe I had besides the final confrontation which was very much a trial-and-error thing compared to the rest of the game.Can't really say I recommend this at full price as it's a bit fiddly around the edges that likely won't be fixed post-release with patches, but if you can get it for 20€ or less, I can recommend it for anyone who wants more a story than a game (it's not completely devoid of being a game like Dear Esther tho).So there. Thumbs waving up here. Liked it. Probably around 4-6 hours long for those who get things right fast and just ignore the side stuff completely, 10+ hours for those who try to get 100% without guides maybe.

WELCOME TO SALEM, THE CITY OF THE UNEXPECTEDI had high expectations for this game, and even though it disappointing me for being kind of linear to play, actually the mystery involved in the game, and the way the narrate it, its quite good and it will make you wish to finish it till the truth is discovered. Pros: - Amazing plot.- Very cool narrative.- Ghosts stories about how they died, its quite human and realistic. A pleasure to read.- Good voice actors.- Music its ok, but I think it should been better.- The ending, if you are clever maybe you will figure out at some point of the game who is the culprit. But when you discovered the truth, there is some shocking stuff you will not foreseen. Cons:- The game its kind of linear, it gets easy sometimes. - The game have some bugs, so far I experienced the follow bugs:   * The game froze out of the blue sometimes.   * Sometimes the bots get stuck when they are supposed to move.   * The game closes by itself, just because. - _-Luckily, this bugs happens just rarely, but still, a game which was released a year ago, should've all of this already fixed.8/10, I had a lot of fun with this game. but I recommend to buy it on a sale.

y 2, 2016
												Enjoyable story-driven murder mystery. Not really exceptional in any way, but the story and mechanics are interesting. You play a detective who becomes a ghost and thus can walk through walls and do other ghostly stuff while investigating a series of murders. While item collection is heavily featured, it doesn't seem simply shoehorned in to increase the game's length. Each item you collect contributes in some way to the story background/context. The only part that got repetitive and predictable was the demon mechanic: I felt it only interrupted your progress while you dealt with them essentially the same way in every level. Recommended for its enjoyable story and original mechanics.

content:
y 2, 2016
												I have mixed feelings about Murdered: Soul Suspect. I enjoyed the game with it's very unique style, and the story full of twists and turns, so I do recommend it, but there are a few issues that prevent this from being as good as it could have been.Some of the puzzles require you to choose "most relevant" clues, so you might pick 3 from 10, but it often feels like guesswork. Not guesswork into your character or the story, but guesswork into the developers minds. This can lead to frustration, but doesn't prevent progress.If you miss a clue earlier in the game, even though you can return to that location, the clue isn't always there. A lot of people get stuck on the 15/16 issue with Apartment 4A, for example, and that was the one clue preventing me from a perfect score. The final area does give you a warning message, but once you enter it, you cannot return to a previous save to hunt down any remaining clues. As soon as you enter the area, you are either choosing to give up on side quests, or planning to replay the entire game again. Those issues aside, it's a great experience and worth playing if you can pick it up on sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
19, 2015
												This is actually quite a fresh and intersting idea for a game. You play a cop who gets killed by the serial killer he is investigating only for him to become a ghost. Even worse for him he can't move on until he finds out who the serial killer is and then stop him. Playing a ghost is actually quite fun as you can walk through walls and objects as well as possess living characters and listen to their thoughts and influence them. The gameplay is a bit lacking though as most of the game involves investigating by searching for clues and then concluding the investigation by picking the most important clues thus moving the story along. The only enemies you encounter are demons which are easily dispatched by sneaking up behind them and killing them and the encounters with them are too few and far between to be a problem. The biggest dissappointment with this game is that they could have done so much more with the ghost stuff to make the gameplay better.The Good:-Interesting idea for a game and it works quite well.-Decent story which is the games main strength. Also the setting of Salem is brilliant and the atmosphere is great.-Playing as a ghost is quite fun even if they could have done so much more with it.The Bad:-Game is really easy and doesn't provide much in the way of a challenge.- Pretty short and padded out with having loads of collectibles.Overall this is a decent game if not perfect.Worth picking up on sale.

												Just finished the game and I really enjoyed it. While it doesn't take long to play it through (I needed 8 hours and I took my time) it was fun while it lasted. I am not sure about the replay value, though. The game heavily relies on its thick atmosphere and the story twists to drive you along and I imagine it will be less fun the second time around. If you don't care for pages after pages of story or lots of cut scenes or do expect a certain amount of fighting in your games you should skip this one, though. There are a few "fight" scenes but you have to solve them through misdirection and stealth. No open combat. Still, if you do enoy a good story and an atmospheric game you should give this one a try. I recommend playing it at night or in a darkened room - both for the atmosphere and to see all the details on the screen. You should also take the time and gather as many clues as possible, especially for the small side quests. The stories are delightfully spooky.

												Murdered: Soul Suspect is a great story. It's a mediocre game but I enjoyed the story so much I have to recommend this.It has great atmosphere, very nice graphics and a very appealing main story. It's a unique take on detective stories with a supernatural flavor. The investigations are easy but the findings are not trivial and kept adding real new information throughout the game. Only when I was very close to the end of the game was I able to figure all the pieces, meaning the game keeps the tension very well.However, Murdered: Soul Suspect also has linear progression, too trivial investigations, many collectibles which I did not find interesting and sort of bland side investigations and strange stealth combat.For me the game really picked up when I stopped trying to collect everything and doing every side mission. So, I recommend this game with a suggestion to stick with the main story.

content:
, 2015
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is a different kind of game, but that doesn't mean its a bad game.  I never got around to playing it when it came out, money reasons mostly, but I was able to play it through a friend's library.  The game is based in Salem and follows the story of a cop who dies at the very start of the game (not a spoiler).  The "combat" in the game is mostly stealth based, there are demons, who you have to sneak up on to kill, and if they spot you, you must flee until they resume their normal patrols, but asides from that there is no real combat to speak of.  That is not a bad thing though, as the story is really nice and has a few pretty good twists in it.  The sounds in the game are really nice, and the screech that is made when demons pops up could catch you off guard, I know it did to me a few times.  There are papers, and different things to collect throughout the game, including area specific items that unlock hidden ghost stories to flesh out the town even more.  I played with my xbox one controller so I don't know how good or well the key binding is, but the controls were really nice.  I was actually quite surprised by this game, as I wasn't expecting the good story that I got.  This is not a game for everyone as there is not a whole lot to speak of for combat.  I really enjoyed the story, the somewhat unique combat system and the atmosphere.  Not much in the way of replay value, as I am not sure if there is a difficulty option, unless you wanted to 100% it there is not a whole lot of reasons to replay it.  8/10

ry 28, 2015
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is engaging and enjoyable.  The atmosphere and graphics are great.  You explore Salem and 'ghost Salem' as a ghost and as a detective, solving your case and many side cases along the way.  Ghost Salem physically exists for ghosts, as a barrier which prevents you from accessing areas of Salem too easily and as a mode of access to collectables in areas you wouldn't have access to in normal Salem e.g. ghost stairs.There is a lot to engage with: collectables (too many, in my opinion), stories to unlock, ghosts hanging around (they say the best things in the graveyard).  It does get repetative and there isn't a challange.  The game is easy to beat but there's still a small amount of action such as dealing with demons.  I find the game satisfactory for entertaining, easy gameplay but I wouldn't pay $30 for it.  Maybe if it was more challanging, everything down to the puzzles are simple.

9, 2014
												During my time with Murdered: Soul Suspect, it felt like a spark of unique features in the sea of games that feel like we are recycling the same ideas and concepts over and over. It was definitely an interesting title combining LA Noire's use of interacting with objects and no hand holding while you piece the scene together and choose the correct action from a list that is revealed once you reveal parts of what happened. However I would have liked to see more of a choice in how you progress making some choices lead you down the wrong path and some that if you dig deep enough into the scene it could progress you closer to the killer. To a trained eye a lot of the story becomes easy to pick up but still has some twists like any good murder mystery would. In all I enjoyed my time with the story and ghost/investigation mechanics even if it felt a little short (I think an extra 1-2 hours would have been about perfect for time spent in the game).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 29, 2014
Short version:+ Amazing detective story + Background stories of characters to uncover+ Possess cats and never ending cigarette+ No need to use doors, just walk through walls- Obviously made for consoles-- Boring and linear gameplay-- No action, apart from demons= 6.5/10Long version:First of all, this game has a Metascore of 59/100 and I can kind of understand why. This is not about the story or the characters, but mainly because of the gameplay.WARNING: minor spoilers (not really spoilers, but just in case, you know). Marked them.Story: The story is simply ah-ma-zing. In my opinion, it’s a great murder mystery in which you have to solve your own death (and prevent others from dying too). The whole ghost-idea is greatly elaborated in the story and makes the whole thing quite original: you’re not the usual cop who has to solve the usual murder mystery. The game has some great (and by that I mean unexpected and mind-blowing) plot twists. And, honestly, I didn’t expect the actual murderer to be the murderer, if you know what I mean.Characters: I LOVE how the characters’ stories become clear throughout the game. Most of the characters’ stories are quite vague when you start the game, but as you progress and collect artifacts, you learn more about each one of them. It made me want to keep playing, not only to know who my killer was, but also to know more about other people’s lives and deaths (and Ronan’s tattoos, for example). The side quests are nice additions to the story; they aren’t very long, but quite interesting, too. The main characters aren't really stereotypes, in my opinion. For example, the fact that Ronan was a gangster himself while he was young, doesn’t make him the stereotype cop (not really sure if spoiler, but marked just in case). It makes the game much more interesting than your usual detective story. The side characters, on the other hand, are much more flat and typical.Gameplay: Not great. Even boring, after a while. You walk around in Salem, investigate surroundings to find clues, possess people (and cats!), hide from and defeat demons, poltergeist stuff, and, well, that’s about it. It’s the same thing over and over again, for the maximum of 15 hours of gameplay the game has to offer (one playthrough). No real puzzles, just looking around and finding things. No real action, I believe there’s a maximum of 20 demons to defeat throughout the game. The combat is boring: you have to sneak up to them and kill them with nothing but your bare hands. You have no defense apart from some hiding spots. The demons are in my opinion unnecessary and only a burden to the game. The game’s pretty linear, too. You have no choice but to follow the storyline. Between cutscenes, you can walk around freely in Salem and the areas you’ve already visited throughout the story.Also, it’s obvious this is a game made for consoles, not for pc. I mean, “Press START”? You’re joking, right? You’re unable to change the controls, so if you’re playing with an AZERTY-keyboard, you’ll have to change the language settings of your pc. I really recommend playing this with a controller, if you have one: it suits the overall gameplay much better.Other: Great graphics. The creepy music fits the atmosphere and story perfectly. Good voice acting. Achievements are relatively easy to obtain, apart from some artifacts. Also, DO NOT ENTER THE MUSEUM IN THE END OF THE GAME before you’ve collected all artifacts! You won’t be able to return, or play the whole game from the start to collect the missing ones.Conclusion: I was doubting whether I would go for recommended or not, since the gameplay is such a disappointment. I did go for recommended, because I haven’t seen such a great and original detective story in all my life.I wouldn’t recommend buying this game if it’s not on sale: €30 ($37.5?) is way too pricey in my opinion. Like detectives, murder mysteries and story-driven games? I guess you can give this a shot. Want action, adventure and shooting? Not the right game for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
6, 2015
												To be honest, I feel that this game got a lot more flack than was deserved. Is it perfect? No, but I think the criticisms were a bit extreme. Mind you, most of the criticisms I read were during the time that it was initially released and some of it had to do with bugs.I'm guessing that by the time I bought the game (4 months after release) all those bugs were fixed because I didn't really have any of the issues that they were talking about. There were times, however, I noticed that the narration would cut out. This happened in maybe 3-5 different cutscenes were there was just no sound at all - the only way I knew what was supposed to have been said during the scene was because I always have subtitles on.I think what hurt the game more than anything else was the story. It was okay, but I feel that it could have been better - more developed maybe. Also I feel like the characters were poorly written.I say this because I felt no emotion towards any of them whatsover. The wife was annoying, and there were too many random collectibles of her memories with him - I'm guessing like finding pages of her diary or something scattered around. I felt myself annoyed with all of these and couldn't care less about her or their relationship.The friendship or, partnership I guess, between Ronan and Joy felt really shallow. Since Joy is the character Ronan interacts with the most throughout the game, I was hoping for more development in their friendship.  Also the way Joy treated Ronan after he saves her from The Bell Killer is ridiculous. I'm not expecting her to want to help him right away but it was a bit much imho I couldn't even find myself caring about Ronan himself. None of the characters in the game were developed enough for me to root for them or care about them in anyway. Also I felt it was strange that all the events in the entire game takes place in one night. Why on earth was that one couple getting married in the middle of the night / wee hours of the morning? The demons in the game were laughable. It felt like it was just thrown in at the last minute to give the game some kind of combat in it. They should have either given the combat more diversity or taken the demons out completely, in my opinion. I didn't play the game with combat in mind so I wouldn't have cared if there was no combat in this game. There are perfectly good Adventure Mystery games with absolutely no combat in it (the majority of Sherlock Holmes titles for example).With all that negative out of the way now for the positives: I appreciate the game trying to do something different. I'm a big fan of Adventure Mystery type games and one that approaches it from the perspective of a ghost is innovative and interesting. I enjoyed walking through walls and possessing adorable felines, as well as the people around town.It would have been great if they expanded a bit more on this - more animals to possess, control over individuals in town like how Abigail was able to control humans to do her killings  , as well as being able to poltergeist more items.To sum up my review, I would recommend people to give the game a go. It's enjoyable and fun and I definitely don't think it deserved 59 on metacritic. I would rate it more of a 6/10. It's worth a play through to get to play and experience something different. The mystery is also relatively engaging.I just wouldn't get this game at full price - wait for a sale. I was able to scoop it up during one for 4.99.

content:
y 28, 2016
												I just finished this game an hour ago.  I'm not sure why people feels the need to write a review without finishing the game, if I had judged the game after an hour of playing it I would have turned it down too, but after an hour you're not attached to anything, if you're looking for instant gratification in a detective game, you should have never even installed it.At first the fact that its a console port nearly turned me off to it but I trudged on and found that its not all that bad.  I would recommend the game for those who likes the detective style game.PROS------------------------------* Well made storyline* Wealth of history about Salem during the Salem Witch Trials* Ronin and Joy are pretty memorable characters* Pretty original gameplay elements, such as modern infrastructure infusing with past infrastructure.* Great sudden turn of events often* Fair amount of collectibles to learn about side missions and such* Cinematics and voice acting are very well put togetherCONS------------------------------* Console port, you can't rebind keys which leads to mistakes sometimes, especially during QT events* Quick time events are annoying when you're trying to do them with a keyboard/mouse* Some glitches, but nothing game breaking* Not well optimized for PC, often stutters a little

content:
, 2015
												I can see how this game might disappoint others, as there is so much more it could do as a survival horror and as a detective game, but for what it is, I think this is a brilliant game, and there are enough items and secrets to find to give it replay value. I guess because of the different path options of another certain "poltergeist simulator" if you like i.e. Beyond Two Souls it is often a shame when I play games like this now and there aren't multiple endings (even Silent Hill 2 had different endings on replays), but I guess we are a little spoilt, and this isn't trying to be a David Chase or a Deus Ex game. The idea itself was so novel and appealing I knew I had to grab this eventually, it reminded me of the basic premise of the old PS2 game Shadow of Memories in which you travel back in time to solve your own murder. In this moody, supernatural almost LA Noire style of setting I knew I couldn't resist. It wasn't until I played it I realised it's all set in Salem, so given that the backstory and local folklore have a large presence in this game, this was one hell of a bonus for me given my interest in the witch hunts and magic. The music and atmosphere didn't disappoint. The backstory and tragic history is incorporated into it very well, and the way in which this game combined supernatural elements with crime scene investigation was really inventive and original.  As said, there are things you can miss as well, but this is mostly side missions. I guess few games if any have really matched LA Noire in this department. The graphics look great, can't fault the voice acting either. In terms of the horror elements, as a puzzle game it's challenging enough, but seeing the same ghouls everywhere gets very repetitive very quickly, and it just becomes a chore of running, hiding and timing. It's different enough but just has no variety, still I can see how hard it is to do something really novel and inventive with the ghost-themed survival horror format. Especially if you are a ghost yourself. Overall great game worth getting, worth experiencing and worth playing again, just don't be too disappointed by the length and lack of variety in gameplay....Salem does allow for some exploration, though.

content:
21, 2015
												Although there are many issues with this game, I really do recomend it. It's not great, but it is worth playing.The main problem of the game is that it feels really underdeveloped.The story is short, I think you can finish it in around 5 hours if you rush through the game and skip all the collectibles.There are some pretty useless mechanics included, like, for example, reading people thoughts. At first I was quite excited that I can possess pretty much any NPC and read its mind, but I quickly discovered that most of the thoughts are repeating itself and they are absolutely useless.There are enemies in this game. One kind of enemy to be exact. Demons are annoying addition that doesn't introduce anything to the game except from dull idea of banishing them. You just walk behind a demon, hold R to start banishing and then press mouse button + direction key that pops up on screen. It's excatly as exciting as it seems. Not at all. No thrill, no fear, not even a startle from some jumpscare. They appear, you banish and move on. They could remove them completely from the game as they pose no threat at all and only thing that they manage to achieve is to annoy you.Controls are pretty bad. Especially menu controls. You can use mouse only to point the option you want, to select it you have to use your keyboard.Many technical problems, bugs. Sometimes gamebreaking.The game is faaar to easy.What I enjoyed about the game is the story itself. However short it is, it was really entertaining for me. I love the atmosphere of Salem. Conducting the investigation even though it could be more complex. That's what basically makes the game worth playing for me: the story and the world presented in it. I do recomend the game, however not for its full price. If you see it on some good sale go for it, but else just wait for the price to go down.

content:
y 16, 2016
												I picked this up on a sale for 1,99€ and it was worth the money.It's a point and click detective game with a supernatural story.It's not much to the detective part in the game, you mostly answer questions by clicking on clues you have found.The game have some kind of system where if you guess something wrong you lose a "badge" and you have three badges for each mystery but it will not effect anything in the game as far as I could tell.It feels like it was meant for a achievement but they never put it in or that the detective part was supposed to be more complex but got scratched later on.The game have a nice old detective movie feeling to it and the story keeps you interesting.The story is about a detective that have to solve his on murder as a ghost to move on. The two main characters are good written and works well together. It's a nice spooky feeling throughout the game even tho it's not a horror game.In addition to the main story you can solve a handful of side cases for lost spirits around the world to give them peace and in addition to that there is a lot of collectables scattered around.The collectables tells you about the town, the murderer, your character and ghost stories. The ghost stories is a really nice addition, I appreciated them a lot.It took me around eleven hours to finish and I did most of the side stuff, I missed some collectables.If you see this game on a sale I would recommand you to pick it up but not for the current pricetag (29,99€).

content:
y 22, 2016
												Was a gift from a good friend of mine (Humble Bundle)A mix of adventure, detective mystery solving game.  Seriously, just don't hover near the spoilers if you haven't played the game yet Pros :  - Interesting storyline - The town looks great with the mix of  a past (ghost) and present theme  - Voice Acting - Plot twist!  - A game that  lets you play as a cat   - Being a ghost is somehow fun - Unique playstyle Cons :  - The story is too linear.  Putting routes on stories and additional mini quest is fine  - Demons  Stealth in a detective mystery game sounds good but really, screeching demons who chase you but they leave you once you move in a specific spot. Also, sometimes annoying...  - Save slots would be fine. You have to replay the game once you finish/restart to the last checkpoint (A bit of a hassle when it comes to achievement farming) - Point and click. Investigations are kind of easy since they already tell you where the clues are. You can just spam E in the map and you'll probably find the clue   - NPCs - just remove some of the  mind reading  or just  keep them silent . It's confusing  when you're looking for clues   - Locked to 30 FPS....  - Cutscenes...  A skip button would be nice if you die or restart from another checkpoint  - Too short (Finished within 9.6 hours - including breaks)Needs a lot more improvement still. Would buy a sequel if there is one Better buy it on sale.Rating : 7/10

content:
er 23, 2014
												What does it feel like to be staring down at your own dead body, lying helplessly in the street? To see police agents discussing what might have happened to you, without being able to tell them? The first thing you might notice is that being a ghost actually renders you painfully limited in your ability to interact with the world. Thankfully, there are advantages as well. And, as you will soon discover - what you can't do, someone else might be willing to do for you.I imagine some people are holding off on buying this game due to the moderate-to-bad reviews it has received. I'd like to argue differently. It is by no means perfect - I ran into a few bugs and the game even crashed on me in the final chapter. I was also not happy about not being able to change the key bindings. But the story and its two main characters made it easy to overlook these issues. A unique idea for a video game - not perfectly executed, but more than well enough to warrant a playthrough.

content:
ry 16, 2015
Rating: 7.5/10Short thoughts:Overall, I very much enjoyed playing Murdered: Soul Suspect and would definitely recommend it for those who are looking for a cool story about a ghost detective in the town of Salem looking to crack the case of his own murder. Longer thoughts:The story is based around a murdered detective named Ronan who is a pretty cool and has the outfit to match (and never ending cigarette). Ronan travels around the town of Salem investigating his own murder case as well as those of other townsfolk. Main story was enjoyable, as well as the side mini-stories fueled by the collection of 'evidence' around the town. The ghost aspect was neat, as you could walk through walls, possess people and animals, influence their thoughts and more of that nature. Could have used some variety in the options of interacting with NPCs, but I didn't mind it much. The game has a simple combat system which I found to work out great in the end as it allowed you to continue focusing on the story rather than get distracted and spending hours sneaking by monsters as some other games have you do. In the end, I am very satisfied with how this game played out and do not regret purchasing it one bit. However, I would not recommend purchasing this at full price (~$30), but if it can be found on sale below that, I would definitely suggest picking it up.

content:
er 27, 2015
												Playing Murdered: Soul Suspect is akin to watching a tugboat wreck into a freight train.  It shouldn't be happening, it's the most ludicrous scenario you could possibly imagine but somehow you just have to watch the tragedy.  This game is FAR from perfect and a once n' doner.  IMO it's absolutely not worth the 29.99 price tag and I find it hard to believe it was going for over $50 for quite sometime.  I got much more value from budget games like Curse: Eye of Isis or Hard Reset than I did from this disasterpiece, yet Soul Suspect is enjoyable and I couldn't seem to put it down for the 8 and a half hours it took me to reach my goal.  I think the game performed so poorly with professional reviewers because it's simply not what you expect.  At heart, the game is like an old school point and click, detective adventure with some demonic combat and fetch quests thrown in.  In the game you play as Ronan O'Connor; a sleuth murdered at the hands of the Bell Killer...a sort of Jack the Ripper type serial killer stalking the infamous town of Salem.  The plot of the game is interesting if not somewhat predictable, mish-mashing together a bit of ideas from film (Seven, Silence of the Lambs) with the hard-boiled whodunnit atmosphere of LA Noire.  Some of the plot twists you can see from a mile away, but there's some that were at least somewhat of a surprise.  The story is told at a brisk place with cut scenes between present and past (the Salem Witch Trials) with the voice acting being strong enough to keep you involved and invested.  Ronan is voiced well enough, but sometimes the writing is a little untentionally cheesy.   Thankfully, in the context of a hard-boiled, noir style mystery it works and causes a chuckle or two without being too too flat.  Gameplay/atmosphere wise you run around the town of Salem which is setup as a mini-sandbox.  If Airtight Games had more time and money to put into the project, one could only wonder just how amazing this game could have been.  You can't enter alot of the buildings, leaving you to run around between finding various collectibles, taking on a scant few side quests and finally going to one of the city's main locations for the main action.  The graphical detail isn't overly impressive, but it's solid with decent characer models, appropriately dingy gothic design and some cool locales to explore.  Animation is stiff, the framerate is sometimes choppy and sometimes the items you need to collect will glitch in and out of existence making it a royal s.o.b. to pick them up.  The voice-acting as stated earlier was well-done although the ambient effects (besides the sinister demons you take on in stealth combat) aren't anything particularly special.  The gameplay slides between sleuthing, stealth action, fetching and exploration.  You'll come across numerous crime scenes and points of interests where your main goal is to search, examine and interrogate for clues.  Everything plays out like a stripped-down, beginner's version of L.A. Noire.  Sometimes your ghostly abilities will come into play such as possession to get inside people's heads, teleportation to get where you need to go, passing through walls, etc.  Initially, the gameplay is fun but as the game progresses you can see how basic it is.  You shouldn't need a walkthrough at all for this sucker because everything is laid out just how you need.  Once you've collected enough clues you can solve the crime scene by selecting the appropriate hints and picking the order of their importance.  It's a shame that your'e a ghost with such cool abilities but they feel second nature.  You will not be punished, nor will anything change even if you screw things up.  The game is linear to a fault.  Yet, these sequences are enjoyable enough in an old school point n' click style that it's fun.  If you can think past how the game always seems to cramp and rope you into doing what it wants you to, you'll be interested in how solving each puzzle advances the story.  To break things up you'll get the chance to possess a cat and use it to explore hard to reach areas.  The other main shake of the gameplay is stealth combat where you take on floating demons that look like monstrosities culled from Clive Barker's Undying.  They are actually pretty creepy in the way that they scream and hunt you down if they spot Ronan.  The only way to kill them is to engage them from behind, entering a quicktime button combo that will take 'em out.  Once alerted they can be tough to escape as your only means of protection is to hide in spiritual residue left behind from poltergeists.  You can jump from one residue host to another, leading to a cat n' mouse game where you try to get the upper hand on the beasties.  It's a fun addition to the gameplay variety but like most things in Soul Suspect it's awkward and feels undercooked.  By far one of the most enjoyable parts of the game were the sidequests, where you help dwelling spirits find out the manner in which they died.  These murders have somewhat of an emotional, human element to them (as stated by a few reviewers) that makes you want to help the poor schleps get some eternal rest.  Each quest is set up as a mini-mystery where you canvas a crime scene and put the clues together.  The only problem is that there's about 5 of them total.  If more were added it would have been a great thing.  Once again this represents just how much of a missed-opportunity Soul Suspect is across the board.  For those after Steam Achievements there's a ton of stuff to collect, but some of it's level specific, so if you miss it...too bad.  You have to start the game over again from square one and give it another shot.  Maybe some of you will but I sure won't.  I got 73% on a first try and I nodded afterwards saying to myself, "Good enough, good enough."  It would have been cool if you could start the game over as a new game plus.  I started it over briefly and it seemed to reset everything.  From a technical standpoint things aren't perfect either.  The game ran fairly smooth most of the time but several drops in framerate got me killed by demons about 2 or 3 times, I had about 4 game freeze crashes and I also got the end of cemetery level glitch.  None of these are game breaking, so you can get through them without losing too much progress.  To break it down:Pros:-Salem is a killer game setting.  -Involving storyline with great atmosphere-Fun mix of sleuthing, adventure, stealth combat and pick a path gameplay-Side quests and collectibles are a plus-Strong voice acting-Decent graphics and soundCons:-Pseudo sandbox gameplay is too linear-Easy puzzles and difficulty-Cool ghost powers but all of 'em are quite restricted-No branching paths for messing up the detective gameplay-Can't carry over collectibles that I saw-Some minor annoying glitches-Undercooked combat-Once you beat it, there's really no reason to go backThough I have alot of qualms about what Soul Suspect coulda been, what's there is worth playing through once.  Somehow for all of its flaws, there's a charming veneer lurking behind the game's black tooth smile.  The story in and of itself makes it worth a playthrough.  Whether you'll want to pick it up a second time is going to be an iffy, p2p decision.  I'd say this game is worth no more than $15 if you're going to pick it up.  I got it on a holiday sale for a few bucks and it more than exceeded my expectations in terms of value.  I'm pretty sure I paid $5 and could have seen paying as much as $15 for it.  But for $30?  No way Jose!    Final score:  7/10

content:
1, 2016
												Quick Summary: Murdered Soul Suspect is a mystery game more than an action game, so if you’re looking for a shooter or platformer, you won’t find much of that here. I haven’t really played many mystery games so the closest that I can compare this game to is the “investigation” portions of the Batman Arkham series, where you’re in a room with crime scenes trying to piece together what happened. The game has a ton of collectibles, both quest related, and for background on the story, making the experience immersive and decently long if you actually stop to read everything.You play a police detective named Ronan, killed during an investigation into the “Bell Killer,” a serial killer terrorizing the town of Salem. Yes, it’s the Salem with the Witch trials from hundreds of years ago, and the history of the town will play into your investigation. You’re not alone on your quest though, since a local “medium” who can see ghosts such as yourself, has her own investigation to follow and it happens to coincide with yours. Good thing too, since being a murder victim means you can’t interact with most of the living world.As a ghost, Ronan has access to certain powers such as the ability to move through solid objects, “possess” random people (you don’t really control them), “reveal” memory remnants, and later on you can teleport short distances.  The game is played in third person perspective with a lot of narration by Ronan, giving it a sort of noir feel (reminds me of Alan Wake, but with no shooting). The town of Salem is pretty small in this game, and despite being a ghost, a lot of areas are off limits to you because of walls and buildings being “consecrated.” There are 2 worlds that you can see at the same time, the real world (that you can walk through objects in) and a ghost world (mostly walls and objects that block your movement). The town is also littered with ghosts other than yourself that you can talk to. Some of them have mini quests (investigations) that you can take part in, but most of them are just there for short conversations, adding to the game’s atmosphere. I actually stopped talking to random ghosts about 1/3 into the game since most of them don’t have anything story related to tell you.As I mentioned before, this is not an action game so you don’t really fight anyone, however there are a number of “demons” roaming the town in story related areas. You can either avoid the demons by stealthily sneaking around, or you can try to banish them by sneaking up behind them and executing a quick time event. You can see the demons through walls, so it’s possible to get around them if you have ninja hiding skills. Frankly, I suggest banishing them all so you can roam freely and pick up all the collectibles in each area. Pros:+A decent, slow paced mystery story with some twists and turns. You’re playing this game for the story more than anything else.+The investigations are kind of fun, searching for clues and piecing together events after you’ve gotten the hang of it.Cons:-If you’re mostly into shooting games, you may find yourself bored. There’re some stealth sections, but the majority of the game is puzzle solving and searching for clues.-The game uses an autosave system that isn’t very well explained.  There are times where it shows the “saving” icon, but if you quit and reload you’ll be missing a bunch of progress/clues.  I recommend completing side quests separate from main story sections (don’t go back and forth between side quest and main quest) and then move on to the story section. The only time I could be sure the game had saved was when I entered a new area in the story.Overall, I’d recommend this game if you’re looking for a moderately easy “thinker” game, and are taking a break from action/shooting. If you’re just going through the main investigations of the story and not bothering with side missions or collectibles, you can probably finish in about 7 hours.

content:
ry 16, 2015
Rating: 7.5/10Short thoughts:Overall, I very much enjoyed playing Murdered: Soul Suspect and would definitely recommend it for those who are looking for a cool story about a ghost detective in the town of Salem looking to crack the case of his own murder. Longer thoughts:The story is based around a murdered detective named Ronan who is a pretty cool and has the outfit to match (and never ending cigarette). Ronan travels around the town of Salem investigating his own murder case as well as those of other townsfolk. Main story was enjoyable, as well as the side mini-stories fueled by the collection of 'evidence' around the town. The ghost aspect was neat, as you could walk through walls, possess people and animals, influence their thoughts and more of that nature. Could have used some variety in the options of interacting with NPCs, but I didn't mind it much. The game has a simple combat system which I found to work out great in the end as it allowed you to continue focusing on the story rather than get distracted and spending hours sneaking by monsters as some other games have you do. In the end, I am very satisfied with how this game played out and do not regret purchasing it one bit. However, I would not recommend purchasing this at full price (~$30), but if it can be found on sale below that, I would definitely suggest picking it up.

content:

												I was put off this game initially due to negative reports about its length, and so the base price of £20 was enough to give me pause. However, when it appeared on sale for £5 I decided to give it a chance and I am very glad I did. The star of this game is its story, where you play as the ghost of Ronan O'Connor, a detective in modern day Salem. For a large part it feels like a point and click adventure game where the emphasis is on finding the pieces and putting them together rather than on any sort of direct action. Gameplay revolves around investigations that are heavily reminiscent of L.A. Noire (another game I really enjoyed) except you can walk through walls and interrogating people is mostly replaced with possessing them to influence their mind. Perhaps owing to the length of the story (it only took me around 8hrs to complete the main quest, all side quests and most collectibles) both the story and gameplay never outstayed their welcome and remained entertaining to the very end. The main negative in this game is the repetitive forced stealth segments where you are forced to sneak up on demonic spirits before a simple quick time event is entered in place of combat. I felt even after the first of these that it was an unnecessary mechanic designed as a buffer between me and the enjoyable parts of the game. I would commonly find myself sweeping an area of these "enemies" before returning to start the section proper. Thankfully, they don't take too long and aren't difficult, but this just emphasises how needless they are.I would definitely recommend this as a sale pickup if you are even remotely curious.

												Well, a lot of what you've heard about this game is true. There is a lot of clunk to its port (the menu has no mouse support and doesn't even use arrow keys). The "combat" amounts to a random key press alongside a random mouse button click. And the mystery isn't that complex. So why am I recommending it, you ask? Because it never lost my attention. Between the atmosphere, the unlockable ghost stories, and the main case (albeit not Sir Arthur Conan Doyle stuff) it was just a lot of fun to play. I even got into the random key sequences of excuting demons (and was a bit suprised that in the beginning my nerves would betray me and I'd fail at times). It was Airtight's swan song, and you can almost feel it in there what with the brevity and all, but it is a nice tune for those seeking an atmospheric haunted noire vibe. Definitely not for everyone, but much better than the critics have given it credit for, that's for sure.

er 8, 2014
												This is a great game for those who like stories. It is very cinematic and its storytelling involves the player in Ronan's story. It's more a mystery story than a horror one (even though it has some elements). I'm going to start reviewing from the negative stuff to the positive:- Not being able to change the controls in PC is a joke. This will prevent left-handed people from playing and makes the only difficult spot more difficult by choosing ridiculous key controls - That said, the game is not difficult at all (it's almost an interactive movie), though in certain spots the difficulty spikes due to the controls- There's plenty of reading if you want to know the whole stories that make the side quests, but there's a bug in the game: if you want to read the stories of the items on the menu, press Enter, not the mouse- There's plenty of stuff to do and to collect in the city and you have almost complete freedom to move around. Still I'd have liked the option of finishing the side quests before ending the game.- The game design works great to make you feel like a ghost. I soon realised that even though I was dead I still tended to try to walk through doors instead of walls"- The experience is great.Oh, and as someone said, you can posses cats. And meow.

content:
1, 2014
												Good adventure game with a good story. Not a fast-paced game and with very few action elements, but it was never supposed to be an action game to begin with. Soul Suspect plays more like an adventure game with puzzles with an occassional fighting scene (which itself is presented like an action puzzle with a small amount of strategy involved). The atmosphere is great. Sound (voice and music) and visuals are superb and convincing and set the mood for the game right away. The story is classical detective story, obviously with supernatural elements, is well written and even though not mind blowing in its "message", it kept me completely immersed en interested through the whole game. The game world is not very big,but detailed and varying, and there are very many things to observe and find. Lots of collectibles, but these are done right: when found, they provide smaller details to the story, or tell separate smaller stories of their own.Gameplay puzzles aren't very difficult, and failing them doesn't give any penalty. The detective puzzles will remind a lot of LA Noire, but are somewhat easier. To sum up: not a game for people looking for action. It is rather a game for people who don't mind standing still occasionally in a game for a while to observe the surroundings and solve a puzzle or mystery. If you are one of those, you are in for a treat: the game is very convincing as a supernatural spooky detective.PS: almost no bugs found, except cinematics graphics sometimes appeared in much worse quality than actual gameplay (which are pretty good). Also keep in mind that collectibles you might have missed can't be collected once you finish the game (the game notifies about this in the last scene).

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
1, 2014
												Good adventure game with a good story. Not a fast-paced game and with very few action elements, but it was never supposed to be an action game to begin with. Soul Suspect plays more like an adventure game with puzzles with an occassional fighting scene (which itself is presented like an action puzzle with a small amount of strategy involved). The atmosphere is great. Sound (voice and music) and visuals are superb and convincing and set the mood for the game right away. The story is classical detective story, obviously with supernatural elements, is well written and even though not mind blowing in its "message", it kept me completely immersed en interested through the whole game. The game world is not very big,but detailed and varying, and there are very many things to observe and find. Lots of collectibles, but these are done right: when found, they provide smaller details to the story, or tell separate smaller stories of their own.Gameplay puzzles aren't very difficult, and failing them doesn't give any penalty. The detective puzzles will remind a lot of LA Noire, but are somewhat easier. To sum up: not a game for people looking for action. It is rather a game for people who don't mind standing still occasionally in a game for a while to observe the surroundings and solve a puzzle or mystery. If you are one of those, you are in for a treat: the game is very convincing as a supernatural spooky detective.PS: almost no bugs found, except cinematics graphics sometimes appeared in much worse quality than actual gameplay (which are pretty good). Also keep in mind that collectibles you might have missed can't be collected once you finish the game (the game notifies about this in the last scene).

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												I had my worries of the game especially considering how multiple gaming review sites just loved to tear it a new one. I found however a particular repeating element and pattern that struck me the wrong way in most of them. The major complaints often revolve around repetition and easy difficulty structure. The learning curve is rather flat while taking the time to solve mysteries and crimes is often called child's play at that. I hate to use this term but it just feels so rather Meta in the face of the pace the game seems to give off. Salem just looks so ghostly inviting and everywhere has the potential for you to take the time and admire the lives of the still living. At the same time it just doesn't feel like a burden to get to the next part of the story and become all the more curious of the world around you. Even the collectables have merit in the stories they tell. It just seems that a great number of people expected a rather explosive and mind bending experience. Murdered: Soul Suspect is like a brisk walk through the undead and spiritual park. It's a pleasant walk. It has a great way of not stifling the flow it has set up and the characters you come to find along the way give a curious nuance to the atmosphere. Would I say the game is flawless or addictive? No, I do not believe it is an extreme grabber that you can't let go of. It's more like that book you've been wanting to read for awhile and you just finally got down to reading it. Take your time, appreciate the attention to details, and you'll feel all the more rewarded for the investment. If you're more set on something more fast paced and hectic then perhaps another title may be up your alley.

content:
3, 2014
												Well, a lot of what you've heard about this game is true. There is a lot of clunk to its port (the menu has no mouse support and doesn't even use arrow keys). The "combat" amounts to a random key press alongside a random mouse button click. And the mystery isn't that complex. So why am I recommending it, you ask? Because it never lost my attention. Between the atmosphere, the unlockable ghost stories, and the main case (albeit not Sir Arthur Conan Doyle stuff) it was just a lot of fun to play. I even got into the random key sequences of excuting demons (and was a bit suprised that in the beginning my nerves would betray me and I'd fail at times). It was Airtight's swan song, and you can almost feel it in there what with the brevity and all, but it is a nice tune for those seeking an atmospheric haunted noire vibe. Definitely not for everyone, but much better than the critics have given it credit for, that's for sure.

content:
er 8, 2014
												This is a great game for those who like stories. It is very cinematic and its storytelling involves the player in Ronan's story. It's more a mystery story than a horror one (even though it has some elements). I'm going to start reviewing from the negative stuff to the positive:- Not being able to change the controls in PC is a joke. This will prevent left-handed people from playing and makes the only difficult spot more difficult by choosing ridiculous key controls - That said, the game is not difficult at all (it's almost an interactive movie), though in certain spots the difficulty spikes due to the controls- There's plenty of reading if you want to know the whole stories that make the side quests, but there's a bug in the game: if you want to read the stories of the items on the menu, press Enter, not the mouse- There's plenty of stuff to do and to collect in the city and you have almost complete freedom to move around. Still I'd have liked the option of finishing the side quests before ending the game.- The game design works great to make you feel like a ghost. I soon realised that even though I was dead I still tended to try to walk through doors instead of walls"- The experience is great.Oh, and as someone said, you can posses cats. And meow.

content:
ry 28, 2015
												By all accounts, this game should have never been made in 2014.  The market for AAA games demand experiences much different than this one.  This is a niche game, and throwing so many resources at it is a terrible, terrible business decision.The game has almost no combat, and is driven by dialogue, information gathering, and narrative.That said, I am writing this after just completing it, with a huge grin on my face.  The story in this game is STELLAR.  It evokes the slower pacing and murder mystery elements of games like the Blackwell franchise and LA Noire.  It's also compounded with supernatural elements and a heavy influence from the Salem Witch Trials.At it's heart, it's a murder mystery (your own, in fact.)  But once it starts unfolding, there is an incredible narrative to be experienced, one I highly recommend, if you don't mind slow pacing in video games.I can't recommend this to everyone, but if you love a good mystery, and prefer dialogue to gunplay, then I cannot recommend this game enough.  Like I said, it's a niche game, and if you fall into that niche, then please, please, play this game.

content:
6
												Good atmosphere, music, and story. I think the ending was worth the time. Also, it's fully dubbed into Spanish, which is great.Now, I would only recommend buying this game on sale (it's 3€ now at some sites, which is quite fair). The puzzles are basically "Mysterium" in a nutshell, which means they sometimes make sense, and some other times you just random-click through all of the clues until you get them right cause they make absolutely no sense except for the guy who made the game lol.Some people find demons stupid. I think they're a nice touch. Repetitive, indeed, but they create some sort of fear that you wouldn't feel without them, cause you never know when "exactly" they are gonna pop up (but you can mostly guess). Most ghost hiding places are unnecessary, though, since you won't ever use them at all.Collectibles, collectibles everywhere. I found most of them naturally because I inspect all the stages before moving on with the story, so that I don't have to interrupt it later on to find them. I missed all the graffities, tho. Had to find them with a guide. No idea how to find all of them otherwise, except by luck. IMPORTANT: make sure you find everything before Judgement House. Otherwise you will be unable to do it later on, since the game locks you out of the city at the end (no free-roam after the credits).NPCs are repetitive as hell. Mind reading is useless, since they all think pretty much the same things. Ghost teleportation and possession come in handy in few occasions for the plot, and that's about it. Also, there are only like 5 side missions, and the most interesting one was the first one at the apartment.On the bright side, you can possess cats, xD. Press Y to meow.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
14, 2016
												Murdered: Soul Suspect developers have implemented completely new type of investigation games. 'What is it about?', you may ask, so the answer is below:You are local of Salem, Massachusetts, the place which is mostly associated with XVII-century's history about witches, that people were hunting at and then, after catching them, they were burned at the stake. In game, there is mystical climat exposing supernatural skills of Ronan O'Connor, the main character, who had been killed at the beginning of the game and then he transformed to a ghost, who had to face demons, solve a mystery of his death and find out, who had killed him. Ronan, while getting the 'new himself', gets new skills, which allow him to move through the walls, be invisible to people, read in people's minds and even control them! During investigation he meets some demons hunting for souls, so he needs to eliminate them, or move around the place to get safer way. The game reminds me of L.A. Noire, because you need to solve problems by getting some details and then connecting them into one, making sense trace. If you complete it successfully, you'll see what happened before.Graphic effects are nice, the gameplay is happening during the twilight, so colours are darky, but they keep you even closer, because of usage them in thrilling details around. The Unreal Engine 3 is helping the game to get high details of buildings, models and characters, as well as good animations. The last thing I want to mention about is sound - thrilling music showing overwhelming atmosphere of Salem and live comments of O'Connor's adventures, which lead us to equating with Ronan even more.Murdered: Soul Suspect and its story completely touched my heartstrings and that's one of the reasons, why my note is very high! Great compilation of story, graphics and sound is forcing me to put 10/10. Hope you enjoy!

content:
, 2014
												It has been awhile since I’ve played an adventure game. An honest to god adventure game, where you play the character to pass a few simple puzzles to unlock the next part of the story. And Murdered: Soul Suspect developed by Airtight Games scratches that itch. Albeit it does have its flaws.Lets get the basics out of the way, you play a cop by the name of Ronan and in the first seconds of the game you get to see your character die. But unlike a lot of games this isn’t the end, because you become a ghost. Who in order to move on has to find out who murdered him. That’s the basic plot of the game, and the main story line. And so you will spend roughly 8-12 hours going through all of Salem’s locations hunting down the clues to discover your murder. Along the way you’ll befriend some people and learn some very unsettling secrets about the town.While the story isn’t the most complicated or even the best it still is written and presented well enough to be enjoyable. Along with the side quest and collectibles that fill in the background details about the town and the various characters it kept me enthralled for the nine hours that I played it, but then some peoples mileage may vary. The one complaint I will have is that the developers didn’t put more background in, or even more interesting stuff. As in very early in the game you help a young girl discover what happened to her and why she was dead, you barely ever come close to that type of detail again. And that is sad because of this the background environment in terms of engagement is inconsistent, because at one end you find a piece of the map full of history and maybe a doctor who was performing experiments on his patients then at the other end you have a boring area that you have to navigate constantly to get to other locations in the game.  Seriously it gets tedious having to run the same gauntlet over and over again, with nothing changed just the same old Salem with the same old random NPC’s.As for the gameplay mechanics, you will have learned almost everything within the first hour of how to play this game, except for a couple of “powers” you learn later on. You’re a ghost, you can pass through physical real world barriers, except for ghost barriers and all the houses in Salem are blessed or something so you can’t get into them without there being an opening of some kind. You can manipulate real world things like tv’s, phones, and printers, but except for missions these abilities don’t rouse a response out of the people in Salem. You can possess people to hear there thoughts, which there are not many of them. You can influence them to advance the case and you can view the world through there eyes to once again advance the case. Pretty nifty thing, but only actually used in the missions and have very littler bearing on the game.And that is pretty much the sum total of the game in mechanics other than the bad guys. Which are demons and floor demons as I will call them.Just like most adventure games of the past the bad guys pose little to no challenge and are merely there to present a hurdle to bypass. For being called demons if its 1V1 I’m going to win all the time. You hide in shades wait for them to turn there backs and then rip them apart. Also you can use ravens to distract them, but ravens ain’t used a lot. As for floor demons just side step them. Graphics wise, the game is pretty good, not the prettiest in terms of background environment and the character models look a bit dated, they remind me of XCOM the Bureau, or even LA Norie, but that’s not a bad thing as those games had good graphics as well. And as with anything graphics are not everything as the recent trend in PC gaming can attest to.  So you may be asking why I seemed to be praising this game in the beginning but point out a lot of flaws in it. Well because in truth there are very few actual adventure games made by triple A developers anymore so anything coming out in this genre that isn’t a bug ridden mess, it will be enjoyed by those of us who like adventure games. Where you play a guy or women trying to unfold a story, either by solving puzzles or piecing the story together . Where you don’t have to gun down an armies worth of bad guys to move from one area to the next. Where the bad guys have to be planned around as you really have no actual defense against them. Where you know you can’t lose but hate the fact that you screw up sometimes. So for an adventure game, Murdered Soul Suspect is a fine addition, its has a fairly strong main storyline and some pretty interesting side storylines and background storylines, but as I said before could use a few more to liven the area up even more. (Maybe some DLC?)For a game it is pretty average to mediocre though, with most gameplay mechanics discovered and mastered in the first hour it leaves little advancement in that area. The NPC’s are uninteresting, the graphics compared to top of the line are dated, gameplay is pretty linear, and replayability, well to be honest there is none. I’ve played ten hours and the game will probably sit there unless I have an itch to find those 5 pieces of background info/collectibles. So final verdict? If you are a fan of adventure games and smooth easy gameplay, then Soul Suspect is the perfect game for you. But if you are new to adventure games, or expecting something different then I wouldn’t suggest this game. And even if you are a fan of the genre this will slot into, wait till it drops to under $20 for it to be worth the money.

content:
, 2014
												This is a ghost story, About a abused misunderstood criminal, who meets his soul mate and turns a new leaf on life by becoming a detective with the help of his brother-in-law, He places the story of his life in tattoos that cover his body. His wife dies and he becomes reckless, and winds up geting killed. Now hes a ghost, searching for his killer. Theres alot to do in this game, through fairly easy. you have your main story, about 7 additional ghost stories to uncover, history on salem, and many other artifacts, something like 200 Items to search for. As a ghost you get abilities as the game progresses. The game really does not punish for wrong choices except you lose your gold badge status if you mess up. Steam has achievements to earn. There are demons and demon traps so you need to be carefull where you step, or if your running from demons not to step into traps. You can kill demons by getting behind them. or you can try to avoid them. I perfer just to kill them and get them out of the way. The game is not set up so you fail, it relies on the story telling and requires you to scour areas with a fine tooth comb to unlock all the stuff thats needs to be found. Just running through the main story makes for a short game, But trying to collect everything makes a very long game. So the choice is yours. The graphics are very good, I have not found any glitches or bugs in my two play throughs, the controls are responsive. I'd recommend this game for anyone who just wants a casual interesting story to sit back and relax and play. With that in mind the critics scores on this game is unjust. It's not a 10, but more like a 7.

content:
, 2014
												(I know it says it only have 5 hours on the clock but it's closer to six, around 5 hours and 45 minutes in all..that's how long it took me to finish it.)First thing i'll say is you should half ignore the paid critic reviews the only thing they got right is when they say "It lacks a challenge" Because that's true, this game is straight up easy from start to finish. the investigations are fun but pretty much handed to you on a plate. There is little to no combat in this game save for taking out roaming demons wit the equivilant of a stealth kill...or..stealth...banishment i guess? you have hiding spots to evade and avoid detection from these demons, there are also crows scattered around that you can use to distract them, making it easier for you to sneak up behind and take them out.That really is the only form of challenge you will find in this game and even then..it's only a challenge when there are no hiding spots around and no crows.....and even then it's still easy as hell to take them out. The story and characters are what will keep you playing here.The story is interesting, gripping and just down right fun to experience though you could easily just watch the story play out on youtube. If you want to experience this game for yourself then i suggest picking it up on sale. i'll give it a 7/10 for being short and just way too easy

content:
, 2014
												This game is really fun. The story hooked me in right from the start and never let go until the 'yell at your tv' ending. I find the gameplay mechanics refreshing and fun. You are a ghost so you can't directly interact with most things, but you can look and piece together clues leading you through the games story amazingly well. I don't think i ever got frustratingly stuck or bored of the gameplay. The story and gameplay flow together nicely. And the characters! I found them all to be believable, with no cliche cardboard cutouts among the main characters. The collection of all the items in the game adds more reason to search through the levels and adds a nice layer onto the story with collectables about the main character, the enemy, and even the town itself. The world feels very historic. Some might argue that it is too linear, but I personally liked that places were blocked off or I would have spent hours rifling through large buildings, getting lost XDMaybe my only complaint about the game is that there is no map, and since you can go through walls, it can get disorienting. I get that a ghost cant really carry around a map haha, its just a little nitpick, overall I loved the game and would recommend it to anyone looking for a great story and a fun time :)

content:

												Two important features this doesn't have: Multiple saves and letting you complete side-missions after you finish. The issues are linked, since there's an auto-saving checkpoint maybe three minutes before the end that doesn't let you go back for no good reason (and you can't turn toggle autosave). At least there's a warning but it's still far less than ideal.If I'm not mistaken the collectibles in the museum area also become unavailable once you enter the judgement house, this time without warning.Otherwise it's decent, but not for 40€. 30€ maybe, since the game is just not that long. (I completed the side missions but not all collectible hunts, and I'm not going back since my save is effectively wrecked, which is definitely in part my fault but not something I expect to be an issue in a good game.)

content:
, 2014
Murdered: Soul Suspect Review - NihoesI know what you're thinking. Is the game a detective game? Is it like L.A Noir? These two questions are the most common asked ones, and it's a little bit like L.A Noir, but that is only because you can take choices on what to ask other dead persons. Since you're gonna meet others like you, each one of them, have their own story. You can travel into living persons mind and read them, or you can "posses" them. Not making them do things for you, but you can make them think thoughts that you kinda implant in their head, You can't make them do things for you, as like you "posses" a police officer, and then control him, nope not gonna happend.The game not only got the whole detective genre going on, but also a good old thriller.If you like mystery, thriller, action, then this is game for you. You're Ronan, a former gang member who gets tattoos for each and every 'great' memory in his life that he wants to remeber for his very own personal reason.Visit my profile to see screenshots of the game.-Nihoes

content:
, 2014
												This game is absolutely fantastic! I've been playing it throughout the weekend and i've just finished it. I thought it was great. I found the story to be very interesting and everytime I was left with a cliffhanger I wanted to know what happened next. The fact you play as a ghost makes the game all the more interesting to play. You cannot pick up objects and normal people cannot see or hear you. It's a very interesting way to play a game but I really like it and I think it adds a hint of uniqueness to the game.  If you've ever played L.A noire you'll probably be fairly familiar with the concept of this game (finding clues and solving cases) but gameplay wise they are completely differnet, you cannot pick up and examine clues you find for example.Don't let the negative reviews for this game turn you off from buying it. It's a fantastic game with a great story and for £24.99 (even lower on other sites) it's a bargain! I highly recommend this game to any fans of the genre.

content:
ry 21
												I stumbled upon this game as I was checking out the Square Enix webpage because I am a huge fan of Life is Strange and wanted to see what other titles they had that may be just as interesting. I read the information on Murdered Soul Suspect and figured I'd give it a go. I am so glad that I did. This game kept me wanting to come back to it more and more. I grew fond of Ronan and wanted to see this to the end. His ghost to medium relationship with Joy kept me amused throughout the game and their conversations back and forth lifted the darkness from the game itself. The history also was interesting as it is obvious the creators researched the Salem Witch Trials as well as other newsworthy incidents in Salem, Mass. It was well thought out on how to incorporate these details into the game without it coming across as a boring history lesson. I would have loved to have seen more helping of other ghosts around town (I think there were 4 or so?). The side quest portion I really enjoyed while continuing through the main story itself. It was fun running around Salem tracking down all the collectables. I would definitely recommend this game to anyone interested in the Salem Witch Trials, the paranormal, and who enjoys detective work. An enjoyable game!
