content:
, 2014
												For those who don't want to read a wall of text; I give the game a 6.5/10The Short review:Pros+Main story pans out rather well+Collectible ghost stories are great+Unique concept+Intriguing secondary characters (pretty much everyone but Ronan)+Diverse game world+Despite the limited/focused gameplay, it did not get repetitive+No bugs/perfect performance, especially at launchCons-Very short (7hrs to 100%)-Limited side missions-Small game world by modern standards-Ronan, and the investigation system, can be really..really stupid-The facial expressions for pretty much every character in the game sucks**-Limited number of character models, despite how few ghosts you can interact with-Probably would have been received better if it was at a cheaper price**My long review was actually way too long, but the rather awkward facial expressions throughout the game are the most important part of the review that I had to cut outThe (Really) Long review:STORY 6.5/10 - Chances are, you already realize the Murdered: Soul Suspect is an adventure game based very heavily around a story, and that story quite often falls flat on its face in terms of portraying the sense of whodunit type mystery you would get from anything Sherlock Holmes, or from similar games such as LA Noire. The main story starts off kind of rocky, but as it pans out, and you learn to ignore the hand-holding that occurs during the investigations and some of the sillier plot points (where the game screams THIS IS IMPORTANT), it actually becomes quite intriguing. I found myself actually ruling people out as the Bell Killer, with my mind firmly set on one person from very early on in the game. To my pleasant surprise, I only partially anticipated the ending, and it wasn't something from way out in left field as you would find in an M Night Shyamalan movie. It worked (eventually).What didn't work in this game, are many of the aforementioned investigations that hold your hand throughout, often making it obscenely clear exactly what happened without ever even looking at any of the evidence at the scene. In most cases, you needed to guide Ronan to each piece of evidence (generally around 10 items), at which point he would make a remark that is often idiotic (and very often the complete opposite of what the item clearly gave me the impression of) about how it may pertain to the case, and after you have collected sufficient evidence, you would choose the items Ronan deemed important in closing the case. Since chances are you already know what happened, you would then need to find the two or three items that Ronan needed before you could move on to the more enjoyable parts of the game. This burden is frequently increased by Ronan's tendency to ignore VERY important evidence, that could immediately close the case, to focus on items that don't really help his investigation..at all. In general, what could have perhaps been the main draw for many people in this game, ended up feeling trivial and even, at times, tacked on as an after-thought. This became especially apparent when comparing the investigative stories to what was probably my favorite part of the game.Perhaps the most redeeming quality of the game in terms of story, is sadly the part of the game that most people are likely to overlook. Each area of the game has a set of collectibles that you can gather to get a better understanding the lore surrounding that part of Salem, as portrayed through a spooky ghost story. Between these and the investigations, it definitely appears that the ghost stories took a backseat in terms of time spent working on them in the production process, as they consist of a single voice actor describing a very short ghost story, while you look at a spooky picture related to the story. It sounds lame, sure, a cinematic would have made more sense, but at the same time I think it allows you to focus more on the story itself. The ability to successfully portray a spooky story with what seems to be as little effort as possible makes me wonder why this wasn't more of a horror-based adventure game, than a detective-y investigation-y game. Perhaps the most depressing part of the story is the fact that it is so short, clocking in at only 7hrs from start to finish, getting 100% of the achievements at the same time. I would have liked to see more side missions (I'd say investigations, but there wasn't really any of  that going on), and a generally longer story than the game had to offer.CHARACTERS 7.5/10 - Ronan is basically a walking cliché for a bad guy gone good guy cop who does more than just toe the line between cop and criminal when he works cases. You can pretty much ignore his character entirely for a good portion of the game as his comments tend to only point out the other flaws in the game. Joy, the teenage medium, even comes off as a rather cliché young pain in the ♥♥♥, but her character does evolve rather well. When it comes to characters, the game really shines with the secondary characters, such as Baxter, and some of the Bell Killer's victims that you meet along your journey, who have all interacted with the killer in one way or another, and you get to see how that experience has changed them - for better or worse. The same split between really good and really boring characters can be seen in the all-to-few number of side investigations that you can find scattered across Salem, where someone may have a problem that you offer to investigate, and inevitably fix. In the cases where the characters are lame, it is often because of the same thing the investigation part of the game suffers from, the answer being too blatantly obvious to not think that character is an idiot for not seeing it. In other cases, it is clear that the character is in a literal limbo, and they need your help getting out of it. GAMEPLAY 8/10 - First off, the game as a whole  works beautifully, both as a game being played on launch week, and a game in general, as I found no bugs of any kind while playing through the game. Chances are, part of the reason the game runs so great is because it is just so simplistic. The combat in the game is about as basic as you can get, and would most likely have become very redundant had there been more combat sequences in the game. I had only just started to get sick of dealing with demons by the time I reach the last half hour or so of gameplay. It is very clear that the focus is on story and investigating the crimes of the Bell Killer (see the story section for why that is a letdown).The world around Ronan becomes increasingly impressive, and creepy, as the frequency of ghosts increases, but in general I got a very Twilight-zone-empty-town feel from Salem, and the ghosts flat out reminded me of the Haunted Mansion ride at Disney World. Ultimately, the living people that populated Salem ended up feeling even more empty than their ghostly counterparts, which I think actually gave me an even creepier vibe from the game, although I don't think that was totally intentional.While making the world feel a bit more lively is kind of optional, since a gloomier look does make sense to me as you are playing a ghost, I think Salem definitely should have been larger than it was. By the time you reach the credits, you will have only explored just over a half dozen different parts of Salem, and the streets of (a rather small) Salem itself. Sure, the areas are diverse, consisting of everything from a Church, to a Police Station, and a Mental Hospital, but none of the areas are very large, further adding to the small-world feel of the game. On the other hand, with how tedious the combat had become by the end of the game, and how pointless the investigations were (they weren't quite tedious, but certainly would have been soon enough), I think focusing more on other aspects of the game first would have been more important than expanding the world around Ronan.

content:
14, 2016
												Murdered: Soul Suspect developers have implemented completely new type of investigation games. 'What is it about?', you may ask, so the answer is below:You are local of Salem, Massachusetts, the place which is mostly associated with XVII-century's history about witches, that people were hunting at and then, after catching them, they were burned at the stake. In game, there is mystical climat exposing supernatural skills of Ronan O'Connor, the main character, who had been killed at the beginning of the game and then he transformed to a ghost, who had to face demons, solve a mystery of his death and find out, who had killed him. Ronan, while getting the 'new himself', gets new skills, which allow him to move through the walls, be invisible to people, read in people's minds and even control them! During investigation he meets some demons hunting for souls, so he needs to eliminate them, or move around the place to get safer way. The game reminds me of L.A. Noire, because you need to solve problems by getting some details and then connecting them into one, making sense trace. If you complete it successfully, you'll see what happened before.Graphic effects are nice, the gameplay is happening during the twilight, so colours are darky, but they keep you even closer, because of usage them in thrilling details around. The Unreal Engine 3 is helping the game to get high details of buildings, models and characters, as well as good animations. The last thing I want to mention about is sound - thrilling music showing overwhelming atmosphere of Salem and live comments of O'Connor's adventures, which lead us to equating with Ronan even more.Murdered: Soul Suspect and its story completely touched my heartstrings and that's one of the reasons, why my note is very high! Great compilation of story, graphics and sound is forcing me to put 10/10. Hope you enjoy!

content:
ry 24
												Good premise and atmosphere, but some of the gameplay is mediocre.It's basically an interactive story point-and-click game but with a mainstream 3rd person view, some basic stealth and QTE mechanics, and a larger budget to make it more appealing to the masses. This combination of niche and mainstream works well enough, if you have modest expectations. The story is quite enjoyable, but a bit short. Voice acting is decent, and the music fits the mood well. Graphics are fairly modest on a technical level, but some environments still manage to look beautiful, and the effects look slick. While I was expecting some rough edges with gameplay, the core mystery solving mechanics also have some flaws - the answer was sometimes too obvious or seemed inconsistent or illogical. As a console port there are some issues - flawed mouse sensitivity, clunky PC controls you cannot re-bind and a prohibitive autosave system. All these issues are annoying, but they don't ruin the game completely. Possessing cats and solving crimes as a ghost was pretty cool at times.This game reminds me a bit of Alan Wake and LA Noire. While not as good as either of those games, it was better than I thought it would be after seeing the professional reviews. Its sad the developer went bust one month after making this game.If you have modest expectations and some patience, its an enjoyable interactive-story game.Recommended, at sale price.tip: add “-nostartupmovies” to the game's steam launch settings.

content:
26, 2015
												Murdered: Soul Suspect was easily the biggest surprise of 2015 for me, and I think the last game that really blew away my expectations to the same extent was the psychologically assaulting trek through the sands of Spec Ops: The Line. Now of course that comparison gives Soul Suspect a lot more credit than it deserves, it’s a far from perfect game and certainly won’t be looked back on as a game design milestone. But while I expected a more or less point and click hidden object game with fancy 3D graphics and bizarrely contrived QTE’s, what I got was a decent story entwined in a fascinating and well fleshed out word with fantastic mechanics to handle action sequences.Honestly, yes. If I had to boil this game down into a single genre I would have to go with a point and click adventure. The main backbone of the game is walking from crime scene to crime scene and pressing X when you spot a clue. There is certainly nothing revolutionary about the mechanic but the content of the clues- and to a much larger extent the collectibles- brings to light a remarkably well imagined world. Now I’m not well versed in the history of Salem and the details of the witch trials, but I think the writers put in a good amount of creative effort bringing an engaging fictional story into a very real place and time. Typically the little factoids littered around the game world only appeal to completionist minded individuals like myself, however I found myself on a multitude of occasions scouring the town for that last entry to figure out the end of a story.The visuals of the game are adequate, nothing that I didn’t expect after looking at 2 or 3 screenshots. I was able to run the game mostly maxed out on my 680 and the framerate was stable and consistent.Here is the thing that made the game for me: the “final boss”. Don’t worry I will not spoil a thing, and it was actually the absence of something which made it utterly refreshing and a huge relief. Aside from a handful of action-y stealth segments with demons, the game is slow and narrative driven. As I felt the story come closer and closer to a close I got this feeling of dread. You see I know how AAA games go nowadays, every fiber of my being was expecting this dreadful quick time event unfair boss fight that has no continuity with the entire rest of the game. I was even tempted to not finish the game myself and watch the ending online because I didn’t want to walk away from such a great experience with a terrible taste in my mouth. Yet the developers NAILED it. No it’s not a spectacle and no it’s not brutally difficult, but it was satisfying and conclusive to the narrative. The amount of relief I felt at the ending was overwhelming.I’ve harped a lot on a very little point of the game, but it was a big reason this game left me with such a positive view of it. Murdered: Soul Suspect is not perfect but it’s a breath of fresh air for narrative centric games and it kept me engaged and entertained the whole way through.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												This game, just this game.I have so much praise for it that I don't even know where to begin, but I'll try to sound it off.-The gameplay is a breath of fresh-air because it's this unique blend of third-person action game with occasional stealth elements and exploration based adventure game with some crime scene investigation and mild puzzle-solving thrown for good measure. I have trouble really classifying it because I've never played anything quite like it, and it really managed to form it's own gameplay identity instead of being a clone of something else or fitting neatly into a pre-defined gameplay genre.-The graphics are also really pretty relative to how easy on the hardware it it. I was able to max it out (with AA turned off) at 1080p on a 750ti and it was rare that it dropped under FPS.-The story is brilliant and actually managed to have a couple twists that I really didn't see coming because of the way it played with my expectations near constantly and intentionally set itself up for common tropes only to subvert or play with them.-The art design is great and does this thing where it creates interesting eviroments by blending the real-world with ghostly left-overs of the past.-It was interesting how it turned no-clip into a game mechanic.-The bonus stuff like the side-missions and ghost stories were cool.I guess there is some cons, though:-The stealth sections can get tedious because the Demons tend to be a little to smart and aggressive, I often found myself trapped because they got stuck in the alert state and wouldn't go back to the posts no matter how well I stayed hidden.-Some poor optimization, I know I said it runs well but it does tend to suffer from really inconsistant framerates, it can be at 55FPS one minute and 100FPS the next and the Vsync is useless because it looks it to 30FPS instead of to your screens refresh rate.-Some of the items are to well hidden, I missed out on two of the Ghost Stories because I just could not find the last items for either, and one location even locked me out of room that the levels last item was presumably in.-No kind of map, even though the "hub" area is pretty huge and maze-like.-Short, I spent just over 10 hours on it and that was a playthrough with a lot of messing about and finding A LOT of the bonus items. I imagine it would be under 5 hours if you ignored the side-missions. -Price, I think $30 is pushing it. I paid $4 during a sale and I'd say it's not worth more than $15, so wait for it to go on sale.

content:
er 3, 2014
												I saw this on the Halloween sale, I took the gamble and bought it, even after hearing mixed to negative reviews about this game.Let me put one thing straight, anyone who says this is a bad game have bad taste in video games. Murdered: Soul Suspect is a great 3rd person game that involves excellent crime solving elements. The game jumps straight into the action, revealling one of, if not the biggest plot twists in the entire game. After that, you must follow the notorious Bell Killer case around Salem and catch the serial killer, however, just when you thought there wouldn't be any combat in the game, you will face demons that will eat your soul when they find you. This now kinda makes this game like LA Noire + DmC + the detective bits from the Arkham games, which makes it well worth buying.

ry 9, 2016
												This game had a great idea, but fell so short... I played this game over several months and got to the next to last case. The "gameplay" was so bad the idea of spending another hour or two to complete the game was like working a job you don't get paid for. Which is a shame as there is a story and some okay characters... The gpx/controls/sound/engine/etc... were all  decent, but this should have been a pure puzzle/story game with more quests and logic puzzle type gameplay rather than the "demon" sections which ruined the flow and feel of the game.Needed more story and puzzles... while removing the stupid "demon" sectionsPS: This is a game which should take 6-8hrs to beat... the fact that I left it on my HD for so long just goes to show how little the story mattered when related to the boring gameplay... Again, good concept, poor execution...

content:
7, 2016
												A got premise doesn't make a good game.Pro:+ A very interesting concept behind the game (solve your own murder, be a ghost that can walk through everything else)Con:TL;DR: everything else-VSYNC limist the game to horrific 30 fps. disablign VSYNC leads to a lot of screen tearing (GTX 970)-Random performance issues on some maps-Video sequence graphics have worse graphics than actual ingame graphics... wtf-Extremely linear game-Horrible controls (e.g. you always have to look at stuff in a VERY exact angle while the normals XBOX controller controlls are much to sensitive, so you randomly happen to skip past this point...)-inaccuracy in opject / enemy targeting worsens the above issue-> if you LOVE having to redo a stage because of random targeting issues... or simply bugged targting... this is agame for you!-Only autosave, no normal save- Gathering achievement stuff feels unrewarding since the unlocked "story" for each part is sually less than 4 sentences and that's it...- You can "Poltergeist"-stuff to distract people... but unless it's story relevant they don't give a flying f()ck whether that coffee machien nearly explodes... but if you need to disctract them for a story mission they suddely notice a fan beign switched on 3 rooms away....-THE GAME IS EXTREMELY SHORT. I think I spent as much time as I spent playing in order to avoid the stupidly placed save points.... and redoing the same stuff again.... the game already is repetitive enough..-NPC dialogues are limited to very few lines which you'll get annoyed to hear over and over if you use the "possess" feature-Very few sidequests- F()cking overwhelmign amounts of product placement (Essentially every God damn computer in the police station is running Deus Ex Human Evolution... Once would have been a nice Easter Egg, so many are just annoying. Well, maybe the devs wanted to show that their company at least made one good game...)Summary:The idea behind the game is GREAT. It's a good damn shame that essentially everything else went wrong. This game was a pain to play through... To bad I also hate leaving games unfinished... Let me tell you: It's simpyl not worth it...Sidenote:Why does this game have a horror tag? Because it features ghosts? Finding out you already ate the last cookie is a bigger horror...

content:
ry 13, 2015
												As many of you know this game has issues, issues square enix aren't in a hurry to fix.. mainly related to the game not launching on many PC's. Luckily there are people out there who have fixed this.. and the link at the bottom is a youtube video that also links in its description to the files needed to sort it all out. :)Onto the review... This game was very enjoyable from start to finish. The story is great and the whole idea of playing a dead character solving his own murder is one I haven't seen done before and it was excuted perfectly in this game so welldone to the developers for that as in the wrong hands an idea like this just wouldn't have worked as well I feel.The games graphics and look were great. I ran it maxed out at 1080p on my Radeon 6870 with a quad core Athlon II cpu and 8gb of memory. I didn't experience any framerate issues that others have mentioned in the forums.. tho there was one part of the story that seemed to repeat itself at one point and I'm pretty sure that wasn't meant to happen as it made no sense, but the story continued fine after that little hiccup, not a major issue.Controls on the 360 controller were great, very easy to get into and layed out well. I never tried the keyboard/mouse for this game as I felt no need to, so can't comment on some comments form others about it not suiting keyboard/mouse.. considering the price of even a 3rd party wired 360 controller these days its not a problem worth moaning about and as i said, the 360 controller is fully supported and ideal for this game.The game is quite short compared to most large companies titles these days and can be completed in between probably 7 and 10 hours depending on whether to stick to the main story or want to collect everything and complete the side stories. I clocked a bit more than that as I was playing the game on a day I was ill to pass the time lol, so game was paused for periods of time while i was .. well... attending to being ill lol.I'd definitely recommend this game to anyone who likes games with a good story to unfold.. also its a bit different to the norm thats released these days. I hope Square-Enix and Airtight Games work together again on a similar title as I'd definitely buy it.. and hopefully they will learn from their game launching mistakes with this one.As stated the game launch problems are easily fixed using the files the guy links to on youtube for anyone that needs them.. (link below, view on youtube to see description and files link)I'll give the game 8/10 despite the shorter than usual gameplay and the fact I had to fix its launching problem. The score reflects the game itself and it was great.

content:
, 2014
												Is this a perfect game? No, not by a long shot, but then again, are there any perfect games which aspire to the complexity of narrative and gameplay as Murdered: Soul Suspect? As a narrative exercise, Murdered is very enjoyable. The stories of the various ghosts you encounter are always interesting and sometimes quite haunting. Ronan, the dead detective whom you play, may seem one dimensional at the beginning, but he is 'fleshed out', so to speak as you play, to at least TWO dimensions. But to mitigate this issue are some really interesting characters and stories, i.e. the aforementioned ghosts you meet. Some are quite affecting.The game is, for the most part, solidly built and I experienced no bugs or glitches while playing the game. Glimpses of Airtight Game's puzzle pedigry show through in several sections, though there is never an explicit focus on that kind of gameplay. Yet nor is there a focus on action. This a much more quiet and reflective gameplay experience, which I wonder is not an explanation of the game's poor reviews thus far. Certainly, it is not a blockbuster, but it feels more like an independent, more closely focused affair which I think many will enjoy if they are open to it.In many ways, I kept thinking about similar games I played in the 90s. Perhaps it was the interface itself or the mood or the package as a whole. The game is a throwback, so yes it does have obvious shortcomings. The living world which it hints at is very quickly revealed to be smoke and mirrors, but as already explained, I was fine with that. I liked the characters and the ideas and the game played smoothly. I do not regret slapping down the cash for this one.

content:
6, 2014
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is more of a point-and-click adventure game but with actual WASD movements. There isn't really any combat besides exorcising demons rarely from time to time (there aren't many throughout the game). You mostly look around spam clicking for clues and progressing through the story. A mentally challenged 2 year old monkey can beat this game. This isn't necessarily a bad thing though. If you want to just turn your brain off and enjoy an interesting story then this will be great! Think of it as an interactive movie.This game is rather short and linear even the "hidden" collectibles aren't very well hidden and tend to be right next to each other. But if you enjoy a good story and interesting characters it's a good game to play through once.

content:
, 2014
												I will agree with some of the reviews, that this is more like a movie, than a game. And this game gets negative reviews because people are expecting a game, not a movie. But if it was soemthing like "Wolf Among Us" ("The Walking Dead" is a bit off, sicne it's not a detective story), noone would have complained, I think. And if there were more choices, that influence the game, if collectibles did not only tell you some background, but also influenced the ending somehow, if saving ghosts influenced the story... There are a lot of ifs, that could have been covered if this was an episodic game and if it did not feel like pieces were cut off of it. And if it actually had a map IN the game, not on a web-page.But if you forget about all these, it's not a bad story. Yes, if the background told by the collectibles were more integrated in the main story, characters could become more... Real. Less flat. But overall, I actually enjoyed it. It has good dynamic: not too fast (since it's not an action game), but not too slow (as some detective quests can be), it has motivation, it has mistery.I think I'll give it 7/10. Maybe 7.5/10, since it kinda reminded me of Dreamfall (although Dreamfall had more gameplay). I wonder if Airtight Games can make something in similar fasion, while covering some negative points. Or they can simply try an approach closer to Telltale Games, I guess.

r 2, 2014
												I tend to give a game a lot of points if the idea of it is good and it looks good. This totally does, it's a cool film noir thing that's written like a paranormal TV show, in a good way. The 'detective' puzzles can be a little...wonky sometimes, abd a lot of them come down to trial and error. But even then it only takes a few minutes to really sort out which clue you need. The "combat" is kind of a sore spot, it's basically a stealth/reaction puzzle thing where you have to sneak up behind a demon, hold R, then press the WASD+mouse1/2 combination it shows you. Luckily the demons are pretty sparse. The focus is really on the atmosphere and the writing, which is actually super good.

content:
er 7, 2014
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is a pretty good game, as long as you recognize it for what it is and what it isn't. It's essentially a mystery adventure game but entirely lacking in inventory. The game play is fairly simple and most of the game is fairly easy and can be finished rather quickly. A lot of it is going from point to point, looking for clues, answering a few questions based on the clues, and moving onward. In that sense its got a lot of "novel as game" elements. It has a small semi-stealth-like action element that crops up a few times, but it is in no way an action game. While in some sense there's not much to the game play, it has a pretty good story and a lot of atmosphere. In addition to the main plot, there are a few side quest mysteries to solve, and a large number of collectables to find if you enjoy that aspect of games.Because the game play is fairly simple, moderately short, and its almost more of a game novel at times, the game is likely not worth full retail price, but if you can get it on sale and enjoy supernatural murder mysteries, it's a worthy pick up.

content:
, 2014
												So no idea why it's online reviews were so bad. I've been looking forward to this game for a long time and I wasn't disappointed at all. Think of it as LA Noireish with ghosts. It's got the whole detective thing going for it which I like a lot and wish was found more often. Pros: -Compelling story, made me sit down and play though it in one sitting, amazing.-Gameplay, if you like to walk around and discover everything then this is the game for you. It never gets dull, slow or too fast. Demons are there to change up gameplay and overall I enjoyed being a exorcist.-Graphics, beautiful game, love the art, everything looks great.-I found a few Just Cause 2 posters in the game.-Even though it's supernatural it doesn't feel fake/childish.-Writing, for the most part, was done very well.-Made me want to help the lost souls and feel rewarded for doing so.-Examples about people who throw their life away.-Good ending.Cons:-Short, only about 5 hours if you stick to the story and probably close to 6-7 if you want to 100% the game.-Character development, sometimes it felt like characters weren't developed enough for me but I like to know full blown backgrounds, I wouldn't say it was bad though.-Occasional frame drops.Overall: Solid game, would definitely recommend. Good luck in the afterlife!! Morals:Don't do drugs.Don't kill yourself.Don't hold grudges.Do something with your life.

content:
2, 2014
												Oh man, this game. Right from it's release, I somehow knew this game would really capture my interest. I picked it up at the Humble Store when they were doing a Square Enix Sale for $15. I do not regret paying that much, as this game really caught my attention.As far as gameplay goes, L.A. Noire players will find that it's a lot alike in terms of clues you must find and mysters that have to be solved. Of course, if you fail to connect the clues to the pending question of "who dun it", the game is more forgiving in that regard, as you get as many tries as it takes. Get it on your first try, however, and you get a better rank for that mission.There is "combat" in this game, but this is the one and only thing about this game that really was shallow. The "demons" that all of the ghosts within the plot are afraid of are nothing more than easy prey for the protagonist. What was supposed to be a game of cat and mouse where the demons were the cats, actually felt very flopsided, as every demon encounter I had within Murdered: Soul Suspect felt like mice, and I more than likely felt like the cat in multiple situations. I really felt like the purpose of having demons within the game was really undermined, thus, it fell very flat on it's face.The overall plot to this game is where it really shines. Within each level, it's a consistent game of "who dun it" as I mentioned earlier. Each solved case supposedly brings you one step closer to unmasking a pertty good villain: The Bell Killer, keyword "supposedly". I found that whom I thought it was all this time turned out to be completely and utterly wrong, and the game laughed in my face for having me think it'd be whom the clues all pointed to.As an added bonus, within each level you can find these artifacts that, when you collect them all, tell a ghost story about the specific surrounding that you find yourself in. Because of this, I will happily be replaying Murdered: Soul Suspect so I can listen and bask in the ghostly horror of these stories.Overall, this game was great, although a bit short. At it's current price tag of $50, one might be a tad disappointed. Wait for a sale, however, and you'll truly enjoy the ghostly world that is Murdered: Soul Suspect.

content:
23
												There's a lot of good to be found in this game, but it is ultimately let down by its length, scope, and incredibly frustrating 'combat' mechanics.You play as Ronan, a newly-deceased detective on the trail of the same serial killer that had just taken his life. In his new ghostly form, he possesses powers of teleportation, x-ray vision, and some other supernatural capabilities in addition to his police skills.The game is fully linear in nature with some detours (small side stories), but ultimately railroads players down a single, short path. Taking my time to look around, I ended up clocking just under 10 hours on my playthrough, but your mileage may vary here. In addition to basically being a one-track experience, the game heavily relies on collectibles to flesh out its characters, setting, and lore; a bad design decision as not everyone may be inclined to seek out every little hidden detail. All Steam Achievements are tied into this as well; if you collect all 242 collectibles, you have 100% completion outside of surviving the final 'boss battle'.Nonetheless, if you are a fan of murder mysteries, point 'n click games, and supernatural stuff in general, Murdered might be worth a look during a sale (you want to go for 90% off, like I did). That being said, don't expect a groundbreaking ride; interest in the aforementioned things will justify a cheap price tag on this game, but little more than that.If you have no strong interest in the above genres, steer clear of this game; short on content, zero replayability, horribly implemented and hamfisted combat, some bewildering design decisions, and suffocating linearity (with plenty of walls to stifle your progress) will kill most enjoyment you can get out of this game. Additionally, the developers closed down less than a month after release, which is pretty ironic considering the sense of wanting to get things over with the ending has about it. A shame considering the likable protagonist, but the closest the game comes to outright telling you you shouldn't have bothered.

content:
4, 2014
												While I have said I wouldn't recomend it I do have some positive points as well as negative ones.I will admit the concept is quite a fun one, a dead cop investigating his own death however I feel this game suffers from Remember Me syndrome. A good, interesting concept with bags of potential that has a half arsed delivery. It also feels like a dumbed down L.A Noire, that maybe a bit harsh actualy but anyway it still holds your hand through the investigations that are implemented a lot like L.A Noire. The twist is ok and frankly I was quite a head of the investigation before that point anyway and the rest of the game was basicaly confirming my theories. The controls are also very odd. Exorcising demons, which I swear is never explained how the main character and only him can do it however I may have just missed that or didn't pay attention, involves holding the R then pressing either W,A,S,D and the left mouse button. Now I'm sorry but this is just too much, a 3 button QTE is just too much, it's a QTE not a think for a bit to make sure I have the right button because if you don't your going to have to run fast. These demons are quick and kill quick too, they also freak me out a lot but that might be just me. The mouse is also super sensitive and it took me a while to get used to it even on the lowest setting. The cat controls are ridiculous too and seems to be slightly less broken than Radscorpions, which is saying a lot as they are the most glitchy animals in a game, ever. Oh and the game is too short, and the escort parts are silly as the people your escorting won't move till a distraction happens to lead the person away....who is standing still at the time, not actively searching...so those being escorted are never in any real danger, so it's a tad pointless. On the whole, good concept, average delivery and worth £10 on sale, definatly not full price though.Check out my youtbe channel for lets plays and commentary every Monday and Fridayhttp://www.youtube.com/channel/UC2l1zwMcpJm_hJq4owO3nHg

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												The game is actually pretty good. Short, but good. The story is absolutely fantastic - well written, well presented. There are a couple of problems I encountered - keyboard controls felt awkward, so I had to switch to xbox controller, the whole "investigation" thing is pretty linear. But what saved this game for me was the sheer amount of LORE and background for everything happening and what happened. Hell, even the town and some of it's past events are real. But also not only you can "read" newspaper articles or you dead wife's diaries - you can also poke around the city to find some ghostly remains of city's past, reveal some well-narrated backstories and so on.It is pretty linear in it's investigations, but outside them you have your town which is kind of open-worldish, but not really. Nice little touch is the ability to read people's minds - and even though they sometimes repeat - the amount of "thoughts" is pretty big and also reveals some lore.The "ghost" mechanic is great and executed well - the only bad thing I can name is that in tight spaces (there are not a lot of them, but still) you can easily lose your sense of space because of your "ghost noclip" ability. Oh, and demons are kind of annoying, but not too much, and they are pretty rare.The real bad thing is that this game is pretty short. If you ignore all nice details you can possibly complete it in 6 or 5 hours. With all the poking around it will take around 9-10, but not more. Though the story is good, really good. The whole story made me not regret buying it.8/10

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 22, 2015
												I REALLY wanted to like this.  The premise was unique (you're a detective and you need to find out who murdered you).  But this was just not enjoyable.The game is short.  By itself, this isn't a big deal, you don't need to put 40+ hours into a game to get your money's worth.  My playtime was 9 hours.  But I'm guessing 4 of those were spent fighting with the game's poor systems:1) No Map.  Seriously?  What is this 2004?  In a 3rd person exploration game this is unheard of & seems like it was omitted to add unnecessary time & difficulty.  Wandering about town, there is a series of intermediate waypoints that lead you to the next target, but those get broken & send you through areas that aren't available, so unless you're a navigational expert, you're stuck randomly wandering until you luck into the next target.2) Combat.  It's basically added as an afterthought to add time in between the "investigations" (which are generally well done, once you figure out the game's systems).  There's one monster type & it's pattern is easily identifiable.  But the controls are difficult & even if you do everything right you still might get caught & have to redo the area.  The game is using poor controls & frustration to again add extra difficulty & time, instead of giving the enemies useful AI.The graphics are fine, but suffer from overusing a "dark & hazy" theme.  Considering the story takes place entirely at night, this is probably expected.I was engaged enough with the setting & story enough to want to finish it, but definitely won't be replaying to get a 100% finish.

content:
r 31, 2014
												To start off there is only 4 hours of gameplay here and no replay value. It is basically an interactive movie. It is a murder mystery. For me this game/movie was kind of boring... Not very fun for a video game. I feel sorry for those who paid full price. I guess I got my $12 worth out of this game since it's cheaper than going to the movies to kill 4 hours. This is a Crime, Drama, Murder, Mystery. I'd say I've been bored for 4 hours since I just wanted to finish the story. It wasn't worth it for myself. There was no challenge at all... Just go here investigate this and that help this person do this get here blah blah blah.... Just boring.Killing demons isn't even satisfying and it's also a very small part of the game to add a challenge... It's not challenging at all. Just get behind the demon hold R then you will have to hit W, A, S, or D with left or right click, it's completely random which is cool but i'd rather actually battle the demon with something more interactive. But yeah do that and the demon is dead YAYYYY!!! Or you can just skip killing demons and go to your next location... doesn't matter.This game is only worth $12 or less. For a single-player only game for $50 when it released and only 4 hours of gameplay if you don't care about finding every stupid hidden piece in the world. I just went where I needed to go and picked up what I could along the way. Most single-player 3rd person / 1st person games have around 8 hours average if not a little longer and also have replay value majority of the time.Bought it, played it, completed it, never playing it again, the end.

												Criminal turned detective stumbles upon a killer and end up dead. Insted of going into the light, he becomes a ghost, resolved to reveal who murdered him. It's an adventure game, most similar to LA Noire. You go around, detect and inspect clues, listen onto the conversations, talk to other ghosts, walk through the walls, think, make hypothesis, solve mysteries, and reveal the story step by step. There's no much action, but there are stealth sequences, where you have to detect demons, and destroy them before they find you. A lot of optional content (side quests, world information, character info and all that) to be found. Nice graphics and sound, a bit weird controls but one can easily get used to them. I like it.

												So... this game...Well, I got it as part of a Humble Bundle, so I cannot complain about it as such - it was an interesting experience.HOWEVER, had I bought it as a stand-alone game on Steam, I'd be very dissapointed.Visually impressive (to a degree at least) the game is filled with a bit too many collectable quests (get X of Y to unlock something). The investigations are sensible 50% of the time - the other half just felt I was wrong becuase the scriptwriter went for a really surreal story. Finally, the ending... well, I don't wish to spoil things, but what a cop out. On the gameplay side of things... someone decided that to build tension they need to throw in demons into the mix (either in the form of demonic "pools" on the ground or "sentries" that patrol the area). Suffice it to say it doesn't build tension, but it does slow the pace even more, and is purely annoying. Oh, and speaking of the pace - I really wish the character could make a like a ghost and move faster. Getting anywhere is a pain.PS. The game is also buggy. Because the developer is long gone, don't hold your breath for a fix for any bugs you may encounter.

												To be honest I expected better with this game. Better story, better mechanics, better gameplay, better graphics.  The story is probably the best part. It wasn't too obvious and had a lot twists and turns to it. That being said it does have some glaring flaws.  Some of the gameplay is fun for a while but the problem I found is that you begin with almost all the powers you will have at the end. This leaves no room for a feeling of character progression and development. It has some buggy mechanics such as having to stand at the exact right spot to interact with certain things. The graphics seem very last gen. I also HATE the stupid demon killing thing. It's very repetitive and an all round pain in the ♥♥♥ to have to take them out. Negatives aside, I wouldn't say the game was terrible. If you enjoy story based games, in particular, ghost/horror/noir based games. You may enjoy those aspects enough to warrant you buying it. I would say, buy it if it's on sale.

Once again, not horrible if a lot of your play is based on the story and not difficulty.The only piece outside of being the detective was the part about the demons, the cobat part. This was horrid in my opinion. When there were demons I just sighed. It was annoying. I wish there was an option to turn off the demons, like "turn off useless boring combat mechanic that doesn't matter." Maybe others like it, but in my opinion it was just annoying.Overall it is a decent game, as long as you can stick through lame-o combat (which there is not a lot of thankfully, and you can walk by most of it) and fairly easy riddles and puzzles for you to solve. Worth the seven dollars on sale.OH, and, minor spoiler I guess....why did they try to make it a surprise when some of the murders were based on witch killings? The game takes place in Salem, why would this EVER be surprising? It would be wierd if the witch trials didn't make an appearance...

content:
y 4, 2015
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is a game where you play as a detective named Ronan, who dies during a chase for the Bell Killer, who has been killing young women of Salem, Massachusetts.  Ronan is your typical cliche chain-smoking detective, wearing the fedora and vest, and talking with a low, raspy voice.In M:SS, you have constant flashbacks of how you died, and you need to figure out why, because you find out you are stuck in a limbo spirit world, and will be stuck there forever until you find out what you need to find out.  As you solve these cases of the Bell Killer killings to "release your soul", you travel through Salem as a ghost, able to walk through many walls and obstacles, viewing the real world as it progresses (without you) and spirits trapped as you are, along with ghostly residue of things that have happened in the past.As a ghost detective, you will solve cases and ask questions of other ghosts and spirits, find clues at crime scenes and put cases together, and use an abundance of ghost abilities, such as possession, transportation, and reading minds, to name a few.M:SS is a very unique game of the supernatural, and pretty interesting, but it has many flaws that ruin the flow of the game.  While playing detective can be very fun to a lot of crime solvers, the method in which you solve these crimes is a bit silly.  You simply inspect all the clues in the surrounding area, then "solve" the portion of the case by piecing it together with the clues you found.  The problem is, it's like putting together a puzzle where all the pieces are numbered and fool-proof...so it doesn't feel like you are solving much of anything.The worst and most obnoxious part of the game, however, is the combat system.  Yes--the combat system--as a ghost.  Occaisonally, you will come across demons, and you must use stealth to take them out with a clunky, button-sequenced execution mechanic.  If you fail, you have to retreat and hide in "ghost residue" until they leave.  The combat could have been completely been left out and it would have made the game better.However, even with the terrible combat system, and the goofy crime scene mechanics, the story is interesting and the collectibles you find are fun to read.  I recommend this game, but not very high, and only for about $15-20 or less.  All in all, I rate the game a 7.0 out of 10.

content:
0, 2014
												I picked up Murdered: Soul Suspect because a good friend kept stressing how good it is (in spite of all the negative reviews), and I wasn't at all disappointed with the game. In fact, I enjoyed it a lot more than I ever thought I would! The game relies largely on its characters and the murder mystery that's central to said characters' lives. If you're looking for a fast-paced, highly action-driven game, it doesn't deliver on that front - but that's what made it such a great ride for me as a player.I wasn't sure what to expect of the game from the premise alone, but it does atmospheric horror really well, along with the splashes of detective fiction and noir, too. Investigating, gathering clues, questioning witnesses, and making deducions are all important to the game. It even has an historical angle that I first thought would be somewhat canned, but actually surprised me a bit by the end.Collecting is an important part of the game and, although it's "optional," a lot of the story content depends on how well you can scour a map for all of the items - some hidden and some not. Even with ~10 hours play time into my first "completed" game, I still didn't track everything down! So if you're a completionist who enjoys searching and interacting with maps, M:SS definitely appeals on that front.The other main challenge of the game is demon encounters, and they can be tricky to master at first, since some of the combinations are a little awkward. Still, by the last few maps it seems easier (as the difficulty doesn't really go up much during the course of the game) ... but it's definitely anxiety-inducing sometimes! All in all, the demon encounters kept the game from feeling extremely linear (i.e., like a visual novel).So if you're into mysteries and crime fiction, love spooky stuff, and enjoy a game that burns a little slowly, definitely give it a try.

content:
, 2014
												A hidden gem or a rusty stone To some players, this game popped up from nowhere in the Square Enix's catelogue. However, some players has been following this game from E3 2013 and has been building up alot of anticipations and pre-release hype. Based on the original concepts, authentic setttings and unique mechanics, this game definitely delivers.In this epic detective meets criminal adventure heavily inspired by the likes of L.A. Noire and Alan Wake players takes the role of detective Ronan O'Connor who happens to find himself being killed by the mysterious 'bell killer'. He then not only find himself dead in the real world but simultaneous alive in another dimension like the movie 'ghost'. Determined to find out who the killer was, Ronan embarked on a endless investigation to solve the mysteries behind his death and discover the dark secret behind Salem's ancient history of witchcraft.By playing as a ghost, you gain awesome abilities such as no clipping through walls, possessing people, poltergeist electronic devices to attract attentions, and if these aren't enough you can possess a cat and go 'meow'.By poeessing common folks around the town, you are given the options mind read their thoughts. However, most of the things they say provide little to no useful information at all which makes it pointless at any point of the game. Some NPCs such as police officers will allow player to obtain useful clues regarding the cases often by means of eavesdropping, peeking through their eyes and influence their decision making.By possessing the cat, you gain access to platforming sections of the game which often will help you to get to a upper level.The detective elements of the game was not as good as L.A Noire, investigation can help you gather clues and the amount of clues needed for each case was given to players. Interrogation can only be done on other ghosts and it involves picking from limited options and are way too easy most of the time it is just common sense. With enough clues gathered, players can conclude the current investigation by chossing pieces of important information. Players are given 3 chances and even if you selcted the incorrect choices, the game will give you infinite tries leading to eventually picking out the correct information by trials and error.This idiotically defeats the purpose of giving 3 tries and has way too much hand holding throughout the story. Whereas, in L.A noire inability to solve crimes often can have consequences and investigation cannot be done again once it is concluded.The combat is however interesting as player gain ability to see demons through walls to allow advanced planning of strategies and make decisions to whether encounter or avoid. Most of the battle requires player to teleport between human remain souls to get behind the demons to perform execution called 'exorcism'. However, the game has only one enemy type and every encounter feels the same and after a while it gets repetitive.The environment is also quite boring with little open world elements, no interactive NPCs, and bland design choices that players often just walking around for collectibles, side cases or towards the next objective. Speaking of side quests and collectibles. It can be a real chore as the game has little replay value so you gasically back tracking for the sake of it. There are no incentives or rewards for doing it apart from some achievements for completing a side case or a set of collections.Characters have little personality development throughout the game, most of the time I find it hard to relate to most of them. If the story wasn't decent enough to make me continue playing I just cannot think of much selling point in this game.Techniquelly, there has been occassional frame rate drop issues and stuttering problems which is annoying but still playable. When booting up the game for the first time, the screen also flickers a few times but I won't rate a game based on these minor issues as it can be simply fixed with a update or two.Is this a good game?I think overall, yes it is a good game if you like story driven adventure that doesn't involve all out shooting and straightout combat. Its appeal really comes from a real life location and interesting depiction of Salem's ancient history and traditions with a unique play style, it can be really appreciative. If you can ignore the problems present and look at the good side of things plus the price they are asking for, I would say it is worth a try.Final verdictMurdered: soul suspect is far from perfect or a masterpiece if you compare it to similar games such as L.A noire and Alan Wake. But it borrows what is good from both titles and add its own twists which some think it is good and some simply may not like it.Finally, I think it is one of those game that should be played but just don't expect 100% perfection and a fully immersive world and rather expect a rough around the edges unque title to try in 2014.7/10

content:
3, 2014
												Having seen footage of the very first part of the game, I was curious about the story. The characters and detective esque gameplay seemed interesting. So, I purchased the game and have only just finished it. The game is about a detective who has to find the mystery behind his own murder. This game was played with a 360 controller.Lots of text following, so:tldr; amazing cat simulator, 10/10serious tldr; Only buy if you are interested in the story only and not in it as a game. And only then when it is on sale.numbers tldr;Gameplay      [3/10] - not much of itWorld            [2/10] - felt emptyStory             [6.7/10] - not as exciting or interesting as I hoped, but still good. Narrated short side stories were very entertaining, and eerie. Graphics        [6/10] - adequateSound            [5/10] - nothing noteworthy or memorable, but adequateVoice Acting   [6.7/10] - mixed feelings, bland NPCs are bland, main characters are quite okay.You can move freely as a ghost, passing through real world objects such as walls. The design here is quite well done, clipping through objects felt quite natural in this game and definitely was an interesting experience. You grow quite quickly accustomed by it, and by the time you do the novelty of it does wear off as fast (atleast it did for me). Even though you can pass through some objects, ghostly objects and certain walls still limit you. More and more as you progress through the game, making it feel like any other regular game. Gameplay wise, throughout the story you encounter different "crime" scenes and are left to examine it. This involves some looking around, and depending on how many of the clues you want to find and how adept you are at it, it could take 5 to 10 minutes. It does not involve more than walking around the crime scene and pressing X to interact with an object. Sometimes,  the game wants you to be slightly more involved by asking you to, for example, select which of 3 objects matches the sound being played. More often than not, the sound and belonging object combination were quite far fetched in my opinion.  Another type of clue is when you "reveal" a memory of the scene. You get to see a person and need to select out of a bunch of choices what the person was doing or experiencing, again a selection of 3 to be made. When you have collected enough clues, you can "solve" the scene by combining the most relevant clues to mystery at that time (such as: "What was person X doing here?"). For each of these elements, the player has 3 tries to get it right. When the player fails within those 3 tries, I believe it doesn't quite matter and the counter stays at 1. I'm not sure of this, since I've at most only had it happen to me once in the beginning of the game.The player moves from scene to scene through the town of Salem, which is filled with bland NPCs. You have the option to possess them and read their thoughts, which more often than not are only 2 of. Once you listen to a thought, you can't quit it either, and have to wait for the voice to finish talking. Other options the player rarely has when possessing an NPC is to "Influence" their thoughts (pick the most likely clue out of a bunch to try help the person remember something useful) or to "Peek" meaning watch through their perspective to see what they see. These are only ever useful with NPCs at a scene, not random NPCs spread throughout town (whom, by the way, all look similair and mostly have the exact same thoughts). You can sometimes hear them converse with eachother, which is a nice element to the game to give it a bit more depth and make it seem more alive, but it is not far enough to stop the NPCs and the town of Salem feel bland and empty.Other actions the player can use as a ghost is "Reveal" (hold R to reveal a ghostly object), "Remove" (hold R to remove a ghostly object) and "Teleport" (hold LB and release to teleport at an aimed location). In a nutshell, the actions the player has available to him are very limited and do not add much to a gameplay perspective value. To try and make the game more exciting (dare I say challenging?) they have added two enemies to the game: demons and a pool of demon grasping hands. When you walk over the second one it grabs you and you need to press a random direction combined with a button to get out. Once you figure this out it succesfully into like any other wall you can't pass through. Demons patrol certain areas, once they see you they try to suck your soul which means game over. You need to avoid being seen by them, meaning hiding in certain "Ghost residue" or simply behind walls. You can sneak up on them from behind and execute them by, again, pressing a given direction and button. Bland. Annoying. Nothing more than a nuisance.I believe we've arrived at the final gameplay element, which is the cat. Yes, you can take over the cat and move around for some basic platforming action thing. If one could even call it that, as you're basically still just walk around, except sometimes with a jumping or climbing animation. The most interesting thing for me were the short narrated ghost stories, which could be unlocked by collecting a bunch of objects. The problem with this though, was that you had to actively search around to try and find the objects, sometimes 14 of them. And you needed all of them. Got 13 and can't find the last one? Too bad, you get nothing. I would have really liked it if the developers had changed it so that you only needed to find half of them, because a game such as this that only has the story going on for it would do well to cater the only players still playing by giving them these greatly narrated short stories. The characters in the game were alright, there's a bit of character progression going on and you learn the relationships between them. The main character is enjoyable to get to know, and thinks and behaves like a real person. It was good enough to keep me interested. The game can be finished within a day's playtime if you want. I've got about 12 hours on it including afk time and searching for most of the side clues.If you enjoy the story, I recommend just watching a playthrough on YouTube or something and skipping through boring parts. I can only recommend the purchase of this game if you are truly interested in the concept of it and would like to see more (better!) of it by supporting the developers, and even then only on a heavy sale. €40,- for a game as this is severely overpriced, unfortunately.

												★★★★☆I had great fun with this game, the plot always had me playing to the next point to see what is going to happen. That said this is obviously a plot oriented game, everything you do is to further the plot or to give you more information that informs you in a direct or indirect way to what is happening, going to happen or has happened before. Don't expect any 3rd person shooter action in this game, that is not what it is about, it is about finding your murderer and running away (and sapping) demons. So no shooting, only talking and running XD.Okay now that that is all said and done, just a quick summary, it is a good game, definitely worth the money if you like mysteries. I would give this game a full rating but there were a few annoyances I had while playing. The textures are quite crappy in most cases, especially if the cutscenes would zoom up to the people talking, then you can see just how non "high quality" the textures are, but that’s still fine, I can get use to that. But what bugged me the most was that to play the game I had to launch it 5 times every time -_- because the game would automatically flag itself if is set to be fullscreen, for some bloody reason, so I had to open the game, close it, open it, close it, flag it open and close, open and close, and just hope it will not auto flag itself afterward.Now that said this game still gets a 4/5 from me :) enjoy, and hopefully you won't have the annoyance I did.

 So, Hear Me Out, I'm Going to Do Something A Bit Different Here I bought this game for next to nothing on Humble Bundle a while ago and played it awhile ago. Now I'm giving this a positive rating because I enjoyed it for what it was for how cheap I got it at. That said, I am going to give you a dual opinion here. You will hear the side of me who got it cheap and you will hear a side of me who bought as if it were 60 dollars. So, to be fair, I will ♥♥♥♥♥ for both sides. Let's begin.Legend1 - 60 dollar opinion2 - 2 dollar opinion (around the price I bought it for)(1)ARE YOU ♥♥♥♥ING KIDDING ME!!!! 60 dollars for less than a 5 hour experience? I forgot this was an interactive movie. This David Cage ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t is really ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off where game developers think a good short story is enough to justify a 60 dollar purchase for a "Video Game" as in you play the ♥♥♥♥ing game. Sure, the story is decent but the game play is ♥♥♥♥. No wonder so many people were ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off about this interactive story, it lacks meat, it has almost no game in it. Now you have to follow some teen girl around because shes the only one that will put up with your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t or rather is the only one who can since no one else can hear you since shes psychic that has to listen to whiny ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s like your character who can't handle being dead so he has to find out which ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ killed him. Of course, I don't give a ♥♥♥♥ since the main character is easily forgetable, hell there's interesting side characters I remember more than him that are in this game.(2)The game will start off with your character, Ronan, literally dying in the first 2 minutes after starting. The game had a good story and even though lack of game play was present here, at least for the price I got a worthwhile experience and an interesting concept of a story. While the game play does lack, it does have pretty entertaining parts to it at times. These times being the investigation parts where you, as the ghost, investigate crime scenes finding things that humans can't quite find. The game makes you pick 3 evidence that you found to match up a story but there's really no penalty here, the game will just move along and that's that.(1)Speaking of the "game play" there is "stealth" sections but they aren't stealth, its just waiting for someone to turn the ♥♥♥♥ around or setting off a printer so that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ can check it for eternity while you guide a teenage psychic around. You can also possess this teen or other humans so you can pass certain sections you can't get through by yourself. Yeah, this is the first Triple A game where it encourages you to go inside a teenage girl, ♥♥♥♥ing perverts. You also can possess animals as well, so now for 60 dollars I can go inside a teenage girl and a cat, was this concept straight out of Jared Fogle's computer history? You also can read their mind and hear what they're thinking if you're a nosy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. This game also presents you with a linear open world where you can't travel through certain walls, cause ♥♥♥♥ it, right? They came up with some sort of an excuse but I forget what it was.(2)The game play, or what is there rather, consists of stealth sections, while linear, are more like puzzles you have to solve. You guide the teenage psychic through a dangerous area, like, a Police Station or a Mental Hospital. You just distract somebody one certain way and you move her on. Sometimes they might switch it up but essentially its the same kind of pattern. There's also collectables...(1) Who gives a ♥♥♥♥ about the stupid collectables.(2) ....That I can agree with. So, they're not hard to find but with a game with little content in it, I doubt it'll reward you in anyway besides giving you behind the scenes videos to watch. The open world is hard to traverse at times since its got a lot of invisible and visible walls up to block you way. It can be a boring and confusing process but for being a slow game in the first place, it won't affect the flow too much unless you are on your way to a dangerous event taking place. You also have to use these ghostly hiding places where you can hide from demons when they are hunting you down. You can go about two ways of taking care of demons in most situations, one: You ambush all of them and send them back to hell or you take out who you have to and move on leaving the others alone.(1) The voice acting is meh, but I'm not here to listen to ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, I want to play a ♥♥♥♥ing game. Why is that for 60 dollars that out of my 3-5 hours I have to sit here and listen to an hour total of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t? This game is like the Order 1886 before the the Order 1886. Sure, the atmosphere is creepy and the demons you have to hide from are scary, however, the story is decent, like I said. But there's still no game here. I don't get why this game got a 9/10 for 4 hours of story and almost no gameplay. The game play itself isn't even innovative, why is no one else ♥♥♥♥♥♥ about this?(2)I thought the voice acting was pretty good and the scenes were shot well, although not perfectly. I did enjoy the story and the characters moving around were realistic looking, like they're actually just human beings, they have casual movement and the lip syncing isn't even that bad. Overall, it makes it more believable of a story.(1)Overall, for 60 dollars, its an over glorified movie and its game play is almost non-existent. Its a sad attempt at a game but a good attempt at an interactive movie. Of course, it should be this expensive, you greedy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s over at Square Enix need to stop ruining the game industry damn it. You ♥♥♥♥ing ruined Deus Ex Mankind Divided cause of your ♥♥♥♥ing greed you mother..(2)Unless you can get it for the price I got it at, which is dirt cheap, yeah, just look it up on YouTube or something if you don't wanna buy into it since its just a movie and not much more than that.

content:
ry 28, 2015
												this game is an absolute disappointmentbut before i start raging i must pause and give a thumbs-up to the interesting plot that this game has. and that's about it what can anyone enjoy the game. maybe some shallow gamers could also enjoy it for the graphics but don't get me even started on those.anyways, there is absolutely no gameplay. the whole "game" consits of boring pixel hunting, after which you are asked absolutely dumb "detective" questions, which often don't even make sense and would make even CSI-miami look like a decent detective movie (which it is not). basically, it has absolutely nothing to do with playing a detective.the hours of boredom spent by pixel hunting for "clues" and collectible artifacts are accompanied by an absolutely ridiculously primitive "stealth action", which consists of walking behind a wall with ghost infravision or whatever and just killing these demons with a press of a button. and the game does not even punish you for getting noticed because you just run away, hide and return later, and try to press the "KILL GHOST BUTTON" again. and if you are incompentend enough and manage to get killed somehow, i don't know, maybe a dog jumped in your face or something, then you respawn 1 milliseond and 1 millimeter before the enemy encounter, because the checkpoints and saves are almost literally made after your character makes a step. (honestly, i have not gotten killed a single time during the game, except for once when i wondered what would actually happen if i got killed on purpose)honestly, just reading these few paragraps written with my terrible english will probably be a time spent better than trying to enjoy the gameplay of this excuse of a modern "press x to win" game. but as i said earlier, the story is cool and the little ghost tales told for collecting items during the abrasive pixel hunting are interesting as well. i would much rather watch a 1 hour long B-movie made from this story than die in agony wandering through the streets of the boredom town to get to the story.this was a terrible experience, and screw the money but i want the time back. the time. give me back my time.PS. before you dismiss the review because i have 0.1 hours of the game played on the record, i played it with steam in the offline mode and it just didn't register my playtime

content:
, 2014
												I'd only recommend this game for its story only - in no way is this game worth the full price and it doesn't live up to what a game should be (some good gameplay elements but not used very well).This game is more fitting for a movie than a game since the whole "clue" thing is very much compulsory to proceed in the story line. The investigation aspect is forced on to you on each level and spoon feeds you on what you need to do, meaning that the harder-to-find clues aren't even necessary and have no impact in the game, making it a linear story. Side quests are almost non-existent despite it showing some potential with some of the ghosts you talk to - most of which, there is nothing to persuade them to move on from the living world. It has much potential but it dies down and you realize that everything you thought was cool, becomes repetitive and or unnecessary. Gameplay/Story aside, there are annoying technical issues with this game - only one save file is allowed and the autosave is terribly planned. If you're unlucky, like me, you'd have spent some time and lose all your progress with side quests (did two side quests and quit the game, only to find out that the game didn't save). The game's vsync is garbage, your video driver's vsync produces better results.To sum things up, the game aspects of this game are great but not used well to keep you entertained for long. The only things that could keep you entertained would be the story and that depends per user's preference. The autosave feature sucks, it only saves during main quest and when you enter/exit places. It doesn't save on the town map at all.[Possible spoiler regarding gameplay]The teleport and remove abilities are barely used in this game, making you wonder "whats the point of having this?". In the end, you only use the teleport ability for travel conveniences rather than to get past obstacles like how it was originally introduced to you. Remove ability is pretty much dead in the game, there's no point of having it. I'm quite ok with the monsters but other people may have issues with them. The demons need more variety. There are only 2 types of monsters that get in your way and it's those same 2 from beginning to end. Their availability in the game are very rare and illogical - you don't see them in the open map and only during story related quests. The investigation/clues - some answers are stupid and doesn't fit well in what you are observing, others are so obvious. As mentioned before, the important clues are in your face and you're forced to use them as your evidence. You won't be able to proceed unless you use those set pieces.The AI ... at first, you think it's cool but as you play on and interact with the non-quest related AI, it all becomes repetitive. They all say the same things and they don't react when you use poltergeist... they're there for decoration and nothing more.

content:
er 5, 2014
												I LOVED this game. But I'll confess to having a bit of a bias due to how firmly this game dug into a favorite subject of mine storywise - laying the dead to rest/bringing peace to the restless dead. The story is dark, intriguing, and I count it among those rare ones where I couldn't figure out where plot twist was going ahead of time.PROS:-Superb storytelling-Excellent quality voice acting-Graphically gorgeous and expressively animated-Tons of exploration-Tons of stuff to collect as a reward for exploring-Interesting story-related things unlocked by finishing collections-Controls overall translated well from controller to keyboard-Intriguing puzzle system.-Very good 'beacon' system to get you from goal to goal along the mainstoryline.Cons:-Barely-there combat system. It fit the feel of the game (I'm serious about this), but anybody looking for more than light stealth sections are going to be disappointed.-No map whatsoever. This can be particularly frustrating when trying to track down collectibles.Verdict: Very, very good, excellent game, just not for everybody.

												This title looked fantastic when I first read about it and watched the teasers. Then I watched the first few minutes of gameplay, coupled with reviews, and (wrongly) came to the conclusion that is was a hidden object game/single-room puzzler wrapped in a 3rd person Unreal Engine. Not the case at all. While the puzzling is not brain taxing in the slightest, the story is interesting and the setting can be almost beautiful in places. There is no horror to be found, unless you found Peter Jackson's Frighteners scary. Were it designed for grown-ups instead of E for Everyone it could have been so much more.Despite it's flaws, I found it enjoyable and sometimes hard to put down.

content:
er 5, 2014
												Really awesome game, painfully short.  Game is pretty easy, really no penalty for wrong answers to investigations.  It's also really linear.  But regardless I found myself really enveloped in the world and lore, I found myself finishing it quickly within 3 settings, totalling 10 hours.  If I could say one are I did not like were the demons (enemies) in the game, the only way to beat them is to use a QTE that lasts no more than 1 second on screen that randomizes each time; if you fail you need to hide for a good 30 seconds to a minute if not more each time.  If more than one demon is chasing you, good luck - just kill yourself and restart at checkpoint because I *never* was able to elude more than one demon at a time.The story is fanstastic, the voice acting is above average bordering on great.  There is an awesome twist right at the end and the culprit, in the realm of the gameworld, is believeable and throughly explained.  However it has very little to no replay value.  I would really like to see a sequel with a more fleshed out overworld and maybe branching paths or consequences to your choices.I give the game a 4 out of 5

content:
1, 2014
												WELL! just finished it (12 hours gameplay... really tryed to enjoy it).... WELL...where to start?first: was waiting for this game 2 months... big expectations.... preordered and waitedsecond: limited edition - there was a small journal (i have a phys. game DVD limited ed.) - nice small book, interesting reading.... no spoilers... just some "background" info... nicethird: the game.... well... the story is great i think, the end surprised me. Nice twist. I guessed another ending :) The story, i mean the IDEA of this game is great/unique. The afterlife and etc. Many ghost NPC - some interesting, some useless. The living NPCs on the streets.. .well... the city was a bit dead .... empty. (many repeatitive toughts and lines, etc...) not enought side quests.The gameplay.... not bad, but not superb...  I think the action passages were..... the fighting part was for 3rd time boring. But the demons were great (mean the design, not their skills or AI)I think 2-3 months more for betatesting to correct flaws and changes in gameplay, this game could have been PERFECT  (9 from 10) but maybe next time!But now... one playthrout and I think I never play it again. There are flaws for me I cant never forget....Dont buy it for full price or you become angry. Trust me.  (10-15 euros, or sale)In past, Ive played fahrenheit (indigo prophecy) and both Alan Wakes (game and expansion)... I think this game is first for me, then Alan Wake, and then fahrenheit. Didnt liked the Alan Wake supernatural part, and fahrenheits either. But this was more believable. I really want to try Beyond 2 souls and heavy rain, but i dont have a ps3 and they never make it for PCs.I can tell Im satisfied... And I think theyve made a room for a sequel maybe...I give it a 7 (i dont care for the reviews) this game is: you love it or hate it... no other way. And I loved it more like hated it.Fans of deep story adventures are welcome... the others... well.... you can try (but dont forget, not the full price) :)7And one more thing - the MC was great. He played it very well(he had a great style and personality). And all others too. Like a theatre.
