content:
, 2014
												Murdered: Soul Suspect is a typical Square Enix title story-wise, however it falls short on game length, suspense based on its genre and some pretty slow controls. What do I mean by slow controls? I mean that walking is more like shuffling and the run option is nothing more than a fast paced walk. Granted you get a power later on that helps with that problem, but only to a point.The story is well presented but it still feels rushed and boring at times. The only thing that would make the gameplay any longer is by aquiring all the collectibles which I feel has had more time spent on than some more important parts of the game, both finding them and reading/watching them. This game is portrayed as a thriller and it hasn't failed on that part. However it also implies some horror elements that aren't really present, even with the "spooky" spectres.As my activity time shows, I've not spent long on this game. I'd say that the campaign is only around 3-4 hours long and all other time is spent simply getting the collectibles or completing the tiny amount of sidecrimes/cases that you can solve.All in all, this is getting a thumbs down. While the story is good, I can't help but feel that this game was rushed out to help with the new gen consoles rather than be a good game. I also don't think that with the small amount of time spent on thisgame it is worth the £24.99 price tag.

content:
7, 2016
												While I do recommend the game overall, I have one major gripe with it: the demons. Having to fight them was, for me, a total distraction from the story. In short, they were supremely annoying. IMHO, the game would be much better without them.I have one other, less serious, gripe: the navigation system. At various times there is a pointer displayed that, supposedly, tells how far, and what direction,  it is to the intended destination. It's practically useless; truly annoying.On the positive side, the story is really good. The way the graphics are handled is also pretty clever. Some say it's similar to L.A. Noir. I've never played it so I can't compare. The movement mechanics for keyboard were good. It is a little slow at the beginning while trying to figure out what to do, and how to do it, but it picks up as you get into the story.

content:
0, 2014
												Graphics are nice, but the control system is limited and a little forced (obviously intended for a controler). the only 'Action' is when you interact with demons and try to kill them from behind, in which case you have to quickly push a randomly chosen WASD key+mouse button combo while holding down another key to initiate. If they see you first, or you miss the key combo (EG because you're moving when you initate and the key your holding isn't the right one) then the only thing you can do is run away untill their not searching for you anymore and try again. Other than that it's a really simple detective game where you atempt to move your character into just the right spots to be able to interact with clues to get really obvious hints. (you get flashes of information when you find the clue, then you have to watch it all over again anyway once you 'solve' the crime)If you enjoy 'Tell me a story' mode games and can get past the controls it's alright. but get it on sale.

content:
er 25, 2015
												The game has a good story, nice environments and believable characters with solid voice overs. Actually, it could have been one of those interactive movies if not these two things.First of all, it's completely linear. The main story and a few side quests. The only variable is whether you find all the collectibles (they are all related to the lore) or not. More likely, not - looking for every collectible is just too boring and doesn't provide much new information.Secondly, for some reason the creators tried to add more depth to gameplay and introduced demons that you need to hide from or kill stealthily. And it just doesn't work. Too easy for any Thief (Splinter Cell, Hitman, etc) player and too boring on top of that. Thankfully, those moments with demons are really short and sometimes you can simply run through them and then hide.Despide the flaws, I still recommend playing it. Basically, it's like watching a good movie. Perhaps you can even be surprised in the end!

content:
4, 2014
												To be honest I expected better with this game. Better story, better mechanics, better gameplay, better graphics.  The story is probably the best part. It wasn't too obvious and had a lot twists and turns to it. That being said it does have some glaring flaws.  Some of the gameplay is fun for a while but the problem I found is that you begin with almost all the powers you will have at the end. This leaves no room for a feeling of character progression and development. It has some buggy mechanics such as having to stand at the exact right spot to interact with certain things. The graphics seem very last gen. I also HATE the stupid demon killing thing. It's very repetitive and an all round pain in the ♥♥♥ to have to take them out. Negatives aside, I wouldn't say the game was terrible. If you enjoy story based games, in particular, ghost/horror/noir based games. You may enjoy those aspects enough to warrant you buying it. I would say, buy it if it's on sale.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												A hidden gem or a rusty stone To some players, this game popped up from nowhere in the Square Enix's catelogue. However, some players has been following this game from E3 2013 and has been building up alot of anticipations and pre-release hype. Based on the original concepts, authentic setttings and unique mechanics, this game definitely delivers.In this epic detective meets criminal adventure heavily inspired by the likes of L.A. Noire and Alan Wake players takes the role of detective Ronan O'Connor who happens to find himself being killed by the mysterious 'bell killer'. He then not only find himself dead in the real world but simultaneous alive in another dimension like the movie 'ghost'. Determined to find out who the killer was, Ronan embarked on a endless investigation to solve the mysteries behind his death and discover the dark secret behind Salem's ancient history of witchcraft.By playing as a ghost, you gain awesome abilities such as no clipping through walls, possessing people, poltergeist electronic devices to attract attentions, and if these aren't enough you can possess a cat and go 'meow'.By poeessing common folks around the town, you are given the options mind read their thoughts. However, most of the things they say provide little to no useful information at all which makes it pointless at any point of the game. Some NPCs such as police officers will allow player to obtain useful clues regarding the cases often by means of eavesdropping, peeking through their eyes and influence their decision making.By possessing the cat, you gain access to platforming sections of the game which often will help you to get to a upper level.The detective elements of the game was not as good as L.A Noire, investigation can help you gather clues and the amount of clues needed for each case was given to players. Interrogation can only be done on other ghosts and it involves picking from limited options and are way too easy most of the time it is just common sense. With enough clues gathered, players can conclude the current investigation by chossing pieces of important information. Players are given 3 chances and even if you selcted the incorrect choices, the game will give you infinite tries leading to eventually picking out the correct information by trials and error.This idiotically defeats the purpose of giving 3 tries and has way too much hand holding throughout the story. Whereas, in L.A noire inability to solve crimes often can have consequences and investigation cannot be done again once it is concluded.The combat is however interesting as player gain ability to see demons through walls to allow advanced planning of strategies and make decisions to whether encounter or avoid. Most of the battle requires player to teleport between human remain souls to get behind the demons to perform execution called 'exorcism'. However, the game has only one enemy type and every encounter feels the same and after a while it gets repetitive.The environment is also quite boring with little open world elements, no interactive NPCs, and bland design choices that players often just walking around for collectibles, side cases or towards the next objective. Speaking of side quests and collectibles. It can be a real chore as the game has little replay value so you gasically back tracking for the sake of it. There are no incentives or rewards for doing it apart from some achievements for completing a side case or a set of collections.Characters have little personality development throughout the game, most of the time I find it hard to relate to most of them. If the story wasn't decent enough to make me continue playing I just cannot think of much selling point in this game.Techniquelly, there has been occassional frame rate drop issues and stuttering problems which is annoying but still playable. When booting up the game for the first time, the screen also flickers a few times but I won't rate a game based on these minor issues as it can be simply fixed with a update or two.Is this a good game?I think overall, yes it is a good game if you like story driven adventure that doesn't involve all out shooting and straightout combat. Its appeal really comes from a real life location and interesting depiction of Salem's ancient history and traditions with a unique play style, it can be really appreciative. If you can ignore the problems present and look at the good side of things plus the price they are asking for, I would say it is worth a try.Final verdictMurdered: soul suspect is far from perfect or a masterpiece if you compare it to similar games such as L.A noire and Alan Wake. But it borrows what is good from both titles and add its own twists which some think it is good and some simply may not like it.Finally, I think it is one of those game that should be played but just don't expect 100% perfection and a fully immersive world and rather expect a rough around the edges unque title to try in 2014.7/10

content:
2016
												Murdered is a game with an interesting idea and showed a lot of promise before it was released; a game where you play a deceased detective hunting down his murderer whilst solving crimes and using ghost powers, what's not to love? Well the problem is that the game is ultimately short and, frankly, boring - there is nothing to do outside of the main quest aside from FOUR side-quests and a bunch of collectables no one really cares about; the use of ghost walls, while a good concept, are only present to hide how small the environment is; and the biggest problem? This game is far too easy. It has a points system depending on how well you solve the crimes, but this doesn't actually have any impact whatsoever, and there is no penalty for making a wrong judgement, sure you lose a point but even after you lose them all you can keep on guessing. Oh and this game can be painfully short, if you're good at it you can complete in under 4 hours (or if you want to speedrun and miss the cutscenes - the story is the best part of the game, mind you - you can complete it in about 2). So yes, Murdered is an OK game, but it's one that will be played once and probably be forgotten about soon after playing it. However I do recommend playing it, but get when its on sale.

content:
0, 2014
												I picked up Murdered: Soul Suspect because a good friend kept stressing how good it is (in spite of all the negative reviews), and I wasn't at all disappointed with the game. In fact, I enjoyed it a lot more than I ever thought I would! The game relies largely on its characters and the murder mystery that's central to said characters' lives. If you're looking for a fast-paced, highly action-driven game, it doesn't deliver on that front - but that's what made it such a great ride for me as a player.I wasn't sure what to expect of the game from the premise alone, but it does atmospheric horror really well, along with the splashes of detective fiction and noir, too. Investigating, gathering clues, questioning witnesses, and making deducions are all important to the game. It even has an historical angle that I first thought would be somewhat canned, but actually surprised me a bit by the end.Collecting is an important part of the game and, although it's "optional," a lot of the story content depends on how well you can scour a map for all of the items - some hidden and some not. Even with ~10 hours play time into my first "completed" game, I still didn't track everything down! So if you're a completionist who enjoys searching and interacting with maps, M:SS definitely appeals on that front.The other main challenge of the game is demon encounters, and they can be tricky to master at first, since some of the combinations are a little awkward. Still, by the last few maps it seems easier (as the difficulty doesn't really go up much during the course of the game) ... but it's definitely anxiety-inducing sometimes! All in all, the demon encounters kept the game from feeling extremely linear (i.e., like a visual novel).So if you're into mysteries and crime fiction, love spooky stuff, and enjoy a game that burns a little slowly, definitely give it a try.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												After hearing bad reviews about this game, I was a bit hesitant to even buy it. But the more I read into the reviews, the more I realized that this game was just never given a fair chance from the start. A lot of people came off as jaded as to what they wanted and expected with "Murdered: Soul Suspect". In truth, I feel as though they were wrong."Murdered: Soul Suspect" is what you expect out of a good ghost story, or even a Noir movie. You have many different characters that fit the roles they were supposed to play. The story keeps you guessing until the very end, and manages to keep you on the edge of your seat the whole time. While it is not like a sandbox game like many had hoped and desired, you still have plenty of places to explore and little nooks and crannies to find within the game's structure.This game is not for a player who wants a sandbox world, who wants to shoot up bad guys, or that has to really put some effort to unlock, discover, and solve the many puzzles within the game. This is the kind of game that is for those who enjoy the journey it takes you on. For those who loved games like "Gabriel Knight" or "7th Guest". Good horror stories that make you want to discover everything that happened and why.While the replay value may not be as good as some other games, it is the sort of game you will play, try to find all the artifacts in the first run through, and then put away when you are finished. You will then pick it back up after awhile, and play it once more for the amazing story it tells.

content:
, 2014
												The entire premise of this game is solid. The story is well done. The characters aren't half bad. The locations themselves are very well designed and it doesn't overstay its welcome (about 8 and a half hours to 100%). That being said take note that some problems exist (at least at the time of writing this "review")1. No key rebinding. At all. Unacceptable. Good thing I used a pad.2. If you miss any collectibles you can't go back and find them after completing the final sequence of the game. This game has over 200 collectibles. It honestly expects you to find them all in one go.3. V-Sync locks the game to 30FPS. Unlocked I didn't notice any tearing myself but YMMV. (Runs at over 100FPS maxed on a 2500k/12GB DDR3/670 @ 1920x1080 if you're curious about performance). 4. There are terrible tacked on demon fights in most chapters of the story. They add noting and just slow the game down. It's just a game of waiting for a demon to turn its back to you so you can come out of hiding and do a quicktime event. Absolutely. Pointless. Outside of that, it's pretty awesome and worth about $20-$30. It's no L.A. Noire but as far as detective games go it's not bad.

												Bought this one as part of a Humble Bundle.Pros- the story is quite satisfying, the intro is such that I actually said "WOW!" out loud, flashbacks are well done and interesting, backstory is well told- the main characters are quite fleshed out, especially Ronan (see what I did there?)- love the voice acting, it's quite good, even for minor characters- lots of collectables (if that's your thing)- performance is excellent, I did not encounter any bugs or technical problems what so ever, very polished- you get to be a catCons- combat is THE WORST, you basically have to walk up to the enemy (demon) and pass a QTE, if you fail, you can scramble to get out or (more often) stand there feeling helpless, VERY FRUSTRATING and the reason I'm uninstalling before finishing- gameplay (besides combat) is underwhelming, I've expected much tougher and more diverse puzzles- the city feels quite empty and samey, people's thoughts repeat and are otherwise boringTLDR enjoyed the story, left because of the combat which (I feel) shouldn't be in a adventure / puzzle game to begin with.

												I heard good things about this game, and it's an interesting premise, but after three or four sessions I'm losing interest.  The gameplay typically involves wandering a room/area and picking up 16/16 random glowing points, for each you'll get a mostly uninteresting sentence to read "A police report.  Witness says the killer was wearing a hat.".  Then he'll come to a conclusion to move you to the next scene.  The dialogue is also typically very uninteresting.  You can read NPCs thoughts which should be cool, but each NPC has 2 useless dialogues, and they share the same dialogue with the other NPCs.  "It's so cold outside" "I don't feel safe with a killer on the loose" etc.  And everyone else who has unique dialogue is some kind of secret psychotic serial killer.  The demons are getting annoying.  My favorite part was a bit where you can "posess" and become a cat to access an area you otherwise couldn't.  The main character's backstory was interesting, but just poor implementation so far.  I'll probably push through and finish it, but I'm disappointed.

I was so bored... soooo bored. I did not expect another LA NOIRE but c'mon.. the best part was the intro video. It does have a very good story with interesting characters but it is so dull when you play it.It is sort of like this. You get into a location where you run around and picking up some totally useless things for revealing some sidestories which are interesting (some of them) but after picking up 5(/10/25) whatever they want (saw/papers/photographs) you go "OMG just give me the achievment and let me go". And the game starts telling you the whole sidestory while looking at some picture or something similiarily cheap.Some weird ♥♥♥♥ in the location where you run around belongs to the main story. But the point is same. You runnin around like an idiot and then go "HA! it wants me to push E" then you push E and then continue to run around. Then it asks you some totally dumb question and you got to connect some clues which would be interesting if the game would punish you for a wrong choice... You picked the wrong clue? Nevermind.. Pick another! So you can just click around cause it doesnt matter and answering questions like "Why did she go to church?" with an answer "I think she did go to the church" summs up the dullness of the "detective mechanics".Overall Murdered Soul Suspect looks like a game by someone who knows what makes a good game but doesnt know how to put it into his game. I can imagine somebody can get into this game and actually like it but I was so bored after 2 hours playing it.

Murdered: Soul Suspect is a detective game set around the site of the former Salem Witch trials where you are a ghost stuck in limbo until the you can resolve everything in regards to your death (namely, identifying the killer). content:
7, 2014
												Right then, I just finished the game.Let me start by saying that I like playing detective and love trying to solve puzzles on my own. I don't even mind if the graphics are bad, as long as the gameplay works and the plotline keeps me interested.When the game started I thought it seemed alright. The whole ghost detective trying to solve his own murder wasn't a bad idea and had quite some potential. Woe is me now, having paid 40 euros for something that lasted for 17 hours, and only so long because I kept on exploring the extremely limited environments that seem to be a trademark of Squaresoft's games these days. The player is guided by both arms like a blind and handicapped elderly through the mediocre and predictable story. God forbid anyone who pays good money for the game should have to think for themselves.And it's not just that. The whole game was more like getting from one lengthy cutscene to another. The only times you can screw up or die is when "battling" demons, and by battling I, of course, mean pressing two keys that show up on the screen in the correct order when close to a demon. How exciting.There was really only one thing I enjoyed in this game, and that was the first time I got to possess a cat. The cat's animations were done nicely and it was a fun idea. But really - not worth 40 euros. Another thing that was "ok" was the lead male's voice acting. It was not great, but it didn't get on my nerves either.At some point you gain an ability that made me think I might be able to roam the map more freely, but again I was to be disappointed. Most times I didn't even need this new ability to reach any places that were meant to be reached.I won't be recommending this game for anyone with half a brain.

content:
er 28, 2015
Question: is Murdered a good game? Not really. Is it bad? Not at all. It's the defitintion of "average".You play as Ronan, a badass detective who wears a black fedora and a stupid vest and still managed to get married, who's following a lead to stop "the Bell" serial killer, who enjoys murdering women in pretty babaric ways. But the protagonist ends up dying in the first minute of the game and becomes a ghost. But not even this undead form can stop him to unravel this mistery and stop this murder once and for all with the help of Joy, a psychic teenagers who's looking for her mom. Also, she's a total ♥♥♥♥♥, almost as boring as the main character.The gameplay takes a lot of inspiration from L.A. Noire: you have to inspect the area to find clues to answer questions about murders or misteries. Except it doesen't do that stupid sound every time you're close to a clue; I can actually say that it's a bit improved in comparison of the Rockstar game. You can pass through certain walls to access secret areas, and trust me, there's a lot of secrets (about 240 in total).So, the detective mechanic are pretty fun, but sadly, the devs though it was a good idea to add some kind of fighting system. Sometimes, random flying demons will appear, announcing themselvs with a ♥♥♥♥ing loud scream that will ♥♥♥♥ your ears every single time; how to fight them? Go on their back and click 2 buttons. It's just a time-waster mechanic, and could have easly been removed.The mistery itself in the game is pretty ok, but honestly, I figured out most of it during the middle of the game, while Mr. Spoopi Detective realized only at the end. THOSE MURDEREDS ARE CONNECTED? AND IT'S ABOUT WITCHES? IN THE CITY OF SALEM?! WHAT A COINCIDENCE! ..Yea, is pretty lacking story whise, and most of the characters are pretty obnoxious.Music is almost non existent in this game, so I can't really recommend anything from the soundtrack.Even tho this game is not that great, I can't help but recommend it. But why? Because at least is trying to do something different. Sure, it's borrowing a lot of mechanic and ideas from other games, but at least it's really trying to bring something that is not a classic story "kill the bad guys and win the lady". Sure, you might argue that it's kinda following that path, but it's the way they're getting there that at least is trying to be different.Final Score: 6/10I highly suggest to pick this game up during a sale, or if you have the chance, get it for cheap at humblebundle.com

content:
ber 28, 2014
												Murdered: Soul Suspect - Spoiler Free ReviewFirst off, I'd like to point out that I like both pulp noir and ghost stories both of which are heavy influences on the general feel of this game.  If you do not like either the cinematography stylings of pulp noir (in which case, you won't like the cut-scenes and may dislike the characters on occassion) or think ghost stories are dull, then this is not the game for you.  For those of you still with me and looking at potentially buying this game a bit of background is in order.  The studio that released M:SS closed down despite really ploughing everything into this game.  Part of it is odd in places, which I'll get to, but mostly they'd been struggling for a while due to releasing a couple of games which were bombs a while back.  Any future updates to the game will have to be community driven but that at least is one piece of good news - after multiple playthroughs I only came across one minor glitch, once, and it was a graphical one that I couldn't replicate.  The game runs really well so future patching should not be necessary.So, where to start?  How about the story.  It's pretty standard fair, almost straight out of a "Randall & Hopkirk: Deceased" episode.  You're a detective in Salem when a call is put in about a strange hooded man breaking into an apartment building.  As you are an emotional loose cannon after your wifes' death (it's actually nice to play a character who's irrational behaviour gets some explanation for once) you chase after him alone only to find that he's too strong for you, the eventual fight resulting in your death.  Your purpose is to stop the killer from beyond the grave so that your spirit can move on and be reunited with your wife.  This opening is actually really impressive as it's almost entirely done using the in-game engine and graphically looks superb, the sweeping camera shots and the slow-motion work really well giving a strong movie quality feel but rather than just have you as a passenger watching the opening the developer makes you take part in it, trying to first catch the killer and even trying to survive the attack.  The sound is excellent too and is nicely understated, something that carries throughout the whole game.After this you're left, dead, in Salem trying to figure out how you can stop this killer.  There's a tutorial which covers the controls and then you're given objectives to complete but you are left to wander through reasonably large parts of Salem without being stopped.  As you're dead you come across other spirits and left over memories of Salem in it's past, which just helps to make the world more interesting and full and the contrast in design is really well realised, especially when it ties in with the sidequests and main stories.  The more you progress the more of Salem opens up to you, allowing you to find out more about Salems past and revisit areas you have already explored.  The team have been as historically accurate as possible, considering that the game is a work of fiction, and you'll get to pick up on a real flavour of Salems darker past as you wander town.Character design suits the mood of the town too and there are characters in period dress in certain areas, although they are very few and far between, I'd have liked to have seen more of them.  They are reasonably realistic to look at - not ultra-real - which would feel out of place in a ghost story, but real anyway with very good motion capture and facial expressions especially on the main ones.  One that stood out to me is a point where a character manages to pretty much lie with just their face for a split second near the end, you'll know it when you see it, but the technology is well utilised without being overdone, it does not take you out of the story or gameplay very much if ever.As a ghost you get to travel through walls but presumably due to hardware limitations this pretty much is only really used within enclosed spaces, though this is explained within the game-worlds mythos itself well enough and it can be quite good fun.  These sections really can make you feel like a running, screaming spirit.  I felt less like a spirit and more like I was going to have a seizure due to swoosh noise everytime you select a conversation topic.  It's fine in short conversations but they can be long and a little grating if you want to find out everything.There's some disturbing bits in this game too.  Some pretty nasty deaths of young women, some ghosts have some surprisingly harrowing and well-acted lines, almost mini-stories, of their own if you come across them and there are collectables that unlock urban legends, a couple of which are genuinely quite creepy.  There are places with a lot of extra details added in which build up a wonderful sense of dread and oppression too, a lot of which can easily be missed and overlooked as it is just there for scene-setting.  Controls are pretty tight, the camera is good but can be a bit awkward when you are possessing something or trying to get through a wall slowly.  But there are two elephants in the room and these are what most reviewers scored the game so harshly on.1) Pointless Sort-of Forced Combat/Stealth Sections.You do combat, you either have to go for it whole-heartedly or just don't do it.  In for a penny, in for a pound!  M:SS feels like it's dipping it's fingers into the collection bowl and wondering if it can get away with giving a two Christmas old chocolate coin.  You get an enforced stealth section, taking you out of the more interesting portion of the game which feels jarring, so you can try to sneak past these demon-monsters which look like the Nozghul if they'd been drinking sheep-dip.  It hardly ever works so you have to try to stealth kill them, which is only a temporary fix.  2) Escort MissionThe escort is at least useful but these are really badly designed - it barely matters if you get spotted because the spotter sub-routine is so badly programmed.Both of these things feel tacked on and out of place.  I have a sneaking suspicion that they received orders from their publisher that if they wanted a Triple A advertising budget then it had to have those things in it because they feel completely at odds with the rest of the game.  And yes, I will be doing a video rant I am that annoyed about it.Mercifully, there's only a handful of those sections and apart from that and one point with a truly stupid portrayal of mental illness (completely different to an earlier scene with a ghost in a bath), the rest of the game is pretty much excellent.  If you can stick out those few parts you will find a good to look at, engaging murder mystery, with an excellent twist and interesting backdrop and characters.I recommend it, but have to dock it marks for 1) & 2)        Total Score:  7.5/10  Well above average and definitely worth a play if you want a murder mystery that's a little different or a slowly paced adventure game.

content:
ber 18, 2014
												I was genuinely surprised by this game. I had my doubts when the hype around this game began to wane when it got closer to launch. Glad I was mistaken.The story starts with a bang and keeps you interested with a plethora of sidequests and lore. There's a lot to find in Salem, as there are over 200 pieces of different collectibles you can, uhm, collect. Bits of info about the town, witch trials and the characters themselves. All of them well written.Graphically the game looks good, but then again I'm really not that into graphics when I play. Voice acting is quite nice, though the budget seems to limit the amount of voice actors on NPC:s, as you tend to hear the same dialog often. But at least you don't hear Nolan North arguing with Nolan North (looking at you, Mafia 2).Story is great, in my opinion, and the ending was good. No cliffhangers or anything, everything is resolved.The gameplay is okay, although the "stealth combat" seems a bit out of place. It's only padding, really, they should have let that on the cutting room floor. The UI is very console-like, with rather odd button bindings. Nothing major, though. I played this with keyboard & mouse with no problems.All in all, it's a good game, definitely better than its metacritic score. Sure it's not a masterpiece by any means, but it sure has a spot on my underrated gems -list.

Supplying 8 hours of gameplay, with some side missions which are just as enjoyable as the main storyline, I feel this is a game which all should experience assuming you are someone who just enjoys a good story.

content:
3, 2014
												I need to point out a bias, and that's that I love games that dare to be different. I have no heavenly idea whether it's the optimism or the bias itself speaking, but I really like this game! I'm sure you know what the game is about, you're an ex-"bad boy" who wanted to change your life, so you became a cop. Now, during an investigation, you got shot by a mysterious man who seems anything BUT normal. You now need to solve this wicked mystery of who that man is, to get your redemption. Don't worry, you won't get to hold a gun, exactly, so it's not your "average COD-clone".My personal opinion of the beginning- and middle parts of the story is that they were good.  The ending was the most disappointing part of the game, however. Extremely cheap and weak way to end the game.. and even if it was "cheap and weak", it left you with a whole lot of questions afterwards. I won't spoil anything But story was overall quite good.The world in itself, that you walk around in, is fan-♥♥♥♥ing-tastic! It is soooo cozy to walk around in a very Italian-like village during the night! But there's a huge flaw.. hugeeee flaw. The voice of the main character is painfully bad. He tries to do something Batman-like and deepen his voice way too low that it ruins everything. I don't know how to demonstrate this exactly, but when I was playing and heard him talk, my stomach hurt.. that's how bad this situation is!Other characters are somewhat lovable, and their animations & voice acting are all well done. HOWEVER, despite this game being "open-world" the elements that show this are abscent. There are missions you can do when roaming around such as helping a ghost solving their deaths, but I've only found three or four. Pathetic! And the collectibles aren't even worth thinking about. It does get quite scary at times as well, however, for you horror-lovers. I definitely recommend this game, in the end, though!7,5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
12, 2016
												You play as the ghost of Ronan O'Connor as he investigates his murder and attempts to find the identity of the serial "Bell Killer."  There are several investigations you must perform through the game, plus a number of optional side cases where you can help other ghosts resolve whatever issues are keeping them in the world.  The story is really interesting, especially when you discover the identity of the serial killer, but the game is just okay.Finding clues to solve the investigations is kind of difficult.  There is only a narrow margin in the view angle that will allow you to actually examine each clue, and there is nothing to indicate what can or can't be examined other than the "Examine" option that appears when you look directly at a clue.  Piecing together the clues to solve each case is not at all intuitive, and often doesn't even make sense.  The soundbite clues were my least favorite; the game plays a sound as the menu appears (and the menu has its own sound clip), then you have to choose which object in your sight makes the most sense for the sound you may have not even heard.  There is no way to make the sound replay.Thankfully, there is no punishment for selecting the wrong clues when solving a case.  Unfortunately, there's also no reward for perfectly solving a case.  After solving a case, the game tells you exactly where to go next, which makes for a very linear experience.  You do revisit a few locations, and you can sidetrack to perform optional cases or discover collectibles, but the game really holds your hand the whole way through.  This makes the game pretty easy to complete, but I didn't feel like it caused me to enjoy the game any less.The ghost powers are nothing more than arbitrary game mechanics that change for each situation depending on what the game needs to let you do in order to progress.  You have the ability to possess people and listen to their thoughts, which results in you hearing the same small selection of dialogues over and over.  Sometimes cases will make you possess a person and "influence" them to provide more clues.  You are prompted, "What will make this person remember _______ event?" and then you choose something from among the clues you've found thus far.  You also have the ability to teleport a short distance, interact with electronics as a poltergeist (which only draws peoples' attention when the game needs it to), and reveal ghost objects of events from the distant past (which doesn't ever seem to do anything useful except allow you to find optional collectibles).Each case only requires you to find a handful of available clues, so you need not collect all 362 pieces of evidence (189 of which are for the main story) if you aren't the completionist type.  Failure to collect all the clues will not affect the outcome of the game, so don't expect a Heavy Rain type of game where information you do or do not find affects future revelations.  However, collecting all of the clues does reveal a lot of information about the locations and characters, so you are actually rewarded for picking up the ridiculous amount of collectibles.Despite these flaws, I did enjoy the game.  It holds up as a solid detective game even if the clues and cases are somewhat arbitrary.  This is certainly not the best detective game I've played but it is far from being the worst.

content:
y 2, 2015
												MURDERED isn't really a game. It's more of an interactive story/movie with movement, It has a very interesting premise, but in my opinion it failed to deliver on that punch which it desperately needed and strived for.For the "gameplay" mechanics, you basically find crime scenes, try to find and examine every object, then have infinite tries to choosing the correct ones that apply to move the story along. Sometimes this involves influencing people by possessing them, but that's only during scripted moments and does nothing useful when you possess the NPCs walking around the world. It's the same when you "poltergeist" an object (turn it on/mess it up for a few seconds). Lifeless NPCs will not react unless it's a scripted moment for the story.There are enemies in the game, demons, and you can walk behind them and try your hand at a randomized QTE where you'll have to press one button from WASD and use the left or right click to destroy the demon. If you fail, which you will due to the poor controls of this, then you'll have to jump into ghost fragments around the level to avoid getting your soul sucked until the demon gives up. This is all of the "action" in the story and it's more of a waste of time than anything. There is no boss fight or no real reason for destroying demons. Their AI is on a predetermined route and they're just an inconvenience for scouring a level for the collectible items.Each area has a different amount of collectibles. These unlock urban legend/ghost stories that are just a picture and a person monologuing. That's really it for the entire game's mechanics outside of possessing a cat and following a predetermined route with no real obstacles/puzzles. There's literally nothing interesting to do in this game beyond solving the main storyline with its pre-determined deductivity.  All in all, I can't recommend this as a game. If you're looking for the great supernatural mystery thriller of our time this is far from that. But if you're looking to chance it for a story that you may (or may not) enjoy and you're willing to overlook about 8 hours of lacking gameplay, this one on the cheap might fit that bill. Treat it more like an average-grade movie than a game.

content:
29, 2014
												Murdered Soul Suspect is the last game made by Airtight games, Did the go out with a bang ? In Murdered Soul Suspect you play as Ronan o connor. Salem is haunted by a serial killer named the Bell killer. One day Ronan Finds the trail of the bell killer but gets killed in the process. Ronan returns as a ghost but hes unable to move on until he finds out who killed him. In the proccess he meets Jane who the killer is trying to hunt down. So its youre job to protect her from the killer while trying to find out who killed you. So how is Murdered ? Its actually a great game. The best way i could put it would be a supernatural LA Noire. The game is essiantly you interogating ghosts and people who can see you know as mediums. The game lets you posses people and cats. Mess with electronics and stuff like that. Theres also fighting segments where you have to fight ghost while trying to aproach them from the back. But if they see you you will have to hide because you cant fight them head on. So now for the pros and cons. The game has a great story and a great twist ending. The game is fun and simple. Great puzzles to solve and tons of collectibles to collect. The cons: the game is kinda glitchy and its also really short. Overall Murdered Soul Suspect is a great game and i suggest you buy it because simply put it its a great game and Airtight Games will be missed. I give Murdered Soul Suspect a 8/10

												Would have been okay if it came out 10 years ago. Key word being "okay".Average to bad story, bad acting, not as cheesy as it should have been (big missed opportunity there), and lots of 'collect all the ♥♥♥♥' which is usually my jam, but even that feels messy and arbitrary.Speaking of 10 years ago, I would recommend something like Fahrenheit instead, which still blows this out of the water.On the other hand, if you want to play a $50 game that really takes ZERO brain cells to process, both in story and gameplay, this is the game for you my friend!update: Finished the game (which thankfully speeds up in pace at the end, but still doesn't get an upgrade to recommended from me), and saw that the credits feature a Japanese dev team! This actually explains a lot. It really feels like a eastern interpretation of a western crime story - they pick up every cliche and trope, the cheesiest characters, but approach it completely straight faced. No irony, no self awareness. I wish they'd felt more free to inject more of their own personality.Now it sits in no-mans land, the equivalent of a western attempt at an anime or a JRPG.

content:
, 2016
												MURDERED has a cool concept and plot: You have been murdered and trying to solve your own murder as a ghost. What is not cool, however, is how repetitive and confusing this game can get.The game is a glorified movie with a few cuts of brain-dead gameplay here or there. Your objective will tell you to go to a location. Then you will use to stealth to kill some demons, then you will pickup all the clues to solve a few "questions" which lead you to another location. Rinse and repeat a few times.The crux of the game should be solving hard puzzles, but most puzzles are just wandering around a small room and mashing 'E' on everything to 'reveal' it. Then you have unlimited tries to put the 'clues' together (there is NO penalty for guessing wrong, not even a special perfect ending). Additionally, the demon fighting game play is ridiculously easy. I realized half-way through that you could actually run past every demon without fighting them. In other words, there is no challenge.One final thing I didn't like: No mini-map in-game. It turns out you only could get a mini-map if you PREORDERED the game (for something so core you would think it would just come with the game). If you are a completionist this makes collecting everything a living hell. Every wall in the town looks the same. And some collectibles don't appear unless you go along all the walls and mash a button (in other words, this is near-impossible without a guide).

content:
ry 27, 2016
												So clearly not recommending this game, this Review is being written in 2016 and should be noted as such, if your thinking of buying this game just go for something else.This game is basically a detective story in 3rd person where you hunt for clues to piece together the bell killer murders and find out who the murderer is.The main part of the "game" part of this game, is annoying little demon sections where you have to go up behind a demon and exorcise them, these have really crappy AI and mostly just detract from the story (the main reason to play this kind of game), looking a little too low? these demons won't register, will turn around and notice you, and you will have to hide from them till they get bored and go back to doing their rounds, and this element just feels added for the sake of actual gameplay (even though the story does technically cover it, it's a really loose connection.As for the Actual main story, while part of it is obvious, the true answer is basically a massive cop out, and as this is spoiler free i won't actually be able to say why, but once you have played this game, you will be dissapointed by the ending.Other then this, it's basically a fetch quest where you look for clues and work out which few are actually even relevant (each section requires no more then 4 clues to do any one part, and you can then move on) and it mostly just becomes find the relevant spot and look at it.I finished this game in about 6 Hours (although steam doesn't seemed to have registered my play time properly) and was rather disappointed, i'm glad i bought this through a humble bundle, as i didn't end up paying the $20 price tag, which realistically is asking a bit much for something like this.Without all the filler stuff this could easily be a 2 hour game but you spend most of your time walking around and playing hide and seek with demons.

content:
ry 27, 2016
												So clearly not recommending this game, this Review is being written in 2016 and should be noted as such, if your thinking of buying this game just go for something else.This game is basically a detective story in 3rd person where you hunt for clues to piece together the bell killer murders and find out who the murderer is.The main part of the "game" part of this game, is annoying little demon sections where you have to go up behind a demon and exorcise them, these have really crappy AI and mostly just detract from the story (the main reason to play this kind of game), looking a little too low? these demons won't register, will turn around and notice you, and you will have to hide from them till they get bored and go back to doing their rounds, and this element just feels added for the sake of actual gameplay (even though the story does technically cover it, it's a really loose connection.As for the Actual main story, while part of it is obvious, the true answer is basically a massive cop out, and as this is spoiler free i won't actually be able to say why, but once you have played this game, you will be dissapointed by the ending.Other then this, it's basically a fetch quest where you look for clues and work out which few are actually even relevant (each section requires no more then 4 clues to do any one part, and you can then move on) and it mostly just becomes find the relevant spot and look at it.I finished this game in about 6 Hours (although steam doesn't seemed to have registered my play time properly) and was rather disappointed, i'm glad i bought this through a humble bundle, as i didn't end up paying the $20 price tag, which realistically is asking a bit much for something like this.Without all the filler stuff this could easily be a 2 hour game but you spend most of your time walking around and playing hide and seek with demons.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
, 2015
												This review will be in separate parts when ever I want to complain about the game. But every bit of this review is constructive criticism.First three areas explored in:I am already offended by this game for its lack of social construction. This game's dialogue seems to have bits and pieces of an idea together but are poorly sewn together. If you are a private investigator or an FBI profiler you will be saddened by this game. For the dialogue choices seem to route you to the same answer, but are shallow in complete thought. I get the idea behind this game being the main story line but my problem with this game so far is not your maneuverability, or lack of direction. But more or so to the approach this game takes when it comes to solving the cases. It seems like the person who created this plot forgot that detectives constantly talk to themselves while piecing together a story. Though to be fair it says in the text right there what it wants you to do. But it should be stated by the detective to help people figure out what is going on. The text floating around as you try to piece things together will throw you off guard as soon as a change of course happens within the solving of each small puzzle.While trying to figure out one thing it suddenly switches... but our friend the detective doesn't say much and it quickly moves on to the next thing. So you miss what the text changed to, telling you what you are supposed to look for now, at that very split second given moment and you guess wrong. Worst of all is the clunky UI. You mess something up it freezes you... pauses.... backs out.... brings up several different separate tab screens for each object which suddenly takes away the purpose for searching it, (which is why I say again it would help if the detective was constantly talking to himself in thought to keep the main point in focus.) And quite frankly leaves me bewildered at what happens when you "try again."Maybe the approach to this method should have used better sorting options.... Throwing things around all the time makes me think this detective never carried around so much as a book. Possibly carried around a recording device seeing how disorderly everything being displayed becomes.Just imagine that every time you came up with the idea behind a string of events you got angered, and suddenly threw up all the information you just looked at in frustration... only to come right back to it, to string everything together again, as all the papers fall to the ground and you have this game. I think the creator... if he is or was a detective... must have had little to no patience himself in each case. Possibly due to extra ordinary means like time or money allotted to his investigations. Maybe a sergeant or person's interest was a timely manner. I am still willing to give this a second try but it is so demanding on your eyes, more or so than your brain, that it causes you to lose concentration quite easily.And the demons? My goodness. Talk about an annoying trap puzzle that springs up like a jack in the box that malfunctions a lot. I get the idea behind exorcising ghosts... but uh.... how does our detective friend just suddenly know how to exorcise a ghost exactly? Was our friend the detective a priest? There is no mention of him being one in his own background... But just barely minutes into the game, you have the ability to exorcise a ghost without having to read any books about it. I think this game would have been a lot more interesting with the setup it seemed to hold. In which I think the Detective originally did not know how to exorcise ghosts until later in the game. But I guess the devs thought it would be too annoying to make players fear them so early. Yet it would have been a lot more fun and made more sense if the ability wasn't there until you figured it out.This game seems to be targeted at kids more or so than adults seeing how there are some "way too soft" spots that spring up like a bad smell. You will literally yell at our detective to "JUST GRAB HER F***ING ARM!" When it comes to solving one of the cases. I want to slap the detective for being so.... retentively sympathetic, yet wise cracking at certain times.Also the girl? Best idea ever when it comes to surprising your audience when you finally meet her for the first time. But there was one inconsistency that happened at the cemetery... She complained about not being able to see him... even though she was holding a flashlight... Then a few minutes later she has no trouble seeing them. Could have been the lamp post nearby but uh.... She did shine a flashlight on him.Last three bits:Am I ever more disappointed in a game? This game answered that question. Incredibly short game. I am sad. I am so sad after completing this game.The best puzzle is the ending.I think the issue is that the development team behind this had an astonishingly awesome idea.... but I think budget cuts really let this game down. This game had some real potential but it is so short lived. The ending seems to be pasted together. But at least it did create one hell of a mind ♥♥♥♥. It is just too bad the whole time you believe one thing because of your own abilities... and then there is another. What the hell.Too short. Way too short. My final complaint? Some of the "side missions" are broken.This game should be twitch viewed only.

content:
er 20, 2014
												If somebody asked me to describe Murdered: Soul Suspect in one word, I would say: Unfinished.It's evident from the start that this game was rushed out the door too early in order to meet a deadline. Many things that you'd expect from a modern, full-priced AAA game are not present here. I knew something was up even before I jumped into the actual game. The menu was just a static image. There were no flashy effects when you highlighted any of the options. No bells and whistles whatsoever. Of course, none of that is actually necessary, but it is odd to see a big-budget game cut corners like that.Unfortunately, this was just the tip of the iceberg.After the game's opening cutscene, you're immediately tasked with investigating a crime scene. Games like Ace Attorney and L.A. Noire have already demonstrated excellent examples of how to simulate actual detective work, so it's pretty baffling to me that Murdered: Soul Suspect would take the most basic, and un-intuitive route possible. You point. You click. You win.There's almost zero deductive reasoning involved in investigating these crime scenes. Gathering evidence presents no challenge, since the "clues" are ridiculously easy to spot in the environment. It's depressing that the biggest problem I ran into when solving the mystery behind these crime scenes was my tendency to overthink them. Turns out, the most obvious solution is ALWAYS the right one. Once you figure that out, the rest of the game is a cakewalk. So what else is there? Well, your ghostly character can possess people. This is a great idea on paper, but your enthusiasm will quickly wane once you realize that you can't actually control your posessee's. However, you can read their minds. Better than nothing, I suppose, but you'll be in for a rude awakening once you find that NPCs in the town only have a handful of phrases to recite, none of which are actually relevant to the investigation at hand. What could've been an excellent and inventive way to acquire information about the details of your case is squandered by the complete ineptitude of the developers. Soul Suspect isn't entirely without merit though. The story held my attention for the duration of the game, and even though the characters are archetypes that we've already seen before from the detective/mystery genre, it still managed to be a moderately intriguing tale. The pay-off is also decent, with a twist ending that even M. Night Shyamalan would be proud of.What saddens me the most is that Murdered: Soul Suspect is a very solid idea, and it could've easily been a great game with a little more TLC. It's painful to see a game with this much wasted potential. I liked the ideas here, but the execution left a lot to be desired. I'd love to see a sequel to this game where these ideas are more expanded upon, but as it stands, Murdered: Soul Suspect is half-baked, and it shows.

content:
0, 2016
												A lot of the games that I rate "thumbs down" are just mediocre and still have redeeming qualities. This game, on the other hand, is literally the worst game I've ever played. Took me just over 5 hours to finish it and it overstayed its welcome.The story is actually OK - not great, but a decent B-horror-movie tale. It does have a pretty good red herring followed by a nice twist at the end. However, one aspect of the villain's identity is very clearly telegraphed. The plot is pretty simple - you're a homicide detected who is killed by the serial killer you're hunting. Now relegated to ghost form, you try to track down the killer.The gameplay, however, is abysmally weak. Gameplay has two phases - investigations and stealth. Investigations involve peeking into people's minds and observing supernatural objects. Stealth involves avoiding demons and helping your (live) AI companion sneak into locations by creating distractions. The basic problem with both is that they are essentially hidden object games - all you need to do to progress is to find the correct button to press. The game never gets any more complicated than this. There are a few sections where you have to do things with correct timing, but they're very easy. In reality, you spend the entire game walking around and clicking on things. Occasionally, you will be asked to identify the "relevant" clues out of a crime scene with numerous clues scattered about. If you pick incorrectly, you're just told you were wrong and given the chance to try again. So that means that your "investigations" can be beaten by simply picking clues at random until you get them right. That means this so-called "mystery" game has no actual mystery to it. What's the fun in a detective game where you aren't allowed to be misled? Calling this a mystery game at all is misleading - it's a glorified walking simulator. You couldn't possibly make a mistake. The Vanishing of Ethan Carter has far more actual mystery than this.The game is so brainless and holds your hand so much that at times I felt like I was playing one of the simple educational games you find on Steam, like "The Deer." It's dumbed-down to the point of utter boredom, start to finish.Technically, I guess it's fine, runs fine and looks decent for a last-gen console title. Controls are OK with both M+KB and with controller, which is to be expected when the game has such a limited amount of interaction.The only reason I played this to completion was because I didn't want to feel like I wasted my money. That makes me a sucker. Don't be a sucker like me. Avoid this game.

content:
7, 2016
												I've had this game in my library for like 3 years now and I haven't bothered to even install it once. Recently I figured that I would play it because I had nothing else better to do and I had seen a few short gameplay videos. It's a game by Square Enix, one of my favourite publishers and it's got moderately good graphics so I'm able to play it Ultra and in 4K resolution.Firstly the premise seems cool enough, but also pretty simple. You play a detective who's been killed and you have to find out who killed you. No problem there, as I always like a good 'whodunnit' story.The problem is everything else except the story.CONTROLS - The controls are so annoying to use. I had to turn the sensitivity down so low to avoid the camera spinning around like a tornado. You also walk so slowly, and are forced to constantly hold run 100% of the time if you even want to get anywhere within a reasonable timeframe; having to always hold shift also made my pinky get sore fast. All of these things make the game quickly feel very cumbersome to play and my patience really started to wear thin...GAMEPLAY - There's no 'crosshair' but you have to perfectly directly face an object so it is in the middle of your screen in order to interact with it. Due to being a ghost, you can walk through many solid looking objects which is cool until you realise that there is also no kind of map in the game at all. Paths are constantly 'hidden' bethind objects that you have to walk through, and it's very hard to remember where something is. If you missed something way back at the start of the area, you can go back provided you can find your way through the confusing and very narrow/linear path from one area to another. The game is also filled with pointless empty alleyways and dead-ends that I really could not understand at all why the developers didn't bother to make any sort of map. It would have made navigation so much easier. Finding clues and collectables in Murdered: Soul Suspect is a huge part of the game, but sadly it's very hard to spot some mission related clues do to the objects being absolutely tiny, and/or partially hidden.ENEMIES - There aren't really any except for these 'demons' that lurk around some areas of the game, and 'traps' that just force you to find a way around them. Demons are more of an annoyance than a challenge. Simply hide behind a wall or in a 'safe zone' until they come close enough, then when their back is turned press the right combination to kill them. The combinations are a total pain as you have to keep holding the 'R' button AND then press 2 other buttons at the same time which are often very close to the 'R' button. Getting it wrong means wasting a few minutes whilst the Demon chases you or looks for you. They're incredibly easy to kill as you can spot them through walls and there's often plenty of places to hide. Honestly I found them a pointless addition to the game and just something obviously added to try and increase the overall length of a playthrough.STORY - The story is good enough I guess. Some of the side missions seem stupid and some of the murder/death mysteries are quite boring really. I found it kind of hard to care about a few of the NPCs but at the same time I guess a couple of them were interesting enough. The main story seems interesting enough so far and so long as it's about the same length as 'The Wolf Among Us' I will be pretty happy. I still prefer TWAU's gameplay and smoothness to this game's by far.GRAPHICS - Not much bad to say here as graphics are pretty top notch. The game looks really nice in 4K, although I found that some of the floating papers got a bit distracting as I often mistook them for clues that I could interact with. Also the game is capped at 30FPS if you enable Vertical Sync which made it feel really, really choppy for me. A huge part of the game are also pre-rendered cutscenes which are also all capped to 30fps. So if you end up playing in 60+ FPS normally and then move to a cutscene you can end up getting eye fatigure and a general nagging feeling as the game changes framerates constantly. Finally I thought that it was kind of annoying that a lot of the NPCs don't have proper lip movements when they are speaking. This is something that Square Enix usually does really well, but in this game a lot of NPCs just stand there going through their limited behaviour animations with their mouths closed but they are still speaking.ABILITIES - These are actually pretty boring and feel really lackluster. The first ability you get is to be able to possess people in order to read their minds or try and jog a memory that helps uncover part of the story. Murdered: Soul Suspect has a lot of NPCs in some areas, and using the mind-reading ability shows really how little thought was put into the game. ALL NPCs only have TWO possible dialogues that can be uncovered through reading their minds. Specific NPCs have specific and more 'unique' dialogues however NPCs that do nothing except to just 'populate' the game world almost always all have the same "I don't feel safe here" etc. responses. It's really boring. As for the other features like Reveal, this is just used to uncover small side stories and Teleport is only used to get into 'consecrated' areas that would normally be off-limits.There's not much else to talk about but all in all I wouldn't recommend the game. The graphics are good and the story is interesting enough but the game quickly becomes a total pain to play. My fingers get sore, my patience runs thin and even the uniqueness of the game and the lingering mystery to uncover doesn't hold my attention for more than a few short hours at a time. More than anything I can't help but feel that a few changes or extra small additions to the game would have yielded a much smoother experience. Things such as a small map, faster walking and running, and increased amount of dialogue in the game would have added a lot of value.

												I was actually enjoying this game until I encountered a game-breaking glitch near the end of Chapter 2. What I assume I was supposed to do was use my poltergeist ability on the vacuum to get the priest to walk over the vortex thingy on the floor so I could possess him and safely cross to the other side of the hallway.As it turns out, the priest decided to be a bishop, in the sense that he only moved diagonally. He crossed over and clipped into the wall opposite the vacuum cleaner, and when I possessed him he moved diagonally across the vortex, clipped into another wall, and walked in a courtyard where I could not unpossess him.I tried restarting the checkpoint. I tried letting the priest make a single trip and then using poltergeist on the vacuum a second time before possessing him. I tried starting the game over from the beginning. I tried reinstalling the game. I even tried starting the game from the beginning AFTER reinstalling, but nothing worked.So I checked Google for answers, but couldn't find any solutions. That's when I gave up. Even if there is a solution, I refuse to sit through the same unskippable cutscenes for a fourth time in the hopes that maybe I'll be able to get past the second chapter.If you're thinking of buying this game, don't. There's an old flash game on Newgrounds called "The Dead Case", which is similar yet vastly superior despite being from 2004. Not only is it free, but it actually functions like it's supposed to.

												I am a casual female gamer, not great with button mashing. I really love rich story lines, rpg styled play, and puzzles! This game included all of that. If you're casual like me, it's a great point and click that isn't boring. Too often I find the point and clicks are slow paced, but this isn't. Most of the game is really innate. You know what your goals are and what you have to do. I rarely needed to look something up, so that's a plus for the casual gamer. The storyline is reallllly cool, the characters, the voice acting, all of it. My only negative is I didn't clue in to just how open the world was. You can explore a lot and do side quests and I missed a lot of them because I was only following the storyline. Newb mistake for sure, so be sure you do all the fun stuff on the side to get all the achievements. Graphics and controls were great.

content:
, 2014
												This is my first review, so I'll try to keep it simple.This game is aggressively mediocre. For a puzzle game, the puzzles are never very engaging, but then again, not a lot of puzzles can be done if the main character can't touch things. Every brain teaser is either 'pick the obvious clue' or 'pick the obvious series of clues'. Sometimes you have to do them in the right order, wow.The combat/stealth is practically non-existant. Occasionally demons will jump out accompanied with the sound a piano might make if it were thrown through a window. It shocked me the first time it happened, then never again. You disable them by running up behind them and doing a simple qte. This is made incredibly easy since they cannot see through walls. You, on the other hand, can both see and walk through walls. Dissapointing.Oh, and the many hiding spots in the overworld kept me constantly wondering if I might get jumped at one point. Never happened. Why even have them there?The story itself is okay, but it suffers from the protagonist having never even heard of withces before, and he's lived all his damn life in Salem, of all places. Sometimes there are no excuses. And the ending, oh god, the ending was a major dissapointment. It lasted all of 5 minutes and most of that was cutscenes. That said, I really enjoyed all the interactions between characters. All the ghosts are kind of one note characters, but the humans were kind of special to me. The way they reacted to your death and subsecuent actions made them seem more real and alive then most other characters I can recall offhand. They all mourn and act in their own way and even though this is not a big game, I can't say that there are any living characters that I disliked.Ending... uh. Rent it, I guess? At least wait untill it goes down in price. A 10 hour game does not deserve a 40$ price tag. Definitely get it if you really, really like collecting stuff.

content:
, 2014
												Best Part: You possess a cat.Worst Part: Combat and QTE.I was really expecting this game to be good, and I tried to enjoy it. I recently finished it (6 hours with 77% of achievements unlocked) and I only recommend if you really want to play for the theme.Note: UI is terrible, play with a controller if you have one. Pressing 1/3 and Q/E to change tabs is a no-no and shows that it's a port.First off, you don't really do any detective work, I often got the answers to detective questions wrong because I was over thinking and in the end, I sometimes tried multiple times until I got it right.The town is simply dull, some NPCs keep walking in the same path, really killing the atmosphere, they also have only two lines of dialogue, which are boring. Since there's no map/minimap, there was one time that I got lost and had to keep running all over the place trying to find my way. The barriers they added to limit the scope of the game are horrible, making the game feel more linear than it should have.Also, the combat is simply terrible, you can see they added this part only to make the game lengthier because it's not fun at all. The QTE buttons keep changing, making you sometimes fail and get annoyed.

content:
er 30, 2015
												I am a casual female gamer, not great with button mashing. I really love rich story lines, rpg styled play, and puzzles! This game included all of that. If you're casual like me, it's a great point and click that isn't boring. Too often I find the point and clicks are slow paced, but this isn't. Most of the game is really innate. You know what your goals are and what you have to do. I rarely needed to look something up, so that's a plus for the casual gamer. The storyline is reallllly cool, the characters, the voice acting, all of it. My only negative is I didn't clue in to just how open the world was. You can explore a lot and do side quests and I missed a lot of them because I was only following the storyline. Newb mistake for sure, so be sure you do all the fun stuff on the side to get all the achievements. Graphics and controls were great.

content:
23, 2014
												MSS is pretty much a PNC adventure game masquerading as a modern cinematic AAA game (which I don't find any better, by the way).  While the game has merit for any adventure game fan, know that the story falls apart and I doubt anyone will be satisfied with it.  So with such a major hook of pnc games not really delivering, what are you left with?At its heart, MSS is your typical textbook modern game design, except the main character doesn't carry a gun and you don't run around shooting at pop-up targets.  Instead, you are tasked with investigating your own death, complete with spritely sidekick and canned TWEEST.  This in itself isn't bad as mysteries often need to have at least some sort of turning point and well, being dead kind of demands you have a real-world sidekick to help you out.However, being of modern game design, MSS falls into the trap of checklist design; that is to say, it takes no risks and does pretty much everything by the book.  Exploration?  Check.  Voice actors?  Check.  Cinematics?  Check.  Hidden objects?  Check.  Progessive ability unlocking?  Check, check, check.  None of this bad, really; just saying it brings nothing new to the table.  The worst offender is the checkbox for action - because why would anyone play a game without action in it, right?  Pfft.  From time to time you will be forced to deal with a completely useless and forced section where you sneak around bad guys and try to get rid of 'em (or circumvent them entirely once you're tired of this ♥♥♥♥) because someone in development land has decided that under no circumstance should a game of this type be without an action sequence; problem is, it's stupid and provides nothing to the game other than padding and, of course, a checkbox.  Similarly, you'll be tasked several times to arbitrarily click on multiple clues to proceed through the game and it gets old fast - at least it's thematically sound what with the main character being a detective.  Whatever.Anyways, as far as fans of PNC games goes, this one isn't that bad.  The game has a runtime of approximately 8 hours, maybe 6.5 if you don't bother looking for all the hidden stuff (which is also pointless, but allows you to do some checklisting yourself).  I wouldn't recommend getting this at full price in any shape or form, but if you get a decent deal on it, say... $10 just to cover some of the production value, then why not give it a run-through?  It's kind of like watching the latest sci-fi space opera film just because you don't often see them being made and not because it's actually really good.  MSS is just a decent effort.tl;dr: Adventure game fans may enjoy this game on theme alone, but anyone looking for a meaty game experience will find that this offering is leaner than that girl you used to know whose bones could be counted individually when she had her shirt off.  So this remains a (meh) thumbs-up for adventure game fans, but a thumbs-down for anyone else.

												Awesome game. Reminded me of both "Fahrenheit" and the movie "Ghost". I see a lot of idiots misread the genre and poured out their virginity in a form of a negative bs, learn to read, ffs. It's action adventure!There are no puzzles in traditional point-and-click sense. content:
y 18
												Not a bad game... Thought I feel like this could have been a much superior experience with a little more effort... The core concepts definitely work, and the interaction between a living character and a ghost make for interesting gameplay situations... The game's key failing is in its actual interaction during investigations - you essentially look at things, and click on them, with very occasional sections where you select the most likely explanation of a given situation. This is woefully inadequate for a game that is supposedly about solving the mystery of your own death. I'd confidently state that this is pretty much a zero-difficulty game with no significant challenge except that of avoiding the irritating demons.The game has decent voice acting, yet some pretty ropey cutscenes, interesting ideas and systems, but inadequate use of them, a dreadful cut & paste soundtrack, but reasonable sound design. It could have been better, but that said, this game is still worth your time, so long as you don't buy it full price.

content:
19
												So... I love the idea of the story. Investigate your own murder, help other ghosts along the way. Superb premise. I play games for the story. I personally am not a fan of fight driven games, or games that constantly interrupt the story due to fights and battles inbetween. If the difficulty could be changed to "walk through the fight, so I can go on with my puzzles and story", then that would be ideal for me.As is, however, the controls are so infuriating that I stopped playing it in first chapter. Randomised-button-smashing-after-on-screen-prompt as a "battle" is not my description of fun, particularly when half the time the game doesn't react at all to the button usage even though you KNOW you have hit the right ones. In the right order. (edit: there is a function that lets you make the demons be completely unaware and they won't bother you. That at least let me play the game through to the end...)So, if you are after action, and battle and that tiresome interruption of the story, then yes, that games if for you and I can recommend it, because the graphics are amazing, and the idea behind it is great.Either way, if you are like me, a casual gamer that doesn't have a world of time and plays for exploration, story, puzzles, then no, this one is way too infuriating and I cannot recommend it. (Though, playable with Demon's off, it's bearable and I enjoyed it a tad bit more).Meh... Guess I'll stick to my "simple games" like Myst, Riven, Obduction, etc.

24
												This is easily the best game i've ever played! Granted, i am a strickly point and click gamer where there is a distinct beginning and end, and crime stories are definitely my favorite, but with that said, i have never played a game so incredibly clean and well-written. There was only one glitch that i ran into, and it didn't keep me from completing the game. It had to do with a side story, and although i usually like to be thorough in the games i play, i let it go and moved on (i had no choice unless i wanted to start over, which i definitely didn't want to do because i was well into the game). The graphics were amazing, the voiceover fantastic, and the story was intriguing and kept me interested to the very end. And to top it off, the ending surprised me. All in all i couldn't have enjoyed a game more (except for the glitch)
